fields.bodyText: When Warwickshire reached the NatWest final to face Gloucestershire, I was looking forward to one of the biggest days of my career. The game turned out to be an absolute disgrace. How the biggest domestic game of the year can end in such a way is completely beyond me. The rain on Saturday was a disappointing start for the spectators, but with the playing conditions stating that play could go on as late as eight o'clock, they must have had some hope of play. Those who had travelled to support their teams were at least able to claim a refund as not a ball was bowled but it was sad to see that there were always going to be too many empty seats. When I played in the 1993 final for Sussex against Warwickshire, Lord's was full to bursting and it was the greatest atmosphere I've ever experienced as a cricketer. A Lord's final should be like that, the last great occasion of the summer played out in front of a full house. On Sunday the ground was less than a third full but play was possible. For the first time a NatWest final was being played on an old pitch - the one used for the Benson & Hedges Cup final in fact - and therefore all the worries about a new pitch making the final one-sided were forgotten. Using an old pitch means that the NatWest could return to its traditional end-of-season date. It wasn't until around the thirtieth over of Gloucestershire's innings - Warwickshire had completed our full 50 overs - that it even looked likely to rain, but when it did it came down very hard. The playing conditions dictate that an over is lost for every four full minutes that the teams are off the pitch so time was of the essence. What those conditions also state is that play on the Sunday ends at half past six and not eight o'clock as was the case the previous day. Why? It gets dark at the same time and a game of this magnitude should be played out to its natural conclusion whenever possible. The Monday could have been used - it has been in the past - and as it was a Bank holiday I'm sure quite a few would have turned up. As it turned out the game was called off and we were informed of the decision by one of the umpires coming to the dressing room and saying, 'By the way you've lost.' It seemed a little ironic to be collecting our medals (the losers' variety) in glorious sunshine. Had more thought gone into drawing up the playing conditions what few spectators were present could have been treated to another 90 minutes of nail-biting cricket. I've been full of praise for the two division championship this season but domestic cricket's showpiece game deserves far better than what was served up last weekend. County cricket needs all the support it can get at the moment. Not playing the biggest game of the year to a proper finish is hardly going to help.

fields.headline: Swann breaks a stubborn tail
fields.standfirst:
Northamptonshire 469
Gloucestershire 186 & 209
Northamptonshire won by an innings and 74 runs
fields.trailText:
Northamptonshire 469
Gloucestershire 186 & 209
Northamptonshire won by an innings and 74 runs.
fields.body:
Division Two has been so akin to the game of Snakes and Ladders that even at this late stage of the season, at least six counties remain in contention for three promotion places. However, Northamptonshire, snatching an exciting win with 10 balls to spare - their fifth consecutive triumph - can be more optimistic than all their rivals.

The weather had done its best to save Gloucestershire's skin. Three hours were lost on Friday and if numerous stoppages yesterday amounted to no more than eight overs, it was because Northants' rate of delivery was so quick.

Also, the pitch had proved more durable than could have been expected, Northants only taking two wickets before lunch. The first of them, taken by Jason Brown with his very first ball of the day, fell early. Tim Hancock played for turn which did not materialise and the outcome was a snick to David Ripley.

Having tried all other options to break a solid second-wicket partnership between Dominic Hewson and Matt Windows, Hayden turned to his second off-spinner Alec Swann, understudying for his injured elder brother. The pitch may have helped him to root out the well-established Hewson, with the ball stopping as he pushed off the back foot and gave a return catch.

But another obdurate stand formed between Windows and the doyen of the circuit, Kim Barnett. No success for 18 overs and then Swann junior pulled another rabbit out of the bag when Adrian Rollins flung himself to take a great catch at short leg.

That was Barnett gone and Windows, who had shown immense restraint for two hours, cut uppishly at Brown shortly after.

Now a grim Mark Alleyne and Jack Russell set their stall and manned it for 30 overs before the ingenuous use of Paul Taylor as a left-arm spinner produced a breach. Taylor spun one to induce a brilliantly held slip catch and in his next over, Russell chopped on.

But Jeremy Snape and Martyn Ball carried the struggle as far as the 11th over of the last hour and just when Gloucestershire seemed safe, Ball lashed out with a hook at Darren Cousins and top-edged a steepler. A fired-up Cousins then needed only eight more balls to demolish the tail.

fields.headline: Hussain upsetting the balance
fields.trailText: I am delighted that England are on the brink of their first series win against West Indies since 1969. As an Englishman, I wouldn't want anything else, and it will do wonders for the game in this country if it comes to pass - right down to the grass roots.
fields.body:
I am delighted that England are on the brink of their first series win against West Indies since 1969. As an Englishman, I wouldn't want anything else, and it will do wonders for the game in this country if it comes to pass - right down to the grass roots.

But - and isn't there always a but? - we have to thank West Indies for making us look a good side. I am not sure that we are just yet, and there are several pointers in the current Test before we start getting carried away about what we might do to the Australians next year.

First, let us examine the performances of Nasser Hussain. He went into this Test with a series average of 15.2 runs and has never looked like scoring. Hussain was left forlorn in the Oval pavilion last night after bagging his first pair. A duck on Thursday, when England's fine opening partnership had only just been broken, was miserable enough; a second yesterday - trapped lbw by Nixon McLean - took the biscuit.

But who can be surprised? When Hussain broke a finger and had to miss the second Test at Lord's, Michael Vaughan and Atherton did a superb job as England won by two wickets to square the series - yet what happened next did neither England nor Hussain any favours. The skipper almost immediately declared himself fit and returned when the series resumed. He was struggling before his injury and has continued to struggle since.

I am not questioning his undoubted ability, but he is not playing well enough this summer to justify his place, even if he is a good leader. By continuing to pick a non-playing captain - or surely a non-batting one - the rest of the side's balance is compromised.

Look at this Oval Test. The selectors - not surprisingly - elected to include a spinner in the squad as, after all, Surrey's HQ has proved a happy hunting ground for spinners, notably Phil Tufnell, in recent years. But the selectors opted not for Tufnell but Ashley Giles and then, having chosen Giles and upset Tufnell, they couldn't find a place in the final 11 for Giles.

Why? Could it be something to do with Graeme Hick batting at No7?. Why on earth is a batsman with more than 100 centuries to his name batting at seven? I'll tell you why - he's there as an insurance policy against our lower order folding like a pack of cards, although some might argue that having Hick as insurance in a Test match is a very high-risk policy indeed.

The same whispers around the England camp suggest that Giles got the nod over Tufnell because he might contribute a lot more with the bat. There you have it again, a defensive attitude prompted by our inferiority complex on batting. I had been labouring under the misapprehension that a spinner's job was to attack and take wickets and, if that were the case, there's nobody better at the moment for England than Tufnell. No wonder he's upset.

Upset, also, at missing the winter tour. Instead his place has gone not to Giles, nor to Chris Schofield of Lancashire, but to Ian Salisbury, making a return to the Test scene after an unhappy experience a few years ago. But why? Salisbury, with respect, does not take wickets, he buys them. I don't know why he is back in favour if he takes his wickets at 70 runs a time. Perhaps bowling in tandem with Saqlain at Surrey has made him look good because batsmen are being tied down at one end and chance their arm with Salisbury at the other.

England need to have confidence in their batting order and pick their best bowlers to attack. In this department there has been some good news this summer. Andy Caddick is undoubtedly our best new-ball bowler and he'll remain potent if he remembers to keep the ball pitched up an extra couple of feet on the length he has tended to bowl in the past. His height means that he will still achieve the bounce he wants.

Darren Gough, too, has bowled well and in Vaughan and Trescothick there is a real feeling that we have emerging batsmen of determination and class. The touring squad will, however, need to be on their mettle to get through a tricky-looking winter tour to Pakistan and Sri Lanka with their recently restored reputations intact.

For the moment, though, let's prepare to savour a series win against the West Indies. It has been a long time coming (I'd only just retired last time we beat them in '69) and the team deserve every credit.

I am not questioning his undoubted ability, but he is not playing well enough this summer to justify his place, even if he is a good leader. By continuing to pick a non-playing captain - or surely a non-batting one - the rest of the side's balance is compromised. Look at this Oval Test. The selectors - not surprisingly - elected to include a spinner in the squad as, after all, Surrey's HQ has proved a happy hunting ground for spinners, notably Phil Tufnell, in recent years. But the selectors opted not for Tufnell but Ashley Giles and then, having chosen Giles and upset Tufnell, they couldn't find a place in the final 11 for Giles. Why? Could it be something to do with Graeme Hick batting at No7?. Why on earth is a batsman with more than 100 centuries to his name batting at seven? I'll tell you why - he's there as an insurance policy against our lower order folding like a pack of cards, although some might argue that having Hick as insurance in a Test match is a very high-risk policy indeed. The same whispers around the England camp suggest that Giles got the nod over Tufnell because he might contribute a lot more with the bat. There you have it again, a defensive attitude prompted by our inferiority complex on batting. I had been labouring under the misapprehension that a spinner's job was to attack and take wickets and, if that were the case, there's nobody better at the moment for England than Tufnell. No wonder he's upset. Upset, also, at missing the winter tour. Instead his place has gone not to Giles, nor to Chris Schofield of Lancashire, but to Ian Salisbury, making a return to the Test scene after an unhappy experience a few years ago. But why? Salisbury, with respect, does not take wickets, he buys them. I don't know why he is back in favour if he takes his wickets at 70 runs a time. Perhaps bowling in tandem with Saqlain at Surrey has made him look good because batsmen are being tied down at one end and chance their arm with Salisbury at the other. England need to have confidence in their batting order and pick their best bowlers to attack. In this department there has been some good news this summer. Andy Caddick is undoubtedly our best new-ball bowler and he'll remain potent if he remembers to keep the ball pitched up an extra couple of feet on the length he has tended to bowl in the past. His height means that he will still achieve the bounce he wants. Darren Gough, too, has bowled well and in Vaughan and Trescothick there is a real feeling that we have emerging batsmen of determination and class. The touring squad will, however, need to be on their mettle to get through a tricky-looking winter tour to Pakistan and Sri Lanka with their recently restored reputations intact. For the moment, though, let's prepare to savour a series win against the West Indies. It has been a long time coming (I'd only just retired last time we beat them in '69) and the team deserve every credit.

fields.headline: Atherton's finest hour
fields.trailText: The rain clouds were gathering, Gough and Caddick had come off and West Indies were comfortably placed at 32 without loss. A draw seemed the only possible result.
fields.body:
The rain clouds were gathering, Gough and Caddick had come off and West Indies were comfortably placed at 32 without loss. A draw seemed the only possible result.

But nothing is certain with the new soaraway successful England team. Cork bowled a wicket maiden. White responded with a double-wicket maiden - including Brian Lara bowled round his legs for his first golden duck against England ('Can't play the English quicks, that lad').

In the next over Cork levelled the wicket score at 2-2 only for White to edge ahead 3-2 with the precious wicket of Sarwan. West Indies 39 for five, 42 runs away from saving the follow-on. England with the first series win against West Indies for 31 years in the bag. Cue general euphoria.

And the real hero was a man who was averaging a little over seventeen for the series, doesn't bowl, and during the extraordinary opening hour didn't even field the ball. England would not have been in the position they were in yesterday if it hadn't been for Michael Atherton.

To understand this, you have to cast your mind back to the first Test, in which no England batsman made more than 34 in either innings and they were walloped by the Windies. Then move on to Lord's and that extraordinary 100th Test. On the first day, West Indies cruised past 150 for one wicket. On the second day, a part of all four innings was played on the same day for the first time in Test history. After all the mayhem, England needed 180-odd to win with all their wickets standing. The most important of which was Mike Atherton's.

On this everyone at Lord's was agreed. 'It all depends on Mike,' said one. 'It's up to Mike,' said another. 'Mike needs to make 70,' said yet another. There could be no argument. If Mike succeeded England would level the series; if he failed they would be 2-0 down and effectively out of the series.

The next morning it was Atherton v Ambrose. Time after time Curtly came in from the Pavilion End, beat the outside of Atherton's bat and grimaced. Time after time Atherton grinned back at him. It was even better than his confrontation with Allan Donald.

He batted for 214 minutes in making his 45 and by the time he was finally out, England needed fifty-something to win with six wickets in hand. Naturally, they nearly blew it. Indeed, if it hadn't been for that most unlikely of heroes, Dominic Cork, they would have blown it. Unlikely because ever since he took a hat-trick against West Indies five years earlier, The Corkster had being convinced that he was destined to be a hero. And pratfall after pratfall had done nothing to rid him of this conviction.

But this, at last, was his moment. Jumping up and down like a nervous Derek Randall and barking instructions like a parody sergeant-major, Cork took control and guided his side to victory.

Yet without Atherton there could have been no Cork. And no victory.

All sports rely on streaks and it is only with hindsight that you can pinpoint the moment when a losing run ended and a winning sequence began. The Saturday of the Lord's Test may prove to be such a turning point.

If it is, then Atherton may be able to do something he must have been despairing of ever doing, leaving the Test team on a high. Last week, in an interview with The New Statesman he said: 'I can't really envisage going beyond next year. Not much longer than a year, that's for sure.

'Whether it be for Lancashire or England, the next year would be the maximum period. (Pause.) I said that without really thinking about it.' Which is normally a sign that someone means what they're saying.

In between now and then England play Pakistan (a), Sri Lanka (a) and Australia (h). On known form you'd expect them to lose all three but that's the funny thing about streaks. Once one gets up and running, the most unlikely results occur.

It may be that Atherton - after 102 Tests, more than half as captain - is finally about to be a member of a successful team.

No one deserves it more. Throughout the Nineties - the infamous dirt-in-pocket episode and his damaged back notwithstanding - he has, unflinching and uncomplaining, given his all for his side. There has been no dissent and no tacky OK! covers. He has kept his head down and kept on batting.

Now as he approaches the end of a distinguished - in terms of personal performance, if not team results - career, it would be gratifying if he were to receive the success that has long been due to him.

fields.headline: Ailing but alive
fields.standfirst: Right balm must be applied to the right wound
fields.trailText: By today, the fifth Test should be over. It is now all but inconceivable that a cricket match involving the West Indies should go into the fourth day and only an unusually good West Indian performance or unusually bad weather can make even the third day a sure thing. England, as every Englishman will always remember and no West Indian will ever forget, needed only two days to wrap up the fourth Test. West Indies have made four of their worst Test scores in the past 18 months and have struggled three times in their last three Tests to pass their lowest-ever score of 51 against Australia at the Queen's Park Oval in 1999.
fields.body:
By today, the fifth Test should be over. It is now all but inconceivable that a cricket match involving the West Indies should go into the fourth day and only an unusually good West Indian performance or unusually bad weather can make even the third day a sure thing. England, as every Englishman will always remember and no West Indian will ever forget, needed only two days to wrap up the fourth Test. West Indies have made four of their worst Test scores in the past 18 months and have struggled three times in their last three Tests to pass their lowest-ever score of 51 against Australia at the Queen's Park Oval in 1999.

Anyone with half a brain can add up these figures to the same total: disaster. Nevertheless, every cricket-lover in the world knows deep in his heart that you count out the West Indies at your peril. The match may well be over and lost today, but who would have staked his life, last Thursday morning, that the West Indies would not have won?

The same team that mucked about for four days in January defended 98 runs on the last day to avoid humiliation by Zimbabwe. The same team that made the 51 in 1999 beat world champions Australia in the next two Tests. The same team that make 54 in the second innings make 400 in the first. Even if they have already lost the Wisden Trophy, the West Indies remain capable of springing back to beat Australia (though even the most patriotic West Indian would consider it unlikely).

Any attempt to understand Caribbean cricket that does not fuse the scientific evidence the brain so easily processes with the Truth the heart cannot deny will simply fail.

The causes of the rot have long been recognised: massive neglect by incompetent West Indies cricket boards; the changing of ICC rules to weaken the West Indies pace attack (and the blind insistence on sticking to the four-fast-bowlers formula although only two have been available for years); the influence of American basketball; the complacency falsely based on the successes of teams trained on English county cricket; the relatively small populations separated by water and distance from which to draw; a mediocre inter-island regional competition; and a furious inter-island rivalry that precludes even the most perspicacious of West Indians from judging clearly any issue relating to a player from his own jurisdiction.

The rot is impossible to deny, but there still remains a great deal of wood and the grain is still the finest. Even at this dismal stage, even the uninformed spectator can discern that West Indies cricket is played at a spiritual level far higher than any other, even Pakistan's, who play for their God.

Fifty years ago, in Beyond a Boundary, the late CLR James, who was born in Trinidad and died in Brixton, argued the case for cricket as Art. Thirty years ago, Robert Pirsig argued, in Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance, that Quality (or, for these purposes, Art) exists at the nexus of the conflicting but equally valid Scientific and Spiritual approaches to all human endeavour. Two years ago, in Beyond Belief , VS Naipaul explained the fatal difficulty facing any fervent believer when confronted with a problem requiring a secular solution: the answer of the believer is always a more fervent belief, which will do if what is needed is a spiritual or mental solution, but is lethal if what is missing is something entirely practical, such as economic growth or net practice. The person who relies upon faith alone is incapable of solving his secular problem and indeed only compounds it.

Before the West Indies take the field, they say a team prayer. Brian Lara and Curtly Ambrose, asked if they believe in God, reply, 'Of course!' with the contemptuous look they usually reserve for a part-time bowler or batsman. God has played a bigger part in West Indies cricket than he, she or it has in any other nation's. (Again, with the possible exception of only Pakistan.)

West Indies cricket, at its best, is CLR James's Art played at Robert Pirsig's point of Quality, where the scientific and emotional approaches meet and fuse into something far greater. No matter how successful it was, though, it was always played unconsciously. Players got their spiritual or emotional input on the beaches of the Caribbean and their net practice on English county grounds and no one gave training a moment's thought or respect.

Courtney Walsh, when he became captain, asked for one change in the team uniform: that the crest be placed over the left and not the right breast, to reflect the team's conviction that they played from the heart. The emotional side of the game has always been far more important to the West Indian because the West Indies as a nation does not exist beyond the boundary. The cricket square is Westminster and the Queen and the Beatles and Disraeli and Gladstone and fish-and-chips and the NHS. It is all the West Indian people have that defines them as themselves.

For 15 years, West Indies, playing unconscious Quality cricket dominated the world. When the team first began losing (or, to be accurate, not winning all the time), the kind of practical solution the Australians found in their Academy became necessary. What was offered, however, was the answer of the fervent believer: forget this crap about taking the shine off the new ball or playing yourself in! Attack the ball! Play your natural game!

Which, of course, was right, and plugged directly into the critical emotional aspect of West Indies cricket; except that it failed to admit that the West Indian 'natural' emotional game has always included the ignored scientific element of training. Believing more fervently could never solve the secular problems of, say, the limitation of overseas players in English county cricket or the number of bouncers per over when what was needed was, say, an enhanced regional competition or a greater reliance on spin.

But from the great Sir Viv to the lowliest spectator at the back of the highest stand, the answer was greater Faith. Attack the ball and trust in God that West Indies would achieve whatever was necessary on the day, whether that was to bowl a team out twice or make 400 runs in two sessions; if all else failed, He would send three days of rain. Of course, it could not work. Quality exists only at the nexus of the two approaches; however much of one you have cannot compensate for not having enough of the other.

Faith thus failed West Indian cricket and, first the team, and then the nation, stopped believing in itself. More emphasis was placed on training and technique and less on playing the natural game; and now, after a decade of uncertainty, the short leg is the emotional aspect of Quality and the team still limps. Only when extreme pressure, such as the prospect of being beaten at home by Zimbabwe or, perhaps, losing the Wisden trophy, concentrates their minds can the team bring the scientific and spiritual elements of their game together into the compound of Quality.

West Indian cricket is not dead, whatever the result of the Oval Test. To be sure it is ailing, but the disease is treatable. However, no accurate prognosis can be made without first the correct diagnosis. What is necessary is that West Indians come to understand their own process. West Indian cricket writing, particularly that of Tony Cozier, is now its most valuable resource. Rudi Webster, the psychologist who helped bring the team back from the humiliation of South Africa, or someone like him, should be a permanent member of the coaching staff.

But on no account should anyone be excused from net practice.

West Indian cricket is still just a tilt of the head away from glory. For every battle-weary fast bowler who bows and hums softly to himself, as Harry Belafonte did, 'Come, Mr Tally Man, tally me bananas/Daylight come and me wanna go home', there is a boy on a beach or in a canefield with his head held high and shouting to the heavens as Bob Marley did, 'Emancipate yourself from mental slavery/None but ourselves can free our minds'. The trick is to apply the right balm to the right wound.

B C Pires is a columnist for the Trinidad Express and Weekend Independent and writes exclusively about the part of West Indian cricket that takes place off the field.

fields.headline: France loses its heartbeat
fields.trailText: French football today wakes up to a new dawn now that Didier eschamps has carried his final bucket of water and Laurent Blanc has planted his last lucky smooch onto the head of Fabien Barthez.
fields.body:
After the double, the quits. French football today wakes up to a new dawn now that Didier eschamps has carried his final bucket of water and Laurent Blanc has planted his last lucky smooch onto the head of Fabien Barthez. After 11 years of service during which they have amassed 200 caps between them, a nation bids au revoir to two men whose influence in helping France to become the finest team on the planet has been monumental. Merci, as they clink their Pastis, pour les souvenirs .

With Cantona-esque timing, they have bowed out at the summit. Although Blanc, 33 years old and counting, had made his decision before the European Championship climax Deschamps was struck by a sudden feeling of finality almost the instant David Trezeguet's golden goal soared into the Italian net. Whilst the rest of the team frolicked on the turf in Rotterdam Deschamps was absorbed by the feeling that his endgame had come. It could get no better. Roger Lemerre embraced him and there, in the middle of the pitch, he admitted privately to his manager that it was over. Their conversation was caught by the camera's eye and later on the media employed lip-reading experts to decipher their exchange. The gist of it was that Lemerre urged Deschamps not to be rash but his mind was made up.

'When I say I stop, I stop.' He can't bear the thought of playing the infamous match-too-much. In a way France's success has contributed to his retirement because as World Champions they don't need to qualify for the next tournament in 2002, and the idea of playing two years of friendlies no longer hits the spot. Lemerre suggested he could pick and choose his matches but Deschamps replied that the captain of France should not be on the bench. He is (although Chelsea might query this) an all or nothing player. This is a man who stood up to Bernard Tapie at Marseille when most players were far too intimidated to even utter a word, and the man whose club CV includes two European Cups and three Italian titles. Of France he says: 'I gave all my energy, my faculties, my time, my heart and my spirit.'

The farewell was delayed to include two more friendly matches so that he and Blanc could properly savour the 'after Euro 2000 party'. They have soaked up the adulation of Marseille, France's footballing hotbed, in a charity match against the Fifa All Stars and now the emotional curtain call at the Stade de France, stage for their most golden of days.

In their 11 years they have witnessed sweeping changes. From crowds of 25,000 at the Parc des Princes, through gut-wrenching failure to qualify for World Cups, to the ultimate highs. 'When I was younger we just tried not to lose,' reminisces Blanc. 'Since I began we have become a club, a family, with our ups and downs. I've known some very deep downs but from the bottom we rose to be World Champions.'

So Les Bleus are left with a treasure chest full of memories. Few players anywhere have been as incessantly successful as 'Dede', a Frenchman's Frenchman, the little big boss with his puffed out chest, scampering legs, and arms best remembered for the unique achievement of hoisting both of football's most glamorous international trophies.

Then there is 'Lolo', as loved for his Mr Ordinary demeanour and philosophical ease as his supremely cultured defending. When his country fumed as he missed the World Cup Final, victim of an undeserved red card brandished after Croatia's Slaven Bilic took play-acting to a tasteless new level, Blanc refused to apportion blame. When romantics tried to hail the Euro 2000 triumph as 'his' final because of his prior misfortune he politely brushed them aside. It was not his, he countered, it was the team's. You'd expect nothing less from one of the game's good guys. He looks like he goes to a twenty franc barber, he smokes when he wants to, and his manager at Inter Milan raves about him so much Sir Alex Ferguson hasn't a hope of prising him away.

Blanc is known as Le President, Deschamps is Le Capitaine, and their legacy is huge. Arsène Wenger suspects France will suffer from the dual retirement of two of the truest of Blues. He believes they are the heartbeat of the side, men of immense experience and mental fortitude who pull all the strands together.

The pep talks that Deschamps gave Zinedine Zidane during the World Cup were detailed, inspiring, almost the work of a manager. And what better example of Blanc's status than the moment he took the tactical initiative to push himself up front in extra time in the quarter-final against a brilliantly resistant Paraguay - he rammed home the golden goal.

Their influence on the younger members of the squad is immense. As Thierry Henry reflects: 'In a group the most important thing is respect and while it's normal for us to have respect for more experienced players they respected us too. They were very nice to us, advising us how to be if we want to have a good career. I'll miss them as people and players. They were exceptional.'

It may take a while for France to recover the sense of leadership, experience, camaraderie, and tactical sophistication which stemmed from them. Marcel Desailly, exemplary stopper as he is, benefits so much from the built-in understanding he shares with Blanc. France are hoping Patrick Vieira will develop the maturity which will see them through when Emmanuel Petit is having one of his introspective or over-emotional days.

It is hard to imagine much of a dip on the horizon when France have such gifted understudies in the wings. Vieira can bring something extra to the midfield party and Lilian Thuram, consistently admired for his defensive qualities in Italy, can move calmly into the centre, allowing Vincent Candela - another who has blossomed in the uncompromising world of calcio - to step in on the right.

The departure of Deschamps (who has captained his country more times than anyone else) means the armband is up for grabs. Desailly is tipped for the honour. The feeling is that Zidane - another popular choice - doesn't need the extra responsibility because he is already commanding, in his own radiant way.

'It's a new chapter but we have to turn the page and I hope everything will go well,' concludes Henry. If they find a new singer to take over from Deschamps leading the dressing room theme tune of Gloria Gaynor's I Will Survive, they might just be all right.

fields.headline: Basham buries Pompey
fields.trailText: The former Southampton striker Steve Basham's first goal for a year sunk a disappointing Portsmouth to extend Preston's excellent start to the season. Newly promoted to the First Division, Preston are up to fourth in the table, still unbeaten at home and the target of survival in their first season back at this level in 19 years looks more than realistic.
fields.body:
The former Southampton striker Steve Basham's first goal for a year sunk a disappointing Portsmouth to extend Preston's excellent start to the season. Newly promoted to the First Division, Preston are up to fourth in the table, still unbeaten at home and the target of survival in their first season back at this level in 19 years looks more than realistic.

Portsmouth, on the other hand, were poor. Not until the final quarter of the match did they mount any kind of sustained pressure, although they felt the game swung on a late first-half penalty appeal when the Preston skipper, Sean Gregan, appeared to pull down Lee Mills in the box. Nothing was given and within 40 seconds of the restart, Basham connected superbly on the volley with a poor headed clearance from Darren Moore to beat Russell Hoult high to his right.

'Incidents like that change games', said the manager Tony Pullis afterwards. 'The lad felt he was brought down but nothing was given. It was a poor goal to concede from our point of view, and overall we were flat, which was disappointing.'

The Preston manager, David Moyes said: 'When the lad went down, I didn't like the look of it, but the referee was closer than me. I'm sure others will go against us later in the season. I thought we deserved it. We're still learning at this level and we don't know what to expect from game to game. But when we get the ball down and play it like we did today in the second half, we're finding we are a match for most teams.'

The penalty incident notwithstanding, Preston were good value for the points, because despite Portsmouth's late onslaught, their finishing was bad. Steve Claridge brought an excellent save from Tepi Moilanen from 20 yards, but failed to get a last-minute header on target from just four yards. Lee Bradbury made an impact when he came on midway through the second half, but fired his best effort straight at Moilanen.

A low-key first half had failed to produce any real excitement, although Michael Jackson could have scored from a point-blank header directed straight at Hoult. But when Preston struck in their first attack of the second, they upped the pace significantly. Paul McKenna probably had their best other chance when Jon Macken sent him clear on the left, the shot was hard and low but whistled inches wide.

fields.headline: Owen punch packed with spirit
fields.trailText: When Aime Jacquet, France's technical director and the coach who masterminded their World Cup triumph, mentioned that England were only one or two years behind his country's footballing success story, it felt like he was being obscenely generous.
fields.body:
When Aime Jacquet, France's technical director and the coach who masterminded their World Cup triumph, mentioned that England were only one or two years behind his country's footballing success story, it felt like he was being obscenely generous.

It speaks volumes for the gulf in status and spirit to realise that never, not for one mili-second, did any Frenchman even countenance the fact that they could lose to England. They gathered to pay tribute to retiring heroes and bask in their eminence. Booming Queen's We Are The Champions seemed like rubbing noses noses in the merdre: England supply the music, but only those with French accents could sing along. The wolf whistling, for their visitors, was more derisory than daunting. Look, they were chuckling, at the state you're in.

Unimaginably swiftly, they were stunned into silence. Dennis Wise clobbered the mighty Zinedine Zidane before you could say excusez-moi and England began to play. Maybe, just maybe, England's super-optimistic manager doesn't have his head far above the clouds after all.

A few subtle changes were rung but collectively a good deal has changed since the morale-sapping mediocrity of a sorry summer in the Low Countries. A natural left- footer was employed in place of the ill-starred Phil Neville. David Beckham, the one English player viewed on foreign shores as genuinely world class, was handed the reins in the centre and sparkled. An adapted formation, with Paul Scholes tucking in behind Andy Cole, made England less predictable. 'It's a bit like the Manchester United shape, as opposed to Michael Owen and Alan Shearer alongside each other,' noted Scholes.

He reckoned this contest was a 'great chance to get a bit of pride back after Euro 2000, to do it against the best team in the world'. After a slick opening spell when Bernard Lama's goal was liberally peperred, France must have been wondering who these imposters in white were. They suddenly looked oddly composed on the ball. Keegan had asked them to take responsibility and nobody shirked. Each individual imposed himself more than was evident under Shearer's uneasy leadership.

A French observer, wide eyed at half-time, exclaimed: 'England can play football!' Order, in his eyes, was restored when Emmanuel Petit opened the scoring and France began to flow forward in the manner to which they are accustomed. Enter Michael Owen, and England were able to take even more than mended pride from this hotly competitive friendly.

As a rehearsal before the real deal begins again with Germany and a potentially slippery trip to Finland next month, it inspired fresh hope. Didier Deschamps, as he rides off into the sunset with his international cap fully feathered, had given England a parting shot: if you don't improve fast, you won't qualify for the next World Cup.

French footballers sniffing at the English game is something we are used to by now (lyrical outpourings from Messieurs Anelka, Petit and Leboeuf spring to mind). But, given their global supremacy at the moment, and their experience of a successful system, perhaps they are not the worst judges around. Robert Pires, only two weeks into his English experience, made some interesting observations about his first impressions in L'Equipe .

He explained how he was glad to sample his initial taste from the bench, at Arsenal's opening game at Sunderland. 'Watching that first half fightened me. It even shocked me. English football is a fight, a street fight at times,' he said. 'They spend their time provoking you, insulting you and getting on your nerves. The English make enormous use of their elbows and pull shirts. They know refs let them play on and take maximum advantage of it.'

But it is his response to this, a typical one for French footballing troubadours, which sums up why their team have evolved into such a potent force: 'I have to adapt to English football without losing any of my own qualities. If I have to use my arms to avoid getting split eyebrows every match, I will do so. If I was not ready to go this way, I would have signed for Real Madrid.' Half of Roger Lemerre's squad have spent some time in the Premiership colony and most of them improved in stature from doing so.

Scholes remains cautious of the imminent Germany confrontation: 'It will be tough. They have started afresh with a new manager, and it won't be like the Euro 2000 game. They were struggling then. They didn't look like a team who were getting on with each other. Their spirit looks a lot better now.' But so, tellingly, does England's.

webTitle: How they rated: England player by player

fields.headline: How they rated: England player by player
fields.trailText: DAVID SEAMAN 6
fields.body:
DAVID SEAMAN 6

Sported England's answer to Petit's pony-tail - and the old Arsenal man's was more impressive. But Seaman also sported a safe pair of hands until Petit struck. Inconsistent distribution, but his reflexes looked sharp.

GARETH BARRY 6

What England have cried out for in recent times is genuine balance on the left. Barry says he might not be in the side if he were right-footed. He may have a point, but he rarely looked out of place.

TONY ADAMS (Captain) 6

The new captain started the game with question marks against his stickability at 34. A late-ish first-half tackle by Deschamps kept the debate going as Adams failed to emerge after the break. Generally a little shaky and with a gashed ankle as a souvenir.

MARTIN KEOWN 7

Not too many problems from the junior partner in Arsenal's long-standing rearguard. Coped pretty well with club-mate Henry's threats.

SOL CAMPBELL 6

Generally sound holding up the right flank but he may feel he was at fault in the build-up to Petit's goal. He did not cope with the loose ball and Zidane pounced to set up the strike.

NICK BARMBY 7

Impressive first half. He was a real bundle of energy on the left flank and perhaps should have scored with a close-range header. He connected well but Lama produced a fine block.

DENNIS WISE 6

Is Bobby Robson right? Can Wise cut it at the top level. On this evidence, Robson might have a point. If his job was to release Beckham, it didn't quite work.

DAVID BECKHAM 6

A frustrating confection of a display. Ineffective in his central role for much of the time, he would occasionally pop up with a fizzing pass or dead-ball contribution. Jury still out as a playmaker.

DARREN ANDERTON 6

Nice start, shame about the finish. He gave way after 69 minutes to Kieron Dyer but did show some flashes of skill and imagination.

PAUL SCHOLES 8

Pick of the bunch and particularly good before Petit's strike. He overshadowed Beckham in midfield with marauding runs and some terrific passes. One complaint - perhaps dropped too deep off Cole at times.

ANDY COLE 7

Could have stolen the glory four minutes after the break when he engineered a fine chance at inside-right, but could not beat Lama. Not completely happy in a lone striking role.

SUBS

MICHAEL OWEN ( for Scholes, 78) 8

Immediate dividend as he converted fellow substitute Dyer's cross with a superb volley

KIERON DYER (for Anderton, 69) 7

Calm, composed and a neat cross for the goal.

STEVE McMANAMAN (for Barmby, 82) 6

GARETH SOUTHGATE (for Adams, 46) 7

Looked so at home and almost scored with his first touch, directing a header just wide. Good use of the shop window.

webTitle: Pokemon panic stirs fear of e-robbery

fields.headline: Pokemon panic stirs fear of e-robbery
fields.standfirst:
First it was kids. Now virus writers target the online banks, reports Simon Moores
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: First it was kids. Now virus writers target the online banks, reports Simon Moores.
fields.body:
Computer viruses are now so common that a new strain hardly raises an eyebrow, unless of course it's the kind that triggers the sort of chaos witnessed earlier in the year. Lifting his sights beyond simple extortion, an unsophisticated Filipino teenager scored seven on the Richter scale by writing a few lines of simple code that became the Love Letter virus. This romantic-sounding electronic worm triggered an epidemic of email, which swiftly crippled computing infrastructure around the planet.

Of the 45,000 or so computer viruses in the wild, by far the great majority are crude instruments of chaos, designed to infect, corrupt and damage as many personal computers as possible. And like any chronic virus, the first symptoms of illness quickly become signs of collapse, followed in some cases by silicon death, leaving very little doubt that something is badly wrong with your PC.

This summer, something changed in the shadowy world of The Matrix . Indeed, we may now be seeing the first real evidence of the virus 'industry' evolving beyond its adolescent, aerosol-can approach to information anarchy and instead pursuing more sinister challenges.

The first hint of the unusual came with the arrival of the Pokémon virus at the end of June. Unique perhaps because it is an exercise in malice focused exclusively at children. Remarkably and unlike anything else to do with the oversold Pokémon character, the hidden worm it carries is free, a feature which acts as a magnet to young internet users. Once again, the unfortunate Microsoft Outlook address book acts as the carrier and in this case, computer animation from the mischievous but lovable Pikachu character will trash Daddy's Windows system directory.

Following closely after the Pokémon panic came the first designer virus aimed at a personal banking application. No need for many of us to worry quite yet, as this one was aimed at customers of the Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS) but it is only a matter of time before some enterprising criminal starts thinking creatively about the increasing popularity of internet banking.

Who is liable, one asks, if a package of clandestine software, a 'Trojan', starts recording keystrokes and trawls your computer hard disk for account information? The banks are spending huge sums on protecting their own infrastructures, but the weakest point in the web still remains the customer. So can consumers reasonably protect their most confidential data? If such details as a password or perhaps even a PIN number are stolen, can they expect an online bank manager to be sympathetic?

Most recently, the Foundation for Information Policy Research web site published a detailed analysis of the contractual and technical weaknesses associated with the many different kinds of emerging e-commerce transaction services. The report revealed that customers of some online banks face the prospect of unlimited personal liability as a consequence of fraud. Invariably, such matters are reduced to questions of negligence and the exercise of reasonable care.

In response, the Halifax bank last week sent a wake-up call to the online banking sector, by announcing, through a deal with leading software security company, Trend Micro, that it would offer all its online customers a free anti-virus software package for their home PCs and provide free ongoing anti-virus updates. Other banks are bound to follow, or at least make reassuring noises while they assess the true scale of the risk as it emerges.

The foundation's director, Casper Bowden, says: 'It's a worrying scenario whether banks might invoke the small print if they suffered a systemic loss due to a virus. If it's one dissatisfied customer, the bank has a customer service problem. If it's 10,000 defrauded customers, it's a question of legal liability.'

Not so, says Jo Wright, a spokeswoman at Barclays Bank. 'Our customers will not be liable if they are victims of fraud, online or otherwise. We will investigate any claim but - should such a thing happen and a large number of customers are affected - we may have to look at each individual case'.

The bank has posted this promise to its website and offers detailed information on how users can protect their account information. It stresses: 'Customers should always be careful when opening emails from unknown sources. This is the most likely way that this sort of fraud could be attempted.'

This may sound like good news but banks aren't famous for their speed in resolving customers' problems. If larger numbers are involved, the process could be slow, and Barclays seemed a little vague about the small print and didn't call us back.

Eric Chien at the Symantec Anti-Virus Research Centre, says: 'Before online banking the opportunity for fraud on this scale just wasn't there. The weakest point is still the home user's personal computer. The Halifax news is a good step forward but the responsibility lies with the banks to invest in customer confidence. People just don't trust online banking.'

The UBS 'Trojan' virus may have been the first example of something new, but it was trivial technically. It simply illustrated how a virus writer's motive could shift from trying to win recognition towards personal gain.

It seems that virus writers see little reward in writing code that targets popular home financial software. Invariably, these packages encrypt the data they hold, and the general architecture of Windows-based PCs makes it easier to steal information directfrom the keyboard than to unscramble professionally written software.

In fact, a really clever virus could conceivably collect and pass on information from many thousands of PCs and, perhaps one day, even mobile phones, to another country. This in turn might be able to execute thousands of small e-commerce transactions before any action could be taken.

Chien says: 'The only silver bullet is user education and solid content security. We can only anticipate and protect.'

Ian Melamed, chief technical officer of the internet security firm SatelliteSafe Europe, says: 'The e-commerce equation is best described by the formula trust = speed + security, and with the proliferation of malicious code, the security aspect of e-commerce is taking precedent over speed of delivery.'

But online security, the integrity of the relationship between a customer and internet-based transaction systems is no longer a private sector issue. Public Sector agencies - including both the Inland Revenue, for self-assessment, and Customs & Excise, for Vat - have to meet Government targets for the wired economy.

Given the sad catalogue of mishaps to date, it is, says one reformed hacker, 'only a matter of time before some clever soul opens his software toolbox and starts to explore what opportunities might lie behind the holes in this particular piece of Swiss cheese'.

 Simon Moores is chairman of the Research Group (www.drmoores.com).

And like any chronic virus, the first symptoms of illness quickly become signs of collapse, followed in some cases by silicon death, leaving very little doubt that something is badly wrong with your PC. This summer, something changed in the shadowy world of The Matrix . Indeed, we may now be seeing the first real evidence of the virus 'industry' evolving beyond its adolescent, aerosol-can approach to information anarchy and instead pursuing more sinister challenges. The first hint of the unusual came with the arrival of the Pokémon virus at the end of June. Unique perhaps because it is an exercise in malice focused exclusively at children. Remarkably and unlike anything else to do with the oversold Pokémon character, the hidden worm it carries is free, a feature which acts as a magnet to young internet users. Once again, the unfortunate Microsoft Outlook address book acts as the carrier and in this case, computer animation from the mischievous but lovable Pikachu character will trash Daddy's Windows system directory. Following closely after the Pokémon panic came the first designer virus aimed at a personal banking application. No need for many of us to worry quite yet, as this one was aimed at customers of the Union Bank of Switzerland (UBS) but it is only a matter of time before some enterprising criminal starts thinking creatively about the increasing popularity of internet banking. Who is liable, one asks, if a package of clandestine software, a 'Trojan', starts recording keystrokes and trawls your computer hard disk for account information? The banks are spending huge sums on protecting their own infrastructures, but the weakest point in the web still remains the customer. So can consumers reasonably protect their most confidential data? If such details as a password or perhaps even a PIN number are stolen, can they expect an online bank manager to be sympathetic? Most recently, the Foundation for Information Policy Research web site published a detailed analysis of the contractual and technical weaknesses associated with the many different kinds of emerging e-commerce transaction services. The report revealed that customers of some online banks face the prospect of unlimited personal liability as a consequence of fraud. Invariably, such matters are reduced to questions of negligence and the exercise of reasonable care. In response, the Halifax bank last week sent a wake-up call to the online banking sector, by announcing, through a deal with leading software security company, Trend Micro, that it would offer all its online customers a free anti-virus software package for their home PCs and provide free ongoing anti-virus updates. Other banks are bound to follow, or at least make reassuring noises while they assess the true scale of the risk as it emerges. The foundation's director, Casper Bowden, says: 'It's a worrying scenario whether banks might invoke the small print if they suffered a systemic loss due to a virus. If it's one dissatisfied customer, the bank has a customer service problem. If it's 10,000 defrauded customers, it's a question of legal liability.' Not so, says Jo Wright, a spokeswoman at Barclays Bank. 'Our customers will not be liable if they are victims of fraud, online or otherwise. We will investigate any claim but - should such a thing happen and a large number of customers are affected - we may have to look at each individual case'. The bank has posted this promise to its website and offers detailed information on how users can protect their account information. It stresses: 'Customers should always be careful when opening emails from unknown sources. This is the most likely way that this sort of fraud could be attempted.' This may sound like good news but banks aren't famous for their speed in resolving customers' problems. If larger numbers are involved, the process could be slow, and Barclays seemed a little vague about the small print and didn't call us back. Eric Chien at the Symantec Anti-Virus Research Centre, says: 'Before online banking the opportunity for fraud on this scale just wasn't there. The weakest point is still the home user's personal computer. The Halifax news is a good step forward but the responsibility lies with the banks to invest in customer confidence. People just don't trust online banking.' The UBS 'Trojan' virus may have been the first example of something new, but it was trivial technically. It simply illustrated how a virus writer's motive could shift from trying to win recognition towards personal gain. It seems that virus writers see little reward in writing code that targets popular home financial software. Invariably, these packages encrypt the data they hold, and the general architecture of Windows-based PCs makes it easier to steal information directfrom the keyboard than to unscramble professionally written software. In fact, a really clever virus could conceivably collect and pass on information from many thousands of PCs and, perhaps one day, even mobile phones, to another country. This in turn might be able to execute thousands of small e-commerce transactions before any action could be taken. Chien says: 'The only silver bullet is user education and solid content security. We can only anticipate and protect.' Ian Melamed, chief technical officer of the internet security firm SatelliteSafe Europe, says: 'The e-commerce equation is best described by the formula trust = speed + security, and with the proliferation of malicious code, the security aspect of e-commerce is taking precedent over speed of delivery.' But online security, the integrity of the relationship between a customer and internet-based transaction systems is no longer a private sector issue. Public Sector agencies - including both the Inland Revenue, for self-assessment, and Customs & Excise, for Vat - have to meet Government targets for the wired economy. Given the sad catalogue of mishaps to date, it is, says one reformed hacker, 'only a matter of time before some clever soul opens his software toolbox and starts to explore what opportunities might lie behind the holes in this particular piece of Swiss cheese'.  Simon Moores is chairman of the Research Group (www.drmoores.com).

fields.headline: Deisler strikes
fields.trailText: World Cup round-up.
fields.body:
Germany and Finland opened their Group Nine qualifying campaigns with wins yesterday.

Germany got off to a bright start with Sebastian Deisler, the 20-year-old Hertha Berlin midfielder, opening the scoring in the 17th minute against Greece. The game finished 2-0 to Germany after Greek Libero Marinos Ouzounidis deflected Mehmet Scholl's shot into his own net with 15 minutes remaining.

Greece's brightest moment came in the 22nd minute, when playmaker Vasilis Tsartas hit the post with a fierce shot from 25 yards.

Finland beat Albania 2-1 despite being reduced to 10 men for the last 20 minutes. Barcelona's out-of-favour forward Jari Litmanen scored the first, Edvin Murati replied for Albania in the 63rd minute, and second-half substitute Aki Riihilahti secured Finland's win with four minutes remaing.

Liverpool skipper Sami Hyypia said: 'Today was a good performance except for the start of the second half, when we let Albania have too much space.'

webTitle: The EU should treat sport as a special case

fields.headline: The EU should treat sport as a special case
fields.trailText: Last week's historic meeting in Zurich about how football should respond to the European Union's determination to ban transfer fees underlines more than ever exactly why sport, and professional football in particular, needs to be given a special protocol.
fields.body:
Last week's historic meeting in Zurich about how football should respond to the European Union's determination to ban transfer fees underlines more than ever exactly why sport, and professional football in particular, needs to be given a special protocol.

Perhaps encouraged by the Bosman ruling, the EU is interfering in sport as never before. But the best service the EU could perform for sport would be granting the sort of special consideration - a protocol - which it needs if it is to survive the huge changes the EU is proposing.

The arts and broadcasting are already recognised as special cases, in that they are not mere 'businesses', so why not sport too? The issue of transfer fees and players' contracts illustrates perfectly why sport is different and should not be treated as just another business.

At first sight it may appear right and proper that footballers should have the same rights as other workers. But it is not that simple. Business has copyright and patent laws to encourage and reward research and development; the transfer system is football's way of investing in development of talent. If football is to be compared to a business, it needs similar protection, and not de-regulation.

The EU wants to end big-money transfers such as those we saw this summer involving Hernan Crespo and Luis Figo. But even if transfer fees are abolished, Figo's market value would still be £37 million because that is how much a club is prepared to pay for his labour. So the European Commission's plans would mean that a player's market value would end up being reflected in his wages instead of the transfer fee. Thus Figo and anyone else at world-class level could soon be earning £250,000-a-week - that's £35,000 a day - which is the equivalent of £37 million over three years of a contract. Top players' wages will explode.

Any large increase in wages would further undermine the financial viability of a sport in which Deloitte & Touche report that players' salaries already account for 95 per cent of the turnover of Third Division clubs and 58 per cent of the Premier League's turnover.

Without wishing to sound alarmist, this could destroy many of the smaller clubs in England, Scotland and across Europe. These clubs rely on selling players on to bigger clubs for a fee to help keep afloat. A club like Crewe Alexandra would have their incentive to develop players such as David Platt, Neil Lennon and Ashley Ward removed at a stroke. The way these clubs have managed to stay alive, their lifeline, would disappear. Unless, of course, the EU accepts that proper compensation should be paid.

Among the proposals agreed in Zurich by Fifa, Uefa, the Premier League and Fifpro, the international confederation of players unions, was that there must be a compensation system so that when a player under 24 moves clubs, the selling club are rewarded for the part they have played in his development. The amount would be based on the club's training programme, the value of the player's contract and his first-team and international experience. Without such a system, the EU's latest foray into sport could destroy countless clubs and jobs - footballers' jobs. People may wonder why the chief executive of the players union is arguing against a move that will make many of my members significantly richer. The answer is that, without the EU agreeing to proper compensation and the creation of an annual 'transfer window' during which players can move - then and only then - the price would be too high. There's no point creating greater freedom for professional footballers if as a result of that freedom there are fewer clubs left to employ them.

While I understand the EU's motives in pursuing this, they have barely consulted the players, the 'workers' whose rights they are so keen to extend. If they had I would have told them that none of our 3,000 members is unhappy with the current system. The present standard contract gives players security and protection to a much greater degree than they would have under the EU's proposals.

If this change is not thought about, planned and implemented in a sensible way, football clubs will become like Euston station, with different players arriving, staying for a short while and leaving again almost non-stop. Nobody wants that - and the EU should do everything possible to ensure that this chaos is avoided. Fans certainly do not want that.

Concern has already been expressed by a wide range of respected voices in football, including the Uefa president, Lennart Johansson, that the increasing influx of foreign players into British football is making it harder for fans to identify with certain teams because so few British players play for them, sometimes none at all.

The special protocol would recognise that sport was indeed different from any other business, and therefore grant it a limited exemption from European principles of free trade and free movement of labour.

The key point is this: sport is not simply another business. Most businesses try to reduce competition through mergers and market forces; sport without competition, without 'uncertainty of result', would descend into monopoly and monotony.

The recycling of money through football via transfer fees helps guarantee that clubs can potentially 'do a Wimbledon'. We end that trickle-down of funds at our peril. A protocol would enshrine in law sport's right to sometimes do things differently. In the view of Fifa, Uefa and the PFA, it would also let us control the influx of foreign players into our game.

The movement of European players within the EU is unchecked because 'free movement of labour' is a sacrosanct principle. But surely there is a level beyond which 'free movement' is no longer beneficial. We could soon have a situation in football like the one in British ice hockey where there are only half-a-dozen English-born players left in the Super League; the national team suffers, obviously. While the EU encourages 'free movement of labour', it should also recognise that national and local identity are important too, especially in sport, and that a balance has to be struck between the two.

Sport is different. Thirteen of the 15 EU member states support some sort of protocol for sport. The only two governments that do not are the Danes and our own. Although the Culture Secretary, Chris Smith, backs us, I understand that the Trade and Industry Secretary, Stephen Byers, is against a protocol, believing that it would 'open the floodgates' and that other industries would start demanding special treatment.

Anyone who cares about the future of sport should back the campaign for a protocol. Football fans can help by writing to their MP, MEP or even Tony Blair, asking them to urge the EU to give sport the special consideration it needs and deserves.

Gordon Taylor is chief executive of the Professional Footballers' Association

fields.headline: Many managers will be celebrating
fields.trailText: If the transfer system is abolished in the next few weeks, as it surely will be, I imagine many managers up and down the country will be celebrating.
fields.body:
If the transfer system is abolished in the next few weeks, as it surely will be, I imagine many managers up and down the country will be celebrating.

You may have seen Arsène Wenger and Sir Alex Ferguson protesting now that the EU has forced Fifa and Uefa to consider such a drastic proposal, but for many of us, both in and out of the game, the end of the current transfer system will be a good thing.

What we have at the moment is archaic and ridiculous. Transfer fees are not rooted in reality, and often bear little relation to a player's true value. If you are buying a house, for example, it will be priced according to the value of the house next door. But with players it seems that fees are plucked out of the air. The system is ad-hoc and in need of a complete restructuring.

It is typical of football that it has come to this. The situation has been on the horizon for four or five years, since the Bosman case changed the landscape as far as transfers are concerned. TS Eliot once said that mankind could not bear too much reality, and this is so true of football people, who have a terrible habit of burying their heads in the sand.

One argument that has been going on far too long is that football should be exempt from certain laws because it is not like any other industry. Nonsense. As the EU points out, why should players be unable to move from one place of work to another because their employers have archaic and draconian controls over them?

The first thing that will change once the ruling comes in, which I imagine will be next summer, is the nature of contracts. The standard contract will no longer apply and will be replaced by more individualistic, personalised deals which will be shorter.

While this means players will have more freedom to move on every year or so, it also gives the manager the power to 'unload' surplus players. I would estimate most managers have at least half a dozen players on the books that they would like to get rid of, but are unable to sell. Instead, those players tend to serve out their contracts in the reserves, serving no useful purpose to the club yet still draining the financial resources.

One manager who has just taken over at a second division club, told me last week how he was desperate to reduce his squad of 40, ridiculously large for his club. The proposed changes would mean he could get rid of ten or 15 at a stroke, thus reducing the wage bill by a huge amount and re-allocating that money among the players he wants to keep.

In the First Division, you could lop £500,000 per year off your wage bill in this way, and in the Premiership I would estimate it to be nearer £2million. That is money you could reinvest in your squad. I predict the wages of the average Premiership player rising by between 25 and 50 per cent, and slightly lower rises in the First Division.

By contrast, I think wages will go down in the second and third divisions, where they are already too high in relation to the money generated by most clubs. I am still amazed, as are coaches from all over Europe, that there are players in the third tier of English football being paid six-figure salaries.

Those are the exceptions, of course, but even the average salaries of £30,000 to £50,000 are ridiculous for clubs who rarely attract gates of more than 5,000. No other sport, nor even the British the atre, is so heavily subsidised as many of these clubs, who are kept afloat on money from sponsorship and TV deals.

No-one wants to see the smaller clubs go to the wall, and I think the new system will mean a lot of them having to cut their cloth accordingly. I don't think it will have a disastrous effect in the First Division because there are very few major transfers between the Nationwide League and the Premiership any more. There are fewer and fewer clubs like Crewe Alexandra, who rely on selling two or three players a year to finance their youth academy.

That is the one example where football has a genuine reason to ask to be treated as a special case, because it costs between £5,000 and £8,000 a year to develop a youth player, who might be whisked off to a bigger club. Obviously clubs would like to be compensated for the investment they have made, as happens here now and was shown when Aston Villa had to pay Brighton a compensation fee for young Gareth Barry.

But it doesn't happen across foreign boundaries, and Arsène Wenger is one manager who has exploited that loophole in picking up promising young players from abroad for next to nothing. While managers of the leading clubs complain that they might lose their top players, they should remember that they are also in a position to pick up replacements from their rivals or lower division clubs such as Palace - for nothing.

The situation has changed enormously over the past five years, when we at Palace received around £25m from the sale of our best players after being relegated. Even that sort of money did not compensate for the subsequent loss of revenue through no longer being in - or able to get back into - the Premiership.

So I think the abolition of the transfer system will be good for football. Managers will have to look after their players better, clubs will need to be run better, and everyone will be more accountable, which should lead to more value for money for the most important people - the fans.

fields.headline: Timid Beeb duck Fergie issue
fields.trailText: It's a pity that the BBC haven't stood up to Sir Alex Ferguson over Manchester United's refusal to talk to Match of the Day after their 2-2 draw at West Ham last weekend.
fields.body:
It's a pity that the BBC haven't stood up to Sir Alex Ferguson over Manchester United's refusal to talk to Match of the Day after their 2-2 draw at West Ham last weekend.

Like thousands of other viewers, I was interested to hear what Ferguson, or one of his players, had to say about a fascinating match, but was informed by Gary Lineker that Manchester United had declined to speak to the programme (apparently because of some pretty inconsequential piece in the MOTD magazine).

This was, in fact, a breach of the contract between Premiership clubs and Match of the Day, which requires two players, the manager and coach from both sides to attend a press conference after a game featured on the programme.

The Premiership say that United's press office assure them that 'there is no official ban on speaking to the BBC'. OK, so it is an unofficial one - does that make it all right?

But the Premiership also make the valid point that they have received no official complaint from the BBC, which, frankly, is the sort of faint-hearted reaction that makes you wonder if it isn't such a bad thing after all that they are about to lose the Match of the Day highlights.

The BBC tell me they are taking the line, 'Least said, soonest mended', which will, of course, only encourage Ferguson to repeat his arbitary action whenever he feels like it.

jon.henderson@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Ferdinand bid turned down
fields.trailText: News round-up.
fields.body:
West Ham United have turned down another bid to sell Rio Ferdinand to Leeds United for £15million - despite knowing that transfers could be scrapped within a year. Hammers boss Harry Redknapp admits that the central defender could walk out of Upton Park at the end of the season, but still decided to keep him at the club. In his column in the Racing Post, Redknapp said: 'Leeds have come back in with another £15million bid for Rio Ferdinand and the news that transfers could soon be scrapped made it a massive temptation to sell. 'I had a long talk with the chairman and we decided to resist again, even though in a year Rio could just walk out. 'That's what could well happen if the European Commission gets its way and bans transfers.' Redknapp believes scrapping the transfer system would be 'a disastrous move' with players' salaries spiralling out of control. He added: 'We'd have to put a revolving door in at Upton Park because we wouldn't be able to pay the wages.'

Paul Merson claims he will have to go into management when he stops playing football to avoid ending up like former Manchester United star George Best. The Aston Villa midfielder has battled against alcoholism, drug addiction and gambling for several years and spent some time in rehabilitation while he was at Arsenal.

Now Merson has revealed that watching a recent documentary about the sad decline of Best, who was recently admitted to a London hospital suffering from a liver condition brought on by years of alcohol abuse, has made him think hard about his own future.

'It hit home when he said he turned to drink after he finished playing football because he felt lost without the game he had known all his life,' Merson told FourFourTwo magazine.

'That frightened me. I was sitting on my own indoors and thought, "I don't want the same thing to happen to me."

'What happens when you finish with football? What a horrible feeling that must be. I want to stay in football, because I can't be without the game.

'I would like to go into management and being a player-manager is something that appeals to me, especially as you are out there with your team. I know I have to start planning for life without football so it doesn't just hit me.'

World Cup qualifying games continue today, with 15 ties taking place around the world. In Europe there are seven games, the most attractive of which is Italy's visit to Hungary. Giovanni Trapattoni takes over from Dino Zoff at the helm of the azzurri and the game in Budapest will not be an easy start for the beaten Euro 2000 finallists.

Italy's Serie A does not start for another month, because of the country's participation in the Olympic football tournament in Australia, so his squad could suffer from some rustiness, which means this group-eight encounter could throw up a surprise result.

The other match in the group sees Romania host Lithuania. England's conquerors at both France 98 and this summer's European championship must get used to life without the talismanic Gheorghe Hagi.

Portugal will have a first chance to put their heartbreaking semi-final defeat at the hands of eventual champions France in Euro 2000 behind them when they head to Tallinn where they will tackle Estonia, who beat Andorra 1-0 in the first European World Cup qualifier on 16 August.

On the other side of the Atlantic, qualifying is in full swing. In Concacaf group C, the picture could become much clearer by late tonight. Canada need an away win in Trinidad & Tobago in order to cling on to any hope of progressing. Panama would appear to need a miracle in Mexico City. In group D, Jamaica play hosts to tiny St Vincent while in group E the US face a crucial game with Guatemala while Costa Rica could make qualification easier if they beat Barbados.

Brazil's defeat to Chile still reverberates in South America. The four-time world champions definitely need a convincing win over Bolivia to get back on track. Uruguay face a crucial home match against Ecuador who have only one point fewer.

Argentina travel to Lima with the intention of extending their lead in the qualifying competition in South America where they should have little trouble in disposing of Peru. The top four go through automatically.
