So I rang Dylan Jones, editor of GQ , to ask if it had ever even crossed his mind to do a fashion shoot featuring hacks. 'We did it six months ago with New York journalists. And we featured Tony Parsons as a fashion model a couple of months ago,' he said. In short, the horse had well and truly bolted. So, Dylan, are journalists sexy? 'I know a lot of sexy female journalists. I know no sexy male journalists.' Different worlds, magazines and newspapers. Over at Esquire , Peter Howarth takes a different line. Hack shoot? 'Absolutely not. If you knew the scuzzy bunch I know... Part of the art of journalism is that we produce these products and everyone thinks we're going for drinks with Brad Pitt. But we're not. We're unshaven people who don't see enough daylight.' Too true. Journalists abhor pub gardens. Are they sexy? 'I don't think so, I really don't think so. Every journalist I know likes to think he's sexy. He read Scoop or Fear and Loathing and thought journalism will be a bit of a laugh and... well, you know.' Indeed. The BBC is said to be on the verge of buying Deadline and screening it here in prime time next year, but there's no guarantee it'll be the next Lou Grant. And Almost Famous and Serendipity may not cause that many shakes either. The great movies about journalism - The Sweet Smell of Success, The Front Page, Ace in the Hole - were all set in the days when newspapermen wore hats. Or at least corduroy jackets (Robert Redford in All The President's Men). A more recent example is provided by Perfect . This intriguing Eighties movie starred John Travolta as a Rolling Stone journalist stalking a health and fitness expert played by Jamie Lee Curtis. After its release Curtis's career took off and there was a health club boom. In contrast, after playing the part of a hack, Travolta didn't get a decent part for a decade and Rolling Stone went into terminal decline. The film flopped in part due to a critical panning. And those who seek to make journalists sexy should be aware that their biggest obstacle will be the journalists themselves. Barely a day goes by without a hack lamenting the passing of the days when Fleet Street was Fleet Street and a talented writer could file a thousand-word think-piece through to copy without, in the slightest, disrupting a four-bottle lunch. These pieces proliferate in part because the hacks are struggling to conjure up copy but in the main because it is in all their interests to maintain the illusion that journalism is no fun any more and thereby help maintain the closed shop. It's a scrubby, under-paid, unfashionable profession, as any journalist will tell you. Before waddling up to the bar, ordering a round, waddling back and having a very good laugh.

fields.headline: Little horrors
fields.standfirst: Ruth Rendell's latest collections of short stories, Piranha to Scurfy, shows her strengths and the form's weakness
fields.trailText: Ruth Rendell's latest collections of short stories, Piranha to Scurfy, shows her strengths and the form's weakness
fields.body:
Piranha to Scurfy and Other Stories
Ruth Rendell
Hutchinson £15.99, pp248

Ruth Rendell's seventh collection of short stories demonstrates both her strengths as a writer and the limitations of the form. The best pieces here are the longest, two novellas that deal with obsession - a common theme of her work - and show her unequalled ability to build and sustain suspense.

In High Mysterious Union, the main character is obsessed with a young woman who loves him but not exclusively. Recovering from a breakdown after his wife left him, Ben goes to stay in a quiet village that he soon discovers is a kind of erotic dream world. Initially he is welcomed, but his total misunderstanding of how the village works soon turns everyone against him.

Rendell's sense of place is acute and her ability to make simple incidents - a group of villagers staring, the sight of all the houses in the village brightly illuminated - threatening and fearful is quite remarkable. Ben is a translator, working on a Jungian analysis of the stories attendant on the Trojan War (especially those surrounding Helen of Troy and Paris, Priam and Hecabe) so there are echoes of classical mythology here. The evocation of a mysterious, enclosed world is also vaguely reminiscent of John Fowles's The Ebony Tower or its precursor, Alain-Fournier's Le Grand Meaulnes.

The best of the collection is the title story, more horror than crime story, redolent of M. R. James. Ambrose Ribbon is another obsessive. He lives alone in a house he used to share with his dead mother. He keeps her room exactly as she left it, her pink nightdress folded on the bed. The title of the story refers to Volume VIII of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, a book he associates with her.

It is a book he uses in his self-appointed task. His obsession is to spend his every waking hour reading novels, though not for pleasure. He checks them for errors of fact and grammar, errors he communicates to the authors in rude letters. However, one book, Demogorgon, a horror novel by best-selling author Kingston Marle, has an extreme effect on him. The demon in the story enters his life. Once again Rendell builds up the suspense by a subtle accretion of detail. As Ribbon's torments increase, Rendell's rendering of his fragmenting personality brilliantly done.

The shorter pieces are, perhaps inevitably, less weighty and suffer from a weakness of the form. Where the short story generally has a flexibility which allows it to present itself pretty much on its own terms - often allusive, atonal or fragmentary - the crime story needs to fulfil genre expectations, especially when it comes to the dénouement. Hence the ubiquitous twist ending, so hard to do well in the limited confines of the short story without the reader seeing it coming.

The nine short pieces - between six and 12 pages in length - are entertaining enough but only one, The Wink, has any deeper resonance. Its account of a woman coming to terms many decades after the event with a youthful violation is powerful stuff.

webTitle: Observer review: Aiding and Abetting by Muriel Spark

fields.headline: He's not Lord Lucan. I am...
fields.standfirst: Muriel Spark takes two Lord Lucans and an idiosyncratic therapist to make Aiding and Abetting
fields.trailText: Muriel Spark takes two Lord Lucans and an idiosyncratic therapist to make Aiding and Abetting
fields.body:
Aiding and Abetting
Muriel Spark
Viking £12.99, pp182
Buy it at BOL

This novel is a brisk fantasia on the Lord Lucan affair. Dr Hildegard Wolf, an idiosyncratic therapist working in Paris, is approached by two plausible men claiming to be the murderous toff - a fugitive from justice now officially dead in his homeland. Muriel Spark's imagination has been set off by real events before, but The Abbess of Crewe offered a drastically transformed account of Watergate.

This new novel relies for the facts on newspaper dossiers and investigative journalism, and for its fictional tension on the cat-and-mouse game between two men, at least one of whom must be lying, and a therapist with her own little secret. The eccentricity of Wolf's method lies in her habit of talking exclusively about herself, sometimes for many hours, before even asking what the patient's trouble is.

This sounds like a perversion of the analytic technique, but there is a logic at work: if her patients have lost a skill which might help them, it is surely that of listening.

Each of the two 'Lord Lucans' bears a certain resemblance to the original, as he would look after decades on the run. The logical answer to the absurdity of two such men appearing would be that they are in cahoots, but what could they hope to gain? Just because someone seeks to manipulate a therapist does not mean he isn't genuinely in need of treatment.

Even if one of them is 'real', what does that mean? The whole rationale behind the murder (whose real intended target was the earl's estranged wife) was insolvency: Lucan was trying to live the life of an aristocrat on an income that couldn't stretch beyond the bourgeois pleasures. In that sense he was a fake, and the person impersonating him a fake twice over.

Wolf's secret is that as a young woman, under another name, she healed not by therapeutic intervention but by miracle - she too was a fake, a 'stigmatic', bleeding from wounds that mimicked Christ's, and yet the effect she had on believers could be real. As long as our access to the Lucan story comes only through Wolf's perceptions, Aiding and Abetting exerts a faint but definite spell. But then Spark lets her structure unravel two-thirds of the way through: her heroine becomes little more than an onlooker, and the Lucan material begins to seem relatively thin, finished off with a black-comedy African nemesis out of Evelyn Waugh.

Perhaps more than a newspaper archive is needed to pass judgment on a whole social milieu. What is presented as shocking beyond the guilt of a privileged individual is his set's lack of remorse over the death of the nanny, Sandra Rivett: 'When a relative called at the Lucan home by arrangement to collect her belongings, they were handed over at the door by Lady Lucan herself, stuffed into a bag, and that was that.'

No etiquette book in the world offers advice on this predicament, how best to return the property of a nanny murdered by your husband in your place, on a night when you were merely bludgeoned and choked. And if the tragedy of the nanny's death is to be restored to its proper place in the scheme of things, then the occasional heartlessness of Spark's tone seems poorly judged, as in this dismissal of Lucan's planning: 'Even if the nanny had taken her night off, even if he had murdered the countess, the plot leaked at every seam as truly as did the blood-oozing mailbag into which the body of Sandra Rivett was packed.'

webTitle: Paperback of the week: In Search of the Third Man

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Charles Drazin's definitive study sets out to distinguish fact from fiction in the making of the film.
fields.body:
In Search of the Third Man
Charles Drazin
Methuen £9.99, pp210
Buy it at BOL

First released in 1949, The Third Man, a collaboration between Graham Greene, Carol Reed, Alexander Korda and David Selznick, was voted Best British Film Ever in a recent millennium poll. Inevitably, British cinema's unquestioned masterpiece has accumulated some hoary myths, and Charles Drazin's definitive study sets out to distinguish fact from fiction in the making of the film.

Many of these myths have to do with Orson Welles, who played Harry Lime, a role originally intended for Robert Mitchum, David Niven and even, amazingly, Noël Coward. Drazin also reveals, for instance, that much of the famous sewer sequence was shot at Shepperton Studios. Welles refused to go into the Vienna sewers. He thought they were too dirty.

Another Welles myth is debunked: the claim that he wrote the famous 'cuckoo clock' speech. These words were, apparently, borrowed from a lecture delivered by James McNeill Whistler - in 1885. Welles himself insisted throughout much of his life that he had written his own lines, and he later recorded a 52-episode radio series in which he recounted tales from Lime's earlier life. Lime himself was based partly on Greene's friend Kim Philby, formerly Beirut correspondent of The Observer.

Drazin explores this material with a sure touch and a good eye for telling detail, bringing to life not only the bombed-out atmosphere of Vienna during the occupation by the Great Powers, but also the mood of the postwar British filmmaking community, notably the bitter battles between Greene and Selznick over the cinematic interpretation of his screenplay.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: This extraordinary novel recreates the harsh background to the 40 days - the 'quarantine' - that Jesus spent in the desert.
fields.body:
Quarantine
Jim Crace
Read by Peter Wickham
Unabridged, 7hrs
Isis £24.49
Mail order 0800 731 5637

This extraordinary novel recreates the harsh background to the 40 days - the 'quarantine' - that Jesus spent in the desert, and audio gives it a further dimension of startling realism. The focus intrigues because the chief protagonist is a deeply unpleasant merchant, Musa, left for dead by his long-suffering wife.

Searching for water on his travels to the desert, Jesus enters Musa's apparently empty tent, and on hearing a faint groan, presses the fever out of him as simply as pressing 'the stone out from an olive'. Musa celebrates his miraculous recovery by beating his old donkey to death with horrific savagery. Then, while starvation in the desert turns the skin of Jesus and the other ascetics to a translucent amber, Musa exploits them shamelessly by selling them water, and unsuccessfully tempts the young Gallilean miracle-healer with packets of food.

The unabridged reading immerses the listener in the detail and imagery which realises this distant world. Musa, the merchant of fabrics, is drawn to women by the fall of their robes; during his own quarantine on his desert caravan, the merchandise includes screeching monkeys strapped to camels, and birds baited with a tick on a thread, pulled in like fish when they swallow the lure.

The creaky, petulant voice that narrator Peter Wickham gives to Musa conveys the merchant's obnoxious, wheedling nature and his cruel treatment of all living things, and also symbolises the harshness of the world in which Jesus lived and died. Remarkable listening.

webTitle: Yasmina Reza talks about the influence of her late father

fields.headline: Papa knew best
fields.standfirst: She made her name with Art, a play about three men arguing over a painting. Now, with a new novel out, and a production of her debut drama in London, Yasmina Reza talks about the influence of her late father
fields.trailText: She made her name with Art, a play about three men arguing over a painting. Now, with a new novel out, and a production of her debut drama in London, Yasmina Reza talks about the influence of her late father
fields.body:
Yasmina Reza was five when she discovered she was not going to live for ever. 'I thought it was a piece of luck to be alive, a kind of distinction - like a medal. I thought: if life is only a short piece of time, I must live with intensity.' Was she frightened of death? 'No. Not at all.' (She is emphatic: 'No. Not at all' is an absolute and her catchphrase). At eight, she wrote a poem about mortality. It was called 'La Mort et La Vie' and it won a 'little prize'. Could she still remember how it went? 'Of course,' she said in that indignant way - between reassurance and reproof - that French women have.

We were sitting in Brasserie Lipp on the Boulevard St Germain, in Paris. On the wall alongside us was a tiled, tropical landscape of pastel cockatoos and parrots. Faded signs warned 'amateurs du pipe' to keep their tobacco to themselves. Reza reeled off her poem at speed; I followed after, dragging my schoolgirl French behind me. Life, according to the authoritative eight-year-old, was full of le bonheur and le malheur - the rest I asked her to write down. 'En subissant l'heure et la peur,/ plus tard la vie s'efface/ et l'ame part,/ en haut dans l'espace.' (Roughly: Undergoing time and fear/ life later will disappear/ and the soul part/ high up in space.)

Now, at 40, not much has changed. Reza has returned to matters of life and death. Not that there is anything moribund about her career. She is about to enjoy a sparkling English season. Her play Conversations After a Burial, starring Claire Bloom, opens at the Almeida theatre and her autobiographical novel Hammerklavier, in part a memoir of her father, is published at the same time (Faber £6.99). She is best known for Art, the intellectually chic comedy about three men who fall out over a white painting, although their quarrel is actually about friendship. Art 's success has been phenomenal; it has been translated into 35 languages and the trio can still be heard arguing in the West End every night.

Reza has described time as 'the only subject'. She was absolutely punctual herself, thrifty about her own time. We almost collided in the entrance to the restaurant. I recognised her from photographs: dark, petite, with a slightly cross face, a sensual, contemptuous mouth, a bustling air. She removed her dark glasses to reveal lively brown eyes under elaborately curved brows. She is not strictly beautiful but has a simian intensity. She was severely dressed - apart from a skirt with a flirtatiously feathered hem - a business-like princess, with no necklace.

Her appearance matters to her greatly. In one of the most memorable chapters of Hammerklavier, Reza describes the purchase of a midnight-blue satin suit with thin grey stripes. She bought it to attend an awards ceremony at the Savoy in London (where she was to pick up a prize for Art ). She was pleased with the suit: 'Restrained... understated elegance, slightly masculine, which is good for an author at lunchtime.' Then she blew it. She bought a necklace: two strings of costume pearls, one of which she converted into a bracelet. She knew the pearls were a mistake but asked her friend Serge (an extraordinary number of male characters in Reza's oeuvre end up being called Serge) to give his honest opinion of her jewellery. He judged the necklace 'dreadful' and the bracelet 'even worse'. She ended their conversation: 'You're right, but from now on we are no longer friends.'

In real life, the conversation ended in laughter. She is still friends with Serge. She never wears the necklace. So why was she tempted to invent such an extreme ending? Friendship is a delicate business, it seems. The necklace incident recalls Art where a friendship is also jeopardised by an aesthetic difference of opinion. Should the white canvas and the costume pearls be insincerely praised? Is deception necessary to friendship? 'No. Not at all. It is not a question of lying. It is a question of manner.' It is style that counts.

This may be true for Reza in more ways than one. Later, she concedes that lying may sometimes be necessary even though friendships must be founded in trust. She has a sort of tricky integrity, admirable in its way. She does not care if her friends hold unsympathetic opinions about art or politics, it is 'the moral differences' that count. She adds a sober PS: 'Real friendship is very rare.'

Reza's father was her real friend. He was her axis: all her work turns on him in some way. As a child, she hardly knew him. Her parents were worldly. 'I first "met" my father when I was a teenager. I got to know him well in my twenties.' He was an engineer of bridges, then a businessman. He was also an amateur musician who played the piano badly but with passion (Reza plays too). He was a Persian Jew, born in Moscow. Reza's mother is Jewish, too, from Budapest. She is a violinist (Reza allows her mother one adjective: 'strong.') Reza believes her writing is more Jewish than French. But she worships French, adores its 'subtlety'. She has no time for English, dismissing it as if it were a flat cake that could never rise.

Conversations After a Burial is about the relationship between sex and death. It is, like most of her plays, beautifully translated by Christopher Hampton. A man and a woman make love on the dead man's grave - an act that does not prove as private as they might have wished. As the rest of the mourners gather round a mighty pot au feu, there is more than leeks and carrots coming to the boil.

You could be forgiven for assuming that Conversations After a Burial must have been written just after her father's death. But it is her first play, written 15 years ago, and her father knew it well. It was in the Brasserie Lipp that she handed him a published copy of the play. Later, walking home with him they ran, by chance, into Raymond Barre, a former French Prime Minister. Her father waylaid Barre - to her chagrin - and boasted about his daughter's talent. Not that he had been convinced of it himself, at first. It was only when audiences hailed her that he changed his tune. He never saw Art. It was written in six weeks to distract her from his death. She believed the play was dreadful - 'not worthy of me' or of him.

She wrote Hammerklavier for herself. Writing was a way of keeping her father alive on paper. She was talked into publishing it. Did she have misgivings now? 'No. Not at all.' The novel is full of private glimpses: her dying father standing naked in the bathroom telling her that when he sees himself he thinks of Auschwitz. She says: 'It's true, Papa, you aren't looking great at the moment' - and they laugh. The book is full of unexpected laughter as well as despair.

What did she miss most about her father? She stared back at me, flinching slightly. She was a little affronted, moved too by the question. 'Everything,' she said eventually. She added that when he was ill and she knew it was the end, 'I tried to fix him in my mind'. Her eyes filled with tears. She said that writing the book had 'fixed him for people who have never met him'. And that seemed to please her greatly.

I stared back at her, at her plain, high-necked top - a colour somewhere between lemon and mustard but hard to place, like her character (mustard and lemon there, too, but with enough sugar to offset the sharpness - like a good salad dressing). Was she a good cook? 'No. Not at all.' She relented: 'I know very well how to do a pot au feu... maybe I am a cook compared to an English woman.' She gave a charming laugh and then there was an embarrassment between us that spread like spilt water - as if she could not decide whether or not she had committed a faux pas. She did not withdraw her remark. She is decided about everything, even kindly taking control of the menu and ordering my lunch: a beetroot and walnut salad, a plate of wild strawberries.

She is as maternal as a swan. And it is not only her children she defends. 'I protect myself a lot. I say no. I say no to invitations, I don't appear anywhere. I don't sign books. I don't go on TV. I do very few interviews. I am very savage. That is why I can have a private life.' She has two children: a girl, 12, and a boy, seven, by her partner, the film-maker Didier Martigny. The boy minds most about her absences. He advises her on her wardrobe, alerting her when one colour does not get on with another. It was 'wonderful', she said, to have a son. He seemed a miracle because he was born only one month after her father died. She was moved by the way birth and death held hands.

Reza's career is burgeoning all over the world. She has a new play Trois Versions de la Vie about to open in Vienna, Philippe Noiret is touring her second play The Unexpected Man in France (the RSC production is transferring to New York with Eileen Atkins and Alan Bates). And as if this were not enough, she is returning to acting, after 13 years, in a film called Terminus des Anges, directed by André Téchiné, set in Tangiers. She plays a seductive woman writer. Téchiné fell for Reza when they met in Cannes. 'I inspired him, physically speaking,' she reported, telling me in delighted detail about how she said 'no' when Téchiné asked her to act in his film, before yielding.

Reza seems content to be herself. But if she could choose to leave the brasserie as someone else, just for the afternoon, who would she like to be? 'Philip Roth,' she said. 'Otherwise, Julia Roberts - but only for the afternoon, the night would be too hard work.' She laughed. And if she could be somewhere else? 'Afghanistan,' for its landscapes. And she liked the idea of a yashmak so that no one would see anything but her eyes.

fields.bodyText: Yasmina Reza was five when she discovered she was not going to live for ever. 'I thought it was a piece of luck to be alive, a kind of distinction - like a medal. I thought: if life is only a short piece of time, I must live with intensity.' Was she frightened of death? 'No. Not at all.' (She is emphatic: 'No. Not at all' is an absolute and her catchphrase). At eight, she wrote a poem about mortality. It was called 'La Mort et La Vie' and it won a 'little prize'. Could she still remember how it went? 'Of course,' she said in that indignant way - between reassurance and reproof - that French women have. We were sitting in Brasserie Lipp on the Boulevard St Germain, in Paris. On the wall alongside us was a tiled, tropical landscape of pastel cockatoos and parrots. Faded signs warned 'amateurs du pipe' to keep their tobacco to themselves. Reza reeled off her poem at speed; I followed after, dragging my schoolgirl French behind me. Life, according to the authoritative eight-year-old, was full of le bonheur and le malheur - the rest I asked her to write down. 'En subissant l'heure et la peur,/ plus tard la vie s'efface/ et l'ame part,/ en haut dans l'espace.' (Roughly: Undergoing time and fear/ life later will disappear/ and the soul part/ high up in space.) Now, at 40, not much has changed. Reza has returned to matters of life and death. Not that there is anything moribund about her career. She is about to enjoy a sparkling English season. Her play Conversations After a Burial, starring Claire Bloom, opens at the Almeida theatre and her autobiographical novel Hammerklavier, in part a memoir of her father, is published at the same time (Faber £6.99). She is best known for Art, the intellectually chic comedy about three men who fall out over a white painting, although their quarrel is actually about friendship. Art 's success has been phenomenal; it has been translated into 35 languages and the trio can still be heard arguing in the West End every night. Reza has described time as 'the only subject'. She was absolutely punctual herself, thrifty about her own time. We almost collided in the entrance to the restaurant. I recognised her from photographs: dark, petite, with a slightly cross face, a sensual, contemptuous mouth, a bustling air. She removed her dark glasses to reveal lively brown eyes under elaborately curved brows. She is not strictly beautiful but has a simian intensity. She was severely dressed - apart from a skirt with a flirtatiously feathered hem - a business-like princess, with no necklace. Her appearance matters to her greatly. In one of the most memorable chapters of Hammerklavier, Reza describes the purchase of a midnight-blue satin suit with thin grey stripes. She bought it to attend an awards ceremony at the Savoy in London (where she was to pick up a prize for Art ). She was pleased with the suit: 'Restrained... understated elegance, slightly masculine, which is good for an author at lunchtime.' Then she blew it. She bought a necklace: two strings of costume pearls, one of which she converted into a bracelet. She knew the pearls were a mistake but asked her friend Serge (an extraordinary number of male characters in Reza's oeuvre end up being called Serge) to give his honest opinion of her jewellery. He judged the necklace 'dreadful' and the bracelet 'even worse'. She ended their conversation: 'You're right, but from now on we are no longer friends.' In real life, the conversation ended in laughter. She is still friends with Serge. She never wears the necklace. So why was she tempted to invent such an extreme ending? Friendship is a delicate business, it seems. The necklace incident recalls Art where a friendship is also jeopardised by an aesthetic difference of opinion. Should the white canvas and the costume pearls be insincerely praised? Is deception necessary to friendship? 'No. Not at all. It is not a question of lying. It is a question of manner.' It is style that counts. This may be true for Reza in more ways than one. Later, she concedes that lying may sometimes be necessary even though friendships must be founded in trust. She has a sort of tricky integrity, admirable in its way. She does not care if her friends hold unsympathetic opinions about art or politics, it is 'the moral differences' that count. She adds a sober PS: 'Real friendship is very rare.' Reza's father was her real friend. He was her axis: all her work turns on him in some way. As a child, she hardly knew him. Her parents were worldly. 'I first "met" my father when I was a teenager. I got to know him well in my twenties.' He was an engineer of bridges, then a businessman. He was also an amateur musician who played the piano badly but with passion (Reza plays too). He was a Persian Jew, born in Moscow. Reza's mother is Jewish, too, from Budapest. She is a violinist (Reza allows her mother one adjective: 'strong.') Reza believes her writing is more Jewish than French. But she worships French, adores its 'subtlety'. She has no time for English, dismissing it as if it were a flat cake that could never rise. Conversations After a Burial is about the relationship between sex and death. It is, like most of her plays, beautifully translated by Christopher Hampton. A man and a woman make love on the dead man's grave - an act that does not prove as private as they might have wished. As the rest of the mourners gather round a mighty pot au feu, there is more than leeks and carrots coming to the boil. You could be forgiven for assuming that Conversations After a Burial must have been written just after her father's death. But it is her first play, written 15 years ago, and her father knew it well. It was in the Brasserie Lipp that she handed him a published copy of the play. Later, walking home with him they ran, by chance, into Raymond Barre, a former French Prime Minister. Her father waylaid Barre - to her chagrin - and boasted about his daughter's talent. Not that he had been convinced of it himself, at first. It was only when audiences hailed her that he changed his tune. He never saw Art. It was written in six weeks to distract her from his death. She believed the play was dreadful - 'not worthy of me' or of him. She wrote Hammerklavier for herself. Writing was a way of keeping her father alive on paper. She was talked into publishing it. Did she have misgivings now? 'No. Not at all.' The novel is full of private glimpses: her dying father standing naked in the bathroom telling her that when he sees himself he thinks of Auschwitz. She says: 'It's true, Papa, you aren't looking great at the moment' - and they laugh. The book is full of unexpected laughter as well as despair. What did she miss most about her father? She stared back at me, flinching slightly. She was a little affronted, moved too by the question. 'Everything,' she said eventually. She added that when he was ill and she knew it was the end, 'I tried to fix him in my mind'. Her eyes filled with tears. She said that writing the book had 'fixed him for people who have never met him'. And that seemed to please her greatly. I stared back at her, at her plain, high-necked top - a colour somewhere between lemon and mustard but hard to place, like her character (mustard and lemon there, too, but with enough sugar to offset the sharpness - like a good salad dressing). Was she a good cook? 'No. Not at all.' She relented: 'I know very well how to do a pot au feu... maybe I am a cook compared to an English woman.' She gave a charming laugh and then there was an embarrassment between us that spread like spilt water - as if she could not decide whether or not she had committed a faux pas. She did not withdraw her remark. She is decided about everything, even kindly taking control of the menu and ordering my lunch: a beetroot and walnut salad, a plate of wild strawberries. She is as maternal as a swan. And it is not only her children she defends. 'I protect myself a lot. I say no. I say no to invitations, I don't appear anywhere. I don't sign books. I don't go on TV. I do very few interviews. I am very savage. That is why I can have a private life.' She has two children: a girl, 12, and a boy, seven, by her partner, the film-maker Didier Martigny. The boy minds most about her absences. He advises her on her wardrobe, alerting her when one colour does not get on with another. It was 'wonderful', she said, to have a son. He seemed a miracle because he was born only one month after her father died. She was moved by the way birth and death held hands. Reza's career is burgeoning all over the world. She has a new play Trois Versions de la Vie about to open in Vienna, Philippe Noiret is touring her second play The Unexpected Man in France (the RSC production is transferring to New York with Eileen Atkins and Alan Bates). And as if this were not enough, she is returning to acting, after 13 years, in a film called Terminus des Anges, directed by André Téchiné, set in Tangiers. She plays a seductive woman writer. Téchiné fell for Reza when they met in Cannes. 'I inspired him, physically speaking,' she reported, telling me in delighted detail about how she said 'no' when Téchiné asked her to act in his film, before yielding. Reza seems content to be herself. But if she could choose to leave the brasserie as someone else, just for the afternoon, who would she like to be? 'Philip Roth,' she said. 'Otherwise, Julia Roberts - but only for the afternoon, the night would be too hard work.' She laughed. And if she could be somewhere else? 'Afghanistan,' for its landscapes. webTitle: Classicwatch: My Life and Hard Times

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: This brief and hilarious memoir is justly praised as one of James Thurber's finest books
fields.body:
My Life and Hard Times
James Thurber
Prion Humour Classics £8.99, pp115
Buy it at BOL

James Grover Thurber is probably best remembered for his cartoons in the New Yorker which he produced from the magazine's early days in 1927 until his death in 1961, but he also published nearly 30 books, of which this brief and hilarious memoir is justly praised as one of the finest.

Thurber presents himself as the nonplussed, deadpan narrator of various absurd anecdotes from his Ohio childhood in the early years of the last century. His cast of characters is largely his endearingly eccentric extended family: placid, put-upon father, sensible but easily confused mother and, best of all, Grandfather, who is convinced the Civil War is still being fought tooth and nail around him but is given to alarming moments of sanity when they least expect it.

Thurber recounts incidents in pithy chapters - The Day The Dam Broke, The Night The Ghost Got In - and the humour lies in the collision between the ludicrous chain of misunderstandings that often spiral out of control, and the reactions of the respectable citizens of Columbus, Ohio, who attempt to regain decorum by pretending nothing is out of the ordinary. As funny now as it was in 1933.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: All we really ought to know about Mao Zedong, plus Along the Wall and Watchtowers, Midnight All Day, What the Body Remembers and The Bedroom of the Mister's Wife
fields.body:
Mao
Jonathan Spence
Phoenix £6.99, pp205
Buy it at BOL

Mao tells us all we ought to know (and probably didn't) about Mao Zedong, or Mao Tse-tung. Born in 1893 in Nunan, Mao was 25 when he left for Beijing, where he read widely (Darwin, Rousseau, Lenin). By 1936, now leader of the Peasants Army, he was living in cave dwellings in Shaanxi. After gaining complete power in 1949, Mao became increasingly tyrannical.

Jonathan Spence, a leading American historian, charts with clarity Mao's slow and painstaking rise to power, marshalling his facts with detachment: Mao dumped his second wife to marry a young actress; the Great Leap Forward, a series of agrarian reforms, led to more than 20 million deaths during 1960-1; the Cultural Revolution increased the repression in China. Spence calls Mao 'The Lord of Misrule': this readable study explains why.

Along the Wall and Watchtowers
Oliver August
Flamingo £7.99, pp244
Buy it at BOL

This engaging narrative is Oliver August's story of his recent car journey along the length of the old Iron Curtain ('Stalin's giant garden fence'), from north to south. The writer was brought up in Germany, then educated at Oxford and is now China correspondent for the Times. He reflects, reports and uses delightful anecdotes to illustrate the changing shape of Germany's identity since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989.

A few miss the old border: in Lübeck, an old man laments how once, 'wonderful birds nested in these trees' because the border guards inadvertently created a nature reserve; East German relatives of August's tell how they lost 'their worldview'. A buxom girl reveals that the 'Wessi' (West Germans) are useless in bed, 'all bumm, bumm, bumm'. But all who read this vibrant, intelligent book will come away more optimistic about the changes in Germany.

Midnight All Day
Hanif Kureishi
Faber, £6.99, pp217
Buy it at BOL

The title of Hanif Kureishi's second collection of short stories sums up the mood of the whole: dark, urban angst. The stories focus on love trysts, ex-lovers, drugs and love, sex and love. The love is often claustrophobic and rarely happy. The characters are fringe people, actors, artists and writers living in well-described London settings.

The surreal concluding story, 'Penis', is the only one that almost breaks clear of world-weary despair. This phallic motif indicates the source of many of the problems suffered by male characters in the other stories. Kureishi has masterful precision of scene, dialogue and temporal movement, but the author is too much in control of his characters: there is often a lack of surprise. However, these obsessional, rather weird stories greatly entertain.

What the Body Remembers
Shauna Singh Baldwin
Anchor £6.99, pp540
Buy it at BOL

This first novel by an Indian author now living in America traces the history of two Sikh women, both married to a rich Balliol-educated Punjabi, and the interrelated lives of all three up to the Partition of India in 1947. The promising first chapter, set in 1937 Rawalpindi, lays out the tensions between the older, childless Satya, and Roop - young, pretty and fertile. Then the novel returns to 1928, and psychological tension is weakened.

Dialogue is sometimes wooden: 'It's simply not done these days, old chap,' sums up the stereotyped Englishman, Cunningham. The narrative can be a bit heady: 'When the wind-god, Vayu, bearer of perfume, god of all the northwest of India...' Some passages strain for a Technicolor effect. The well told later chapters, where plot is tightly underpinned by historical events, grow in pace and intensity.

The overall impression, though, is too melodramatic.

The Bedroom of the Mister's Wife
Philip Hensher
Vintage £6.99, pp200
Buy it at BOL

This rich and startling collection of 14 short stories draws the reader into numerous different worlds with a deftness of touch reminiscent of V. S. Pritchett. The stories feature Stalin's daughter living in Cambridge; a committee of MPs in Prague and Rome; a middle-class couple rising up the property ladder; a strange relationship with the internet; the odd life of an adopted daughter.

Each story reveals some twist or turn that satisfyingly unifies. The metaphysical dimension is earthed by compellingly accurate details of the worlds involved. Characters are depicted vividly, descriptions are spare and taut. One of these stories, 'Dead Languages', was included in the recently published Oxford Book of English Short Stories. Each story demands concentration: this is a collection of extraordinary power.

webTitle: Observer review: Dancing with Demons by Penny Valentine and Vicki Wickham

fields.headline: You don't have to say you love me
fields.standfirst: ...but it would help if you did. Penny Valentine and Vicki Wickham show that Dusty Springfield had the voice and the songs but never conquered her self-doubt in Dancing with Demons
fields.trailText: ...but it would help if you did. Penny Valentine and Vicki Wickham show that Dusty Springfield had the voice and the songs but never conquered her self-doubt in Dancing with Demons
fields.body:
The Authorised BIography of Dusty Springfield: Dancing with Demons
Penny Valentine and Vicki Wickham
Hodder & Stoughton £17.99, pp306
Buy it at BOL

The woman the world remembers as kohl-eyed, bouffant-haired, nightingale-voiced Dusty Springfield was actually born Mary Isabel Catherine Bernadette O'Brien in 1939. A nervous, humorous, strong-featured girl, she never liked her looks, and found it difficult to trust people, including her parents, the highly strung Kay, and pedantic O.B. Despite the curious family penchant for wild food fights and crockery smashing, which Dusty was to carry on, the O'Briens were never exactly touchy-feely. Many years on, when Kay was dying from cancer, she reached out to her daughter, seemingly for an embrace, but settled for roughly pinching her nose.

Of all the riveting facts in Penny Valentine and Vicki Wickham's affectionate yet candid biography, this one makes you wince the most. There are pivotal moments in everyone's life that seem to explain all that came before, and all that came after, and expecting a rare embrace but getting your nose yanked seemed quintessentially Dusty.

Certainly, it goes some way towards explaining the lethargy, paranoia, and drink and drug-soaked self-destruction that blighted her later years. It also explains the many masks Dusty felt she needed to hide behind in order to survive. Throughout her life, she seemed to operate on two levels - both as a real person and her own brilliant invention. The platinum blonde who was actually a brunette. The nation's sweetheart who was actually a lesbian. The sex symbol who felt unfeminine. The happy-go-lucky prankster who tormented herself with self-doubt, but privately confided in a lover that she never felt a moment of joy unless she was on stage.

In the beginning, Dusty was the 'Sixties golden girl' - a young woman with rare talent and drive, who was never going to be content to be just another miniskirt on the Ready, Steady, Go podium. First with The Springfields, alongside her brother, Tom (whose real name was Dion), and then as a solo artist, Dusty enjoyed a stream of hits, including 'I Only Want To Be With You', and 'You Don't Have To Say You Love Me' and 'Son of a Preacher Man'. Her 1969 album, Dusty In Memphis, didn't sell as well as her previous releases, but remains a critical benchmark, and deservedly so.

In terms of emotional clarity, Dusty's voice was incomparable - the equivalent of leaving a smog-bound city, climbing to the top of a mountain and breathing in sharp, cold, pure air for the first time. She was a grafter too. Not only did Dusty make it her business to know her chosen music (soul, r&b and Motown), inside out, she worked at her own vocal integrity with a focus and passion that left even such noted perfectionists as the songwriters Burt Bacharach and Carole King flabbergasted.

On a personal level, Dusty was less a blonde bombshell than she was a time bomb waiting to explode. She was not lacking in moral fibre - forever in thrall to black artists such as Marvin Gaye and Aretha Franklin, she made a courageous, unprecedented stand against apartheid on an early tour of South Africa.

However, this lapsed Catholic from Ealing could never quite bring herself to come out publicly as a lesbian, even after she was heralded as a gay icon, even after her friends Elton John and the tennis player Billie Jean King had come out. When Dusty finally mustered the courage to tell her parents about her sexual persuasion, she was devastated by their refusal to take her seriously. It must have seemed like a rejection, another 'tweak of the nose', when what she really needed was an embrace or some other form of parental absolution.

Dusty's chaotic, unproductive 12-year sojourn in America could only have underlined her feelings of worthlessness. Broke, lazy, sullen, uninspired, unreliable, exasperating, and raddled by booze and drugs, frankly, La Springfield sounds like she was a royal pain in the butt during this period. Of course, beneath it all, she was simply succumbing to the neurotic self-doubt and feelings of isolation that had dogged her since early childhood. At her lowest ebb, Dusty even took to taking overdoses, cutting herself, then signing into mental institutions - partly, her friends feel, because she came to the conclusion that they were the next best things to hotels.

Valentine, a leading music journalist and broadcaster in the Sixties, and Wickham, Dusty's longtime manager, detail these events, and all others, with remarkable candour and honesty, yet never stray into exploitative, censorious waters. Both friends of Dusty's, they seem equally at pains to bring across the singer's best qualities - her kindness, generosity, and wicked sense of humour, which remained in evidence even during her harrowing battle against illness.

Terminal cancer struck just as Dusty was enjoying a career resurgence aided by her admirers, the Pet Shop Boys. But, ever the consummate drama queen, she seemed determined to go out in style. Dusty summoned her hairdresser to the Royal Marsden to give her one last bleaching session, declaring: 'Now I can have an open coffin.' When an OBE turned up at the hospital, she asked drily:'Isn't this what they give to cleaners?'

All of which explains why, as much as Dusty frequently perplexed and exasperated those closest to her, including the authors of this book, they, like her loyal public, could never quite bring themselves to give up on her.

Valentine, a leading music journalist and broadcaster in the Sixties, and Wickham, Dusty's longtime manager, detail these events, and all others, with remarkable candour and honesty, yet never stray into exploitative, censorious waters. Both friends of Dusty's, they seem equally at pains to bring across the singer's best qualities - her kindness, generosity, and wicked sense of humour, which remained in evidence even during her harrowing battle against illness. Terminal cancer struck just as Dusty was enjoying a career resurgence aided by her admirers, the Pet Shop Boys. But, ever the consummate drama queen, she seemed determined to go out in style. Dusty summoned her hairdresser to the Royal Marsden to give her one last bleaching session, declaring: 'Now I can have an open coffin.' When an OBE turned up at the hospital, she asked drily:'Isn't this what they give to cleaners?' All of which explains why, as much as Dusty frequently perplexed and exasperated those closest to her, including the authors of this book, they, like her loyal public, could never quite bring themselves to give up on her.

webTitle: Observer review: Patrick O'Brian by Dean King

fields.headline: Oh, a lie on the ocean wave
fields.standfirst: Patrick O'Brian was a great writer. He just wasn't Patrick O'Brian as Dean King reveals in his biography
fields.trailText: Patrick O'Brian was a great writer. He just wasn't Patrick O'Brian as Dean King reveals in his biography
fields.body:
Patrick O'Brian: A Life Revealed
Dean King
Hodder & Stoughton £18.99, pp304
Buy it at BOL

I read most of Patrick O'Brian's celebrated sea novels as they came out, and reviewed several of them. I greatly admired them, marvelling at their virtuoso reconstructions of the Nelsonian past and their irresistible storytelling, but it never occurred to me that I was reading the work of another Tolstoy.

I am perfectly ready to concede that I was wrong, and the author of this substantial first biography of O'Brian would almost certainly think so. Dean King is one of that devoted band of enthusiasts who elevated O'Brian, not long before his death, to an almost unprecedented pinnacle of literary success. In America, bumper stickers, a cookbook and Charlton Heston promoted his fame; here, the British Library honoured a living author for the first time ever by publishing a bibliography of his work.

King is by no means blind to his subject's personal faults. I suppose the wind was rather taken out of his sails during the writing of his book when there appeared in the press the queer story of O'Brian's false identity. As we all know by now, O'Brian was not the sea-going, Gaelic-speaking Irishman he claimed to be, but was the land-lubberly Buckinghamshire-born son of a physician named Russ, of part-German descent.

King deals sensibly with these harmless peccadillos. They were probably partly the natural instinct of a fiction writer to dramatise himself, and partly the reflection of a confused and often unhappy childhood. O'Brian lost his mother when he was three years old, and was never close to his father. The rest of his family was an interesting and often talented assembly of characters, but he seems to have had a floundering sort of upbringing. No wonder he decided to make himself a Celt from the Atlantic shore, and distance himself from his siblings.

The life of innocent deceit takes on a profounder meaning, though, when one remembers that in 1940, O'Brian abandoned his wife, their three-year-old son and a handicapped baby, and went off with Mary Tolstoy, already the mother of the future writer Nicholas Tolstoy. This act of betrayal is perhaps a more real reason for O'Brian's reluctance to talk about his early life. To judge by this book it was his only cause for shame, and his affair with Mary matured over the years into a long, happy and honourable marriage.

Still, the episode probably tainted O'Brian's days, and as we watch him grow older in the pages of this book, his deliberately fostered self-mystery becomes less engaging. He lived for nearly half a century in bohemian semi-reclusion with Mary in the Roussillon village of Collioure, but in his last years, when he was rich and famous, he acquired another personality again. He became a London clubman, an Establishment figure, feted by dukes and celebrities and honoured by the Queen; and this last denouement, however innocuous, somehow makes one doubt the essential integrity of the man.

King's telling of the puzzling tale is decent, fair and extremely thorough, but often ingenuous. There was no Australian Embassy in 1929; there never has been such a thing as 'England's Air Force'; the Basque country is not the same as Catalonia, as page 168 seems to imply. Who cares that, on a journey in France: 'Patrick revved the engine of the little 2CV to pass slow-moving traffic on the winding two-lane roads'? Too much of the book consists of quotations from reviews - one wonders how much even O'Brian himself, who was very sensitive to reviews, cared about opinions expressed in the Housewife, the Chatanooga Times or New Zealand's Taranaki Herald.

On the other hand, it is salutary to be reminded how highly respected O'Brian was as a novelist, short-story writer and biographer long before we had heard of Captain Aubrey and Dr Maturin, and to learn how intricately his personal experiences were woven into his novels. For of course it is as a writer that O'Brian must finally be judged, and Dean has made clear to me, I believe, why it is that I never thought of him in Tolstoyan terms.

It might well be argued that if the 20 volumes of the Aubrey-Maturin cycle were to be telescoped into one book, it really would rival War and Peace as a supremely grand historical novel. O'Brian's attention to detail is astonishing, his invention never flags, his characters are rounded, his plots are compelling and he is often wonderfully merry. His saga ranges the world through many years of history, and his prose can be beautiful.

Why, then, does his work not give me the ultimate frisson I get when I feel I am in the presence of creative greatness, and which constantly moves me as I read the pages of Leo Tolstoy? I think it is because in Tolstoy I know I am confronting fundamental truths, expressed in fiction that has grown organically out of human life, out of history, and out of the author's heart. In O'Brian, on the contrary, I am reading the work of an artificer, a contriver of genius and, well, a liar.

fields.headline: A dictionary for our times
fields.trailText: New dictionaries probably tell us as much about the state of our culture and society as any other kind of book.
fields.body:
New dictionaries probably tell us as much about the state of our culture and society as any other kind of book. Last year's Encarta dictionary was an eloquent commentary on the hurricane of 'globalisation'. Today's New Penguin English Dictionary (£15.99 1,642pp) speaks volumes about the difficulty of providing a reliable snapshot of the language in the age of the internet and the computer diskette.

Traditionally, the dictionary's task was to pin the errant butterfly of language to the page, to capture and codify. In the eighteenth century the dictionary was often seen as the essential bastion against the Visigoths of linguistic innovation. In the days when the only sources were printed ones, and when the only printing method involved hot type, it was easy enough for the lexicographer to insist that the dictionary should approach the riot of language as a self-employed security guard.

Not any more. Confronted by the challenge of online publishing and the cornucopia of new sources from press, television, radio, video, advertising and popular culture, contemporary lexicographers have been forced to admit that the contemporary dictionary is bound to be normative. The New Penguin English Dictionary mirrors this precisely. Where, in the past, such a volume from an established publisher would emphasise its gravitas and comprehensiveness, the New Penguin has taken a tab of ecstasy and is heading off to a rave. It invokes the Devil and announces in the accompanying blurb that it's 'a dictionary with attitude'.

This attitude is defiantly hip and belligerently contemporary. The New Penguin' s publisher, who reads as though he is recovering from the hangover of a lifetime, announces that the English language that interests him is "Ali G's English as well as the Queen's". On closer scrutiny, 'Ali G's English' turns out to be rather less vivid than Mr G himself and to consist very largely of modish formulations from the world of dotcom yuppies, terms like 'quantoid' (somebody who is very enthusiastic about statistics), snakehead (a member of a Chinese gang involved in smuggling illegal immigrants), shedload (a large amount) and page-jacking (the process of diverting internet users from a website).

The New Penguin is also a child of its time in supplying definitions for 'ladette', 'pashmina', 'WAP', 'Blairism' and 'yettie'. Despite its avowed aim of reflecting 'how people really use language today' it omits my two current favourite Americanisms 'bo-bo' (bourgeois bohemian) and 'bogsat' (bunch of guys sitting around and talking), but never mind. How many of these late twentieth-century linguistic novelties will survive is anyone's guess, but the new technology will enable such references to be silently replaced by new coinages as they occur. The New Penguin will no doubt sell in 'shedloads' to the dotcom generation, but it will probably seem rather dated by the year 2005.

webTitle: Observer review: Hugh Casson by Jose Manser

fields.headline: The man who chose the carbuncle
fields.standfirst: He shaped the nation's taste - but he wasn't even a second-rate architect. Deyan Sudjic on Jose Manser's life of Hugh Casson
fields.trailText: He shaped the nation's taste - but he wasn't even a second-rate architect. Deyan Sudjic on Jose Manser's life of Hugh Casson
fields.body:
Hugh Casson: A Biography
Jose Manser
Viking £25, pp409
Buy it at BOL

Jose Manser clearly knew Sir Hugh Casson well enough to feel the need to inject her biography with enough taps on her subject's wrists to demonstrate that she is no partisan but a judiciously dispassionate critic. She protests perhaps a little too much, painting a portrait of a man who, despite all that notorious charm, was distant to the point of being invisible in bringing up his children, who obviously adored him all the same.

A man who was the son of a colonial administrator; but was sniffy about foreigners; an absentee professor at the Royal College of Art who let his department drift to the point of anarchy; an impossible business partner who refused both to be sufficiently involved in the work of the office or to be suitably detached from it either; and an architect who at one point Manser suggests was not even second rate.

Why then bother to write a book at all about the man who was for almost four decades the aesthetic sticking plaster salving the conscience of a British establishment feeling just a little guilty about allowing the Hilton to sprout in Hyde Park, demolishing the Euston arch and driving roads through the hearts of Glasgow and Liverpool. He was constantly popping up to dispense advice to Bath, design the royal boudoir - along with the royal train and the royal yacht - and grace countless agreeable black-tie dinners.

Well, at least two aspects of his career certainly deserve close attention. There was his triumph at the Festival of Britain. If only Stephen Bayley could have turned out watercolour thank you notes with even a fraction of Casson's facility, how different things might have been in Greenwich - even though the festival actually attracted a far from universally enthusiastic response at the time.

James Stirling for example, an authentic big beast of the architecture world in a way that Casson could never be, recalled coming away from the festival with what he called a sense of disgust at its sentimentality and its lost opportunities. But it was never seen as a failure by the wider world beyond architecture. Casson did get it open on time; and he presided over a whimsical collection of pavilions and entertainments that really were a tonic to the nation, in the phrase of the period.

Then, after three decades of increasingly pedestrian architecture - look at Casson and Conder's buildings in Derby, Swindon, and Cambridge, interrupted by one delightful success in the shape of the elephant house at London zoo - Casson got his hands on the Royal Academy, and proceeded to make a pretty good job of rescuing it from financial and cultural oblivion. Yes, it is perfectly true that a lot of people got very cross when Casson wouldn't back the great exhibition on his predecessor as president, the architect Edwin Lutyens, that ended up at the Hayward Gallery instead of the RA which would have been its natural home. And Manser's critical sense certainly falters when she makes an ill-judged comparison of the two architects.

But it was Casson who hired Norman Rosenthal to run the RA's exhibition programme, a move which led directly to the 'Sensation' and 'Apocalypse' exhibitions, the very last outcome that could have been expected from such a polite figure as Casson. And it was Casson, despite his much less successful choice of Piers Rogers as secretary for the academy, who put the place on the road to financial security.

For all her attempts to distance herself from her subject, Manser vociferously defends him against all those - and there were more than a few - who regarded his particular brand of what might be called 'modern lite' as doing more harm than good. Manser's clear conviction is that, on the whole, Casson was a jolly good thing.

Those who pointed to the curiously overcooked confection of the Ismaili Centre, Casson and Conder's dubious project opposite the Victoria and Albert Museum, are denounced as racists. As if this isn't enough to exculpate Casson she cites as an alibi his almost indolent refusal to get involved with the nitty gritty of architecture once the job was landed. It is an argument as double-edged as Manser's anecdote about John Sainsbury asking Casson to recommend a talented young architect to design his house for him, and Casson's unblushing nomination of his 54-year-old self as just the lad for the job, a suggestion that the client accepted with alacrity.

The third aspect of Casson's career that would have repaid closer attention than a perfunctory chapter tacked on at the end is his role as an architectural arbiter of taste, and the extent to which he shaped the aesthetic climate in which English architecture had to operate.

Manser recounts the story of how Casson, as one of the judges in the first National Gallery competition, was actually responsible for the 'monstrous carbuncle' itself, foisting it on a seriously reluctant National Gallery. It comes at the other end of the book from her account of its most dramatic consequence; the night that the Prince of Wales put a whoopee cushion under the architectural profession by making the carbuncle speech at Hampton Court in front of a gathering of architecture's great and good, ostensibly there to award the Royal Gold Medal for Architecture to Charles Correa. Manser, who was herself present at the dinner afterwards, describes Casson as playing the peacemaker between a clearly cross Norman Foster and the prince.

And yet she seems oblivious to the fact that it was Casson himself who was more responsible for the entire outburst than anyone. It would be interesting to know rather more about just what must have been going through Casson's mind at the time, to say nothing of the prince's. The remainder of the group were embarrassed; Casson sat on the fence; though later he suggested that 'the architects reacted with spinster-like cries of, "How dare he?" ' Did not Casson understand the speech; or did he, as is often rumoured, assume that the prince was talking not about his choice, Ahrends Burton and Koralek, but Richard Rogers's far tougher scheme which did not win?

Instead of an insight into the taste wars of the recent past, we get a touching portrait of one of those chilly Edwardian colonial childhoods, of Casson not seeing either parent for critical parts of his adolescence, and the way that it shaped his life.

webTitle: Observer review: Super-Cannes by J.G. Ballard

fields.headline: Designer loathing
fields.standfirst: J.G. Ballard has created another corporate Eden in Super-Cannes. Watch out for the serpents...
fields.trailText: J.G. Ballard has created another corporate Eden in Super-Cannes. Watch out for the serpents...
fields.body:
Super-Cannes
J.G. Ballard
Flamingo £16.99, pp392
Buy it at BOL

J.G. Ballard is the Dr Moreau of British fiction, creator of controlled environments and out-of-control dystopias. He is, of course, uniquely qualified for the role: his Empire of the Sun years in a Shanghai detention camp allowed him grim, unrivalled childhood insight into the mechanics and effects of bizarre enclosure; he now sees constricting theme parks and open prisons everywhere he looks.

His pebble-dashed Shepperton semi, exactly as old as he is, lies between the twin make-believes of the film studios and Heathrow Airport. Every morning he blinks out on this suburban world as through a Big Brother surveillance camera and the first thought to cross his mind is always: 'What is this?' However far we travel in outer space, he says, the worlds just outside our front doors will always be the ones most fundamentally alien to us.

The fully realised visions Ballard creates in his novels are only ever five minutes away from that observed reality. In his last book, Cocaine Nights, he conjured the rarefied Spanish township of Estrella del Mar, home to a vicarious climate-controlled community of British money men, freed from their ties to the City by technology and from social responsibility by their cartoonish wealth. The only recreations in the whitewashed, sanitised resort were tennis, adultery and gratuitous violence.

Here, he refines that concept further, to create Eden-Olympia, Europe's ultra-sophisticated answer to Silicon Valley in the hills above the French Riviera. The business park is the world's first intelligent city, one horribly logical conclusion of a corporatised continent in which 'freedom was the right to paid work, while leisure was the mark of the shiftless and untalented'; dreams here come equipped with airbags, and the only sounds are the whispers of sprinklers on lawns and the effortless combustion of computer-navigated German sports saloons.

The city is home to techno-chic supernationals - Ciba-Geigy and Siemens, Mitsui and Monsanto - and to the Euro-elite of chief executives who control their strategies, a post-leisure class which derives its excitement from the imposition of systematic efficiencies. There is no need here for law or religion; Eden-Olympia polices itself; decisions are corporate not ethical, and sex is something one watches on customised adult channels.

Ballard carefully constructs this serpentless paradise in perfectly engineered sentences. His images come together with the satisfying hiss of Japanese micro-hydraulics. 'There was a vast car park concealed behind a screen of cypresses, vehicles nose to tail like a week's unsold output at a Renault plant,' he writes. 'Somewhere in the office buildings the owners of these cars were staring at their screens, designing a new cathedral or cineplex, or watching the world's spot prices. The sense of focused brain power was bracing, but subtly unsettling.'

Little disturbs the slick meniscus of this prose which coolly reflects its environment like the Eden-Olympia swimming pools into which no executive would ever dream of diving. But there is a great deal going on beneath its carefully maintained surface tension. More than any other writer Ballard understands the transformation technology may effect on human desire. This is his most potent statement yet of the outcome of that transformation, an elegant nightmare with all the internal coherence of an Escher engraving or a Calvino fable.

Into this hothouse of millennial dreams, at the outset of this novel, drive a young British couple in a temperamental old Jag. Paul Sinclair is a commercial pilot recovering from a crash in his antique single-engined Harvard; his new wife Jane is a consultant paediatrician disillusioned with an NHS in which she has been forced to work as an auxiliary bedpan emptier. They met while he was recuperating, an affair accelerated in true Ballard style by the erotic qualities of Paul's leg brace.

Jane has accepted a job at the Eden-Olympia medical centre, replacing an old friend, another British doctor, David Greenwood, who recently and inexplicably had gone berserk with an automatic rifle, apparently killing 10 of the residents of the park before turning his gun on himself.

Their story is told through the eyes of Paul, who, along for the ride and sleeping in the serial murderer's bed, finds himself drawn to examine the motives for Greenwood's psychosis and in turn the reality of Eden-Olympia. Ballard unravels the secrets of his post-industrial elysium with panache, leading us into a society which is both an exaggerated parable for our times and a chill piece of futurology. Along the way there are some signature themes: Ballard's books always feel as though they are shot on security cameras and spotlit by police flash photography; their violence is both sterile and graphic. The worlds he describes are frequently immunised against human emotion. And in Eden-Olympia that deficiency has become a potentially fatal threat.

This is a place in which illness has been almost eradicated by the constant daily monitoring of its sleek, toned population. Every morning each one of its citizens dials the clinic and logs in their health data: pulse, blood pressure, weight and so on. Stress is minimised through an unfailing network of support systems. The problem, if anything, as set out by the community's resident consultant psychiatrist and project leader Wilder Penrose 'is not that too many people are insane, but too few...' and that in the absence of conflict a certain aspect of humanity is atrophying.

Penrose's extreme antidote to this dulling of his population's moral edge is to force feed the community regulated doses of antisocial behaviour. The wild joker Penrose casts among the gently susurrating cypresses of Eden-Olympia could hardly be more extreme; under his instruction the corporate leaders have become a kind of designer fight club. They go down into the Arab ghettoes at night and make home movies of the beatings and robberies, murders and rapes they enact, all in order to remind themselves of their humanity.

This 'weekend fascism' - assisted by the park's security staff who are paid-up members of the Front National - is a typical Ballard inversion. In this vision crime becomes recreation of the super-rich; the corporate overlords ride out to trample on the villagers. 'The middle class have run the world since the French Revolution,' Penrose argues. 'But they're the new proletariat. It's time for another elite to set the agenda.'

As ever, Ballard gives this agenda its full realisation. His satire, however extreme, is always convincing because its governing ideas inhabit every detail. He sees a strain of totalitarianism running through particular dehumanised philosophies of engineering and design and management; sees the potential for dictatorship in the absence of democracy engendered by the colossal power of corporations.

Set this against the credible notion that 'for the talented and ambitious the future means work, not play' (there is no place in Eden-Olympia for those who are 'not net contributors to society: poets, traffic wardens, ecologists...') and what you come up with is a place that is 'very civilised and very corrupt. webTitle: Leader: Britain is failing on education

fields.headline: Britain is failing on education
fields.standfirst:
Our 'divisive' system must end

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: This government talks a good game when it comes to social inclusion and children. It has produced a catalogue of initiatives - all with names designed to suggest a new dawn.
fields.body:
This government talks a good game when it comes to social inclusion and children. It has produced a catalogue of initiatives - all with names designed to suggest a new dawn.

Sure Start for young mothers, New Start for alienated teenagers and Fresh Start for failing schools sounded wonderfully millennarian when introduced. But the cold reality in this first year of the twenty-first century is that our education system remains the most fragmented and divisive in Western Europe. Even those close to Tony Blair know this to be true.

Before he joined the Number 10 Policy Unit, Andrew Adonis wrote a series of articles for this newspaper entitled 'The Great Divide' in which he lamented the 'apartheid' in the schools system that Labour had inherited from the Tories. Tragically, all too little has changed. No one should gloat at the failure of Fresh Start, least of all the Conservative Party, itself responsible for two decades of neglect which brought state education to its knees. But the news that only one of the Government's Fresh Start schools has shown any marked improvement in standards comes as no surprise when nothing has been done to tackle the fundamental divide at the heart of British education.

The summer began with a row over élitism at Oxford. Autumn begins with a 'sink-school' crisis. The two issues are interlinked. We have an education system based on élitism. While we continue to find it acceptable that our top universities should be dominated by children who have attended private schools, it is unlikely that we will tackle the so-called 'failing schools' at the bottom. This Government desperately hoped to finesse the politically explosive issues of selection and private schools, and concentrate on improving the rump of the comprehensive system instead. This is clearly not working and the children in need of greatest support are still not receiving enough.

This is a matter of such gravity that the Prime Minister should institute a National Commission to investigate educational underperformance. At the top of its agenda should be the issues of selection, the current poor governance of so many state schools and the unfairly advantageous charitable status of private ones.

fields.headline: Pro-life rage over 'lessons in abortion'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teachers are being advised to encourage underage students who become pregnant to abort their babies under new government guidelines which will come into force tomorrow, pro-life campaigners have claimed.
fields.body:
Teachers are being advised to encourage underage students who become pregnant to abort their babies under new government guidelines which will come into force tomorrow, pro-life campaigners have claimed.

It is the first time the Government has officially advised teachers to tackle abortion as part of standard sex education and offered guidelines on how to do so.

The guidelines emphasise that, while respecting the religious convictions of pupils and parents, teachers must accept that pregnant girls 'need to know how to access relevant agencies if necessary'. Both pro-life and pro-choice campaigners agree that the term 'relevant agencies' refers to abortion clinics.

The document also says that, while aiming to reduce the number of unwanted teenage pregnancies among students, teachers should encourage students to consider the benefits of abortion if pregnancy does occur.

Pro-life groups are enraged by the campaign, launched after a report found the pregnancy rate among British girls aged 15 to 19 is the highest in Europe, and still rising.

At 6 per cent, the British rate of teenage pregnancy is twice that of Germany's, three times the rate in France and six times that of the Netherlands. Only Canada, New Zealand and the United States have higher rates.

But according to pro-life campaigners, the document, to be read by all head teachers, teachers and school governors, endorses under-age sex and fails to suggest any alternative to unwanted pregnancies other than abortion.

'This document advises teachers to encourage children with unwanted pregnancies to turn immediately to abortion clinics without considering any other option,' said Josephine Quintavalle, campaign manager at the Pro-Life Alliance. 'That's an unacceptable and completely irresponsible thing to do. Abortion is just one of many options open to pregnant women,' she said. 'The Government is losing the plot on the abortion issue: the figures speak for themselves.'

Quintavalle believes helping pregnant girls abort their babies rather than focusing on prevention will only exacerbate the problem of teenage pregnancy.

'How can young people see that underage sex is wrong when they're getting the message in the classroom that underage pregnancies can be sorted out?' she asked.

More than 90,000 teenagers in England fall pregnant each year - 8,000 of them under 16 - and 38 per cent of such pregnancies were terminated in 1998 - almost 39,000 abortions.

The Government hopes the guidelines will protect children from the 'inappropriate teaching and materials' circulating in some schools which oppose abortion.

But Paul Tully, general secretary of the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child, anticipates an outcry once teachers realise what they are being urged to do.

'These new guidelines are incredibly disturbing,' he said. 'The only explicit references made are to abortion and that's a great concern.

'The publication has not yet come to the attention of parents or religious groups but when it does, there will be a great outcry. Many teachers will be appalled by the fact that they are being put in this position where, to fulfil these guidelines, they are being pushed towards a situation where they're being expected to promote abortion.'

The guidelines were welcomed by pro-choice groups, but many believe they do not go far enough.

'Schools need to feel confident that they can provide information to help young people to understand the options open to them but the cowardly way it is dealt with in this document has obviously been influenced by people who will never regard abortion as a positive choice,' said Anne Weyman, chief executive of the Family Planning Association.

Jane Roe of the Abortion Law Reform Association says the guidelines presume that abortion is morally wrong.

'While never an easy decision, abortion could be the best option available to a young girl,' she said. 'We're very disappointed that the Government is still treating abortion as a problem in itself, rather than a solution.'

'It's a powerful indication of what the Government wants schools to do,' said Sarah Colborne, chair of the National Abortion Campaign. 'It's giving teachers who aren't quite sure the clearance to point students in the direction of abortion clinics and giving a clear indication to those who are against choice that they would be failing in their duties if they exclude discussions about the issue from their lessons.'
