fields.headline: Sink schools carry on sinking
fields.standfirst:
Results show that the gulf between the haves and have-nots in British education is as big as ever

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Results show that the gulf between the haves and have-nots in British education is as big as ever
fields.body:
Huw Howe provided Education Secretary David Blunkett with his one good news story of last week. Just. As headteacher at Fir Vale Secondary School in Sheffield he has managed to squeeze enough improvement out of his most able children to save his local MP from extreme embarrassment. His was the only school in the Government's flagship Fresh Start scheme for failing schools to show any real rise in its GSCE results last week, and that by just a tiny margin.

This weekend Howe was understandably defensive of the Fresh Start scheme, by which failing schools are closed down and reborn with new headteachers, new management and a new name. 'The situation in schools like ours is very complex and needs to be managed with sensitivity. I won't comment on the other schools, but the reason we are bucking the trend is that we have established partnerships, working very closely with other schools, the local authority and benefiting from the strong leadership of the governors.'

He was fortunate. Torsten Friedag, the superhead at London's flagship Islington Arts and Media School, who resigned earlier this year after just months in the job, found himself caught between some hostile left-wing governors opposed to New Labour's education policy and a Lib-Dem controlled local authority that wouldn't release the money he needed. The experienced heads at Firfield Community School in Newcastle and East Brighton College of Media Arts found themselves in similarly impossible positions before they threw in the towel.

The rash of summer stories about ever-increasing numbers of exam passes at GCSE and A level, the news that girls were outperforming boys across the board and the Laura Spence affair over elitism at Oxford all concentrated on the children at the top of the pile. Last week's evidence that the Fresh Start scheme is in meltdown was a salutary wake-up call to a government obsessed with education. At Firfield, only 4 per cent of pupils scored five or more GCSEs at A*-C grades and at East Brighton College the proportion fell from 20 to 13 per cent. At Islington Arts and Media School, where Tony Blair's special adviser on education was on the appointment panel for Friedag, only four pupils managed to achieve a total of five results in the top three grades.

Howe, a determined character who worked in tough inner-city schools in the West Midlands before moving to Sheffield, knows that he is only one bad year away from failure. When you are near the bottom of the league tables, a handful of able children can make a difference of several percentage points. He had therefore unashamedly concentrated on the children capable of boosting the figures and attracting more children to the school who can do the same.

'We have a large proportion of youngsters for whom English is their second language and while we are still undersubscribed we are still vulnerable to refugees coming in to the school who inevitably depress the results.'

One of his major achievements is that this year's intake and classes now moving into the second year are full and no longer open to new arrivals excluded from other schools or asylum seekers who have just arrived in the country. Howe doesn't buy the idea that the success of his school will simply create a sink school elsewhere in the city. 'The secondary schools in this part of Sheffield have always had a tough ride. The real problem is that pupils have to catch a bus to the other side of the city after the age of 16 because there are no sixth-forms.'

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers, has been at the centre of the debate over failing schools since he took up the case of teachers at the ill-fated Ridings school in Calderdale, which was forced to close after children rioted. He believes Blunkett is genuine in his wish to tackle underachievement, but not prepared to put his money where his mouth is. 'There is nothing magic about this, you need a brilliant head and brilliant staff and lots of them. In these sorts of schools you need class sizes of about 10 pupils, to treble the number of staff and pay them premium salaries. They are just not prepared to face up to the cost and so they turn to privatisation.'

The symbolic importance of Fir Vale cannot be underestimated. The school - the name was changed from Earl Marshall two years ago - is right in Blunkett's backyard, bang next door to his Brightside constituency. Quite properly, the Secretary of State has been one of the school's most high-profile supporters, happy to be photographed laughing with the head during better times.

The proportion of 16-year-olds at Fir Vale gaining five or more exams at grade C or above rose from 11 to 17 per cent, but even a recognised superhead like Howe realises he is not out of the woods yet: the national target is 50 per cent. This weekend Howe, a straight-talking pragmatist, told The Observer that his targets had to be modest because he knew he was working with children who had become almost completely alienated from the education system. Next year, he will aim for 20 per cent.

Research by the Roehampton Institute has identified a contradiction at the centre of New Labour's education policy. 'On the one hand, New Labour has decided to continue the Conservatives' policies of choice and competition; on the other hand, it has put in place a package of policies to reduce social exclusion,' says Jim Docking, senior researcher. These policies, which include privatisation of failing schools, the Fresh Start scheme, Education Action Zones, and the new Excellence in Cities programme to persuade middle-class parents back into the state system by introducing increased selection, have yet to be genuinely tested and this summer's exam results demonstrate that the gap between the educational haves and have-nots is as great as ever.

Blunkett's timetable

May 1997

Numeracy and literacy targets

For 11-year-olds.

July 1997

Fresh Start

Blakelaw in Newcastle reopened under the name Firfield Community College.

September 1997

New Start

£10m over three years to help remotivate 14- to 17-year-olds who have dropped out.

January 1998

Headteachers honoured

To improve image of teaching.

May 1998

Social Exclusion Unit

Truancy and social exclusion: calls for levels to be reduced by one-third by 2002.

July 1998

Sure Start Pre-School programme

Focus on 125,000 pre-school children and their families.

September 1998

New Deal for Communities

Deals with run-down estates and failure in schools.

February 1999

Booster classes

First 'crammer' lessons for Year 6 children with literacy and numeracy problems.

March 1999

Excellence in Cities

Launched to revitalise urban schools.

July 1999

Teaching and Higher Education Act & School Standards and Framework Act passed. The former reduced the length of some courses to two years. The latter removed the LEA's ability to review expulsions.

January 2000

Maths Year 2000

A programme of action to ensure 75% of 11-year-olds reaching the expected standard in maths by 2002.

September 2000

Revised National Curriculum

Plans for lessons on citizenship.

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters/Union of Women Teachers, has been at the centre of the debate over failing schools since he took up the case of teachers at the ill-fated Ridings school in Calderdale, which was forced to close after children rioted. He believes Blunkett is genuine in his wish to tackle underachievement, but not prepared to put his money where his mouth is. 'There is nothing magic about this, you need a brilliant head and brilliant staff and lots of them. In these sorts of schools you need class sizes of about 10 pupils, to treble the number of staff and pay them premium salaries. They are just not prepared to face up to the cost and so they turn to privatisation.' The symbolic importance of Fir Vale cannot be underestimated. The school - the name was changed from Earl Marshall two years ago - is right in Blunkett's backyard, bang next door to his Brightside constituency. Quite properly, the Secretary of State has been one of the school's most high-profile supporters, happy to be photographed laughing with the head during better times. The proportion of 16-year-olds at Fir Vale gaining five or more exams at grade C or above rose from 11 to 17 per cent, but even a recognised superhead like Howe realises he is not out of the woods yet: the national target is 50 per cent. This weekend Howe, a straight-talking pragmatist, told The Observer that his targets had to be modest because he knew he was working with children who had become almost completely alienated from the education system. Next year, he will aim for 20 per cent. Research by the Roehampton Institute has identified a contradiction at the centre of New Labour's education policy. 'On the one hand, New Labour has decided to continue the Conservatives' policies of choice and competition; on the other hand, it has put in place a package of policies to reduce social exclusion,' says Jim Docking, senior researcher. These policies, which include privatisation of failing schools, the Fresh Start scheme, Education Action Zones, and the new Excellence in Cities programme to persuade middle-class parents back into the state system by introducing increased selection, have yet to be genuinely tested and this summer's exam results demonstrate that the gap between the educational haves and have-nots is as great as ever. September 1997 New Start £10m over three years to help remotivate 14- to 17-year-olds who have dropped out. January 1998 Headteachers honoured To improve image of teaching. May 1998 Social Exclusion Unit Truancy and social exclusion: calls for levels to be reduced by one-third by 2002. July 1998 Sure Start Pre-School programme Focus on 125,000 pre-school children and their families. September 1998 New Deal for Communities Deals with run-down estates and failure in schools. February 1999 Booster classes First 'crammer' lessons for Year 6 children with literacy and numeracy problems. March 1999 Excellence in Cities Launched to revitalise urban schools. July 1999 Teaching and Higher Education Act & School Standards and Framework Act passed. The former reduced the length of some courses to two years. The latter removed the LEA's ability to review expulsions. January 2000 Maths Year 2000 A programme of action to ensure 75% of 11-year-olds reaching the expected standard in maths by 2002. September 2000 Revised National Curriculum Plans for lessons on citizenship.

webTitle: Teenage kicks: Boys? Must try harder

fields.headline: Boys? Must try harder
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: I started a new school last week, for the seventh time in my life.
fields.body:
I started a new school last week, for the seventh time in my life. I've been a new girl at a Quaker school when I thought Quaker was a type of oats. I've been a new girl at an American school where I refused to pledge allegiance to the flag. I've worn the wrong uniform, turned up at wrong times and thrown up in school toilets. However, each time I was merely an amateur new girl. This year, having just joined a mixed school for A-levels, I was professional.

Judging from previous first-day experience, everything that can go wrong does go wrong. I made a morbid list, anticipating problems like having the hiccups during assembly and getting locked in the toilet. But as it happened my first day went disarmingly well.

I still had hair when I woke up in the morning. I didn't trip over while walking into school. I was wearing similar clothes to everybody else. I had the same accent. I turned up at the right time, on the right day. I didn't get hiccups, I didn't sneeze at any awkward times all day. I had even remembered to clear out my schoolbag for the first time in four years so that when I took out a pen I didn't also spill hundreds of old tissues, Tampax, lottery tickets, socks, leaflets, holiday photos and pieces of homework still due at my old school. The only problem was that I was the wrong sex.

This new school is a boys' school, which now takes girls in the sixth form. Scary. The boys wear proper suits and eat at proper tables. There is a whole vocabulary I've never heard of, like 'gating' and 'houses' and 'stations' and 'water'. They are actually going to make us play sport as opposed to allowing us to spend time in the multi-gym, sitting next to the rowing machine painting our nails and stretching.

Throughout my prime teenage years I was denied the company of boys to carry my school bag and steal my protractor. After three years at an all-girl school, only seeing boys at the weekend, I was beginning to find myself wondering what a boy looked like when he wasn't holding a cigarette and a beer and trying to sleep with you. Therefore, seeing boys in a normal environment is a healthy change.

The last time I was at school with boys was when kiss chase and sticker swapping were the most popular activities. It does not seem natural to be in an all-girl school when you're 16. You have boyfriends out of school but you are forced to see them as a different species. You only learn to interact with boys on one level, and it is unlike the outside world.

Single-sex schools claim that they are protecting you but really it's just putting you in Bubble Wrap during the week and ripping it straight off at the weekend. It makes more sense just to let everyone get on as they were meant to, I suppose.

What worries me is whether the classroom will end up mirroring society? Will the girls have to flutter their eyelashes when Disraeli is mentioned while the boys stirringly recount their views, opinions and impressive collection of facts? Will we have to stare into their eyes as they offer their theses on various wars? Will we have to giggle appreciatively when they define suffragettes as lesbians?

Or will it teach us to stick up for ourselves. I suppose we are going to have to cast aside all the techniques that we have previously used to get our own way with boys and now instead opt for a more rigorous, academic approach. I now have to disagree with them, argue with them, try to be better than them.

It is said that at sixth-form level, girls are brought in to somehow jump-start the boys. I see it the other way round, however, with the boys jump starting the girls. I haven't beaten anybody up yet, but I am taking martial arts classes, just to show how tough I am.

I have a horrible feeling they're expecting me to work quite hard to keep up with the boys, so no more columns for a while.

fields.headline: 'We took the step forward needed'
fields.trailText: Keegan praises players as Euro 2000 becomes just a distant nightmare.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan praised his players for the 'gutsy' way they went about taking on the world's best team.

After the limp surrender in Euro 2000, more spirit was exactly what Keegan wanted, especially as France seemed intent on using this friendly as a gigantic celebration of their recent success.

'France were having a party, but we didn't want to be just making up the numbers at a sideshow,' Keegan said. 'I think we deserved what we got out of the game. To have come away with nothing would have been a travesty.

'We didn't sit back. We got right at them and put our stamp on the game in the first 20 minutes. We needed to take a step forward, and that's what we've done. Even when we went a goal down, I still felt we could get something out of it. That was a real game tonight, between two nations with a lot of pride.'

Owen was disappointed to start on the bench, Keegan revealed, but proved his point in the best possible way.

'He gave me the perfect answer,' said Keegan. 'The cross from Kieron Dyer was one David Beckham would have been proud of, and Michael came up with a great finish.'

Keegan was impressed with Beckham's contribution from central midfield: 'It was hard work for him in there, but he did OK. He's got a fantastic attitude and the engine to go with it. He's the future in that position, I'm convinced of that.'

fields.headline: Parallel universe may spell the end for broadcast TV
fields.standfirst: Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: People have taken to accessing the Big Brother site from office networks rather than waiting for images to arrive via domestic systems. Some humourless drudge has worked out that 15 minutes wasted in this way costs employers £2.91.
fields.body:
It's fascinating to watch a great industry go down the tubes. I refer, of course, to broadcast television. Last week it was reported that RTL - owner of Channel 5 - has decided to spend some money improving the channel's 'tacky' image (to use the FT 's phrase). The best way of improving Channel 5's image is to take it off air, but this option, alas, does not seem to be on the table.

As they call in the consultants, RTL executives will find a new phrase cropping up in PowerPoint presentations: 'parallel broadcasting'. The idea is beautifully simple. First think up a tacky scenario that panders to the voyeuristic instinct lurking deep in every viewer. Then commission a company to make this happen. Finally, broadcast some of the action on your television channel while making live video feeds available round the clock from a website. Before you know where you are you have a big hit on your hands.

The latest example of this ingenious formula is Big Brother - Channel 4's current contribution to distinctive minority programming. The formula calls for 10 strangers to be isolated from the outside world in a house equipped with 26 cameras and 30 microphones that record their every activity. A website providing streaming video enables people to eavesdrop on the subjects round the clock while a nightly TV programme provides edited highlights, if that is the right word.

The idea originated in the Netherlands, a country that once was a great centre of arts and learning. Last year the Dutch version of Big Brother generated 52 million total page views, and similar shows drew more than 200 million viewers during a 100- day period in Spain and Germany. Channel 4 is getting between 100,000 and 150,000 unique users every day hitting the Big Brother website for an average user session duration of 15 minutes.

The problem is that, as the site's managers explain, 'even with today's advanced internet technology, the web connection going into your house is pretty much like the proverbial eye of a needle. Television pictures are not just the size of a camel, they are a whole line of camels running past at the rate of 25 every second'.

One consequence of this is that people have taken to accessing the Big Brother site from office networks rather than waiting interminably for images to arrive via domestic dial-up systems. Some humourless drudge commissioned by a software surveillance company has worked out that 15 minutes wasted in this way costs employers £2.91 per video stream, based on the average gross hourly rate of £11.64 (taken from the April 1999 earnings survey from the Office for the National Statistics). Big Brother is costing the nation's employers £1.4 million a week!

This is presumably what lies behind last week's announcement that Tony Blair has decided that everyone in the country should have broadband access to the internet by 2005. He does not want the citizenry wasting time at work when they could be wasting time at home.

Of course the Prime Minister's broadband pledge might be just another futile New Labour gesture (akin to the one about making the UK the most 'e-friendly' country in Europe). Nevertheless, if I were a broadcasting executive I would be sitting up and paying attention because if people do eventually get broadband at home then they will be able to receive TV signals of acceptable quality.

In which case, their attachment to conventional broadcasting might diminish to the point where advertisers begin to notice. The phrase 'parallel broadcasting' will then return to haunt the television industry as it discovers that while parallel lines may not converge in geometry, in the media world they just might. And if they do they will converge on the web.

fields.headline: England give France a fright
fields.standfirst: France 1 - 1 England
fields.trailText: A goal from substitute Michael Owen five minutes from the end earned England a highly creditable draw in a fiercely contested friendly against the best team around in world football at the moment.
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at the Stade de France
fields.body:
A goal from substitute Michael Owen five minutes from the end earned England a highly creditable draw in a fiercely contested friendly against the best team around in world football at the moment.

Anxious afterwards to stress that neither team had taken this fixture lightly, Kevin Keegan was already pleased with the performance of his reshaped post-Shearer side before Owen put a broad smile on his manager's face. This was a vastly different, more effervescent England than anything seen since the first 20 minutes of Euro 2000, and would have been even in defeat. The Stade de France was stunned by the cheekiest of equalisers, but long before that England had established they could live with the most illustrious of opponents.

France are in the unique position of holding both World Cup and the European Championship, and certainly know how to make the most of it. After children in replica kits had paraded both trophies around the pitch, the start was delayed five minutes by presentations to the retiring Laurent Blanc, Didier Deschamps and Bernard Lama, then Zinedine Zidane was permitted to bring his child to the centre circle to perform a mock kick-off.

England had little choice but to stand around whistling during this period of indulgence, and in the circumstances one could almost forgive Dennis Wise for fouling Zidane in the opening minute.

England had promised to improve their passing and ball retention and were as good as their word from the outset. Both sets of supporters were rubbing their eyes in disbelief as Keegan's players tore into their opponents in the early stages, creating a couple of presentable scoring opportunities in the first 15 minutes.

David Beckham found Darren Anderton easily on the right, but with Nick Barmby in particular showing mobility and awareness, England attacked through the middle and on the floor as if the last couple of years of ploughing predictable furrows down the flanks had just been a bad dream.

Gareth Barry, coming forward confidently, swapped passes with Barmby and fired a warning shot at Lama's goal after six minutes, but the French goalkeeper was much more seriously tested five minutes later when Andy Cole got a header on target from Paul Scholes' ball into the box. Lama then nervously swatted an Anderton cross over his bar, and had to make the most agile of reaction saves when Beckham's corner bounced through to leave Barmby what looked like a simple header at the far post.

If this makes it sound like it was all England, it was never quite that. Zidane escaped his midfield minders in the 10th minute to carry the ball past Barmby's flailing challenge to leave Nicolas Anelka a shot from the edge of the area, and Deschamps also went close before the interval. France came into the game more as Zidane began to make his presence felt towards the end of the first half, but England made encouraging progress practically every time they went forward.

Beckham distributed with precision and economy from midfield, but more often than not it was Scholes' final ball which found an opening. England replaced Tony Adams, victim of a double tackle by Marcel Desailly and Deschamps, with Gareth Southgate for the second half, the captain's armband passing to Sol Campbell at right-back. France brought on Sylvain Wiltord, who immediately looked busier than Anelka, feeding Zidane for another defence-splitting pass in the 49th minute. Youri Djorkaeff was the recipient, but Campbell atoned for his initial mistake in playing him onside by dispossessing the Frenchman.

Cole was next to sight goal, recovering his footing quicker than the French defence only to shoot tamely at Lama with more time than he perhaps realised. England's best chance of taking the lead, however, fell to one of their best players just before the hour. Barmby definitely had more time than he realised, perhaps more than he actually needed, when he ran round the back of the French defence to collect Wise's through ball. The Liverpool player was alone in possession with only Lama to beat, though could only man age a shot on the turn which cleared the bar.

France held the game up again with hugs and kisses for the departing Deschamps and Blanc after an hour, but if England interpreted this as a sign that the remainder of the game would pass peacefully they could not have been more wrong. France put their foot down instead, a subtle change of pace indicated by Zidane's caution for a retaliatory foul on Wise.

None the less the home side were preparing to substitute their most influential player when he played the most effective pass of the game, a simple inside ball for Emmanuel Petit to collect and run on to beat Seaman low to his right. Just to prove that was no fluke and that France were in complete control now, Lilian Thuram was inches away from a second on the next attack, and Wiltord and David Trezeguet both brought diving saves from Seaman.

England only sent on Owen for the last 13 minutes, and even he would have been unable to make a difference had Trezeguet put away a good chance eight minutes from the end, but a trio of substitutes exposed French complacency five minutes from time. First Steve McManaman made good ground to establish an attacking position, Kieron Dyer whipped in a ball from the right and Owen ran through the French defence to volley past the surprised Lama.

England had been impressive enough, this was better than anyone had dared hope. Dyer even managed a cross from which Cole was close to a winner at the death. Perhaps judgment had better be reserved until the real games start, but at least Germany are no longer the only ones staging a recovery.

France Lama, Thuram (Candela, 80min), Blanc (Leboeuf, 57), Desailly, Djorkaeff, Deschamps (Vieira, 57), Petit, Zidane (Pires, 65), Henry (Trézeguet, 72), Anelka (Wiltord, h-t). Subs not used: Barthez, Micoud, Karembeu, Dugarry, Ramé.

England Seaman; Campbell, Adams (Southgate, h-t), Keown, Barry; Anderton (Dyer, 69), Beckham, Wise, Scholes (Owen, 78), Barmby (McManaman, 82); Cole. Subs not used: Martyn, P Neville, Ince, Smith, James.

Referee J Ansuategui Roca (Spain).

fields.headline: Missing Lucie: sighting claim
fields.trailText: A British woman who disappeared while working as a bar hostess in Tokyo may have been spotted in Hong Kong.
fields.body:
A British woman who disappeared while working as a bar hostess in Tokyo may have been spotted in Hong Kong.

An Australian research chemist claims he saw a woman resembling Lucie Blackman, who was 22 on Friday, withdrawing money from a cashpoint machine between 16 and 18 July after seeing her picture in the China Evening Post. Keith Bobbermein, who is now in London, told the BBC she was shouting incoherently.

Blackman, a former British Airways flight attendant from Sevenoaks, Kent, disappeared on 1 July from an apartment in the Shibuya ward of Tokyo.

Her father Tim Blackman, from Ryde, Isle of Wight, told a recent news conference he believed his daughter had been kidnapped with four other Western girls and shipped to Hong Kong, possibly to be sold for sex slavery.

He said he had received an unconfirmed anonymous tip saying the former BA air hostess had been spirited out of the country.

Yesterday he said Bobbermein's possible sighting was being followed up. It was one of many reported to a special hotline set up in Japan.

'The date seems a bit early for us,' he said 'and he was describing someone a bit shorter, but you can never be sure. We have had a number of messages of this type on the hotline. We have to sift through them to see if we can develop a pattern.

'I have spoken to Mr Bobbermein and he seems very credible. I think the best thing we can do is identify if those particular cashpoint machines were in a CCTV area and see whether we can get anything from that.'

fields.headline: Lobster wars enrage Indians
fields.standfirst: Mounties called in after Canadian lawmen are caught on video ramming fishing boats
fields.trailText: A bitter dispute over Canadian lobster fishing rights has erupted into violence and allegations of attempted murder after a Department of Fisheries and Oceans patrol boat was filmed ramming native Mi'kmaq fishing boats.
fields.body:
A bitter dispute over Canadian lobster fishing rights has erupted into violence and allegations of attempted murder after a Department of Fisheries and Oceans patrol boat was filmed ramming native Mi'kmaq fishing boats.

The incident took place at Burnt Church, New Brunswick, an Indian Reservation with a population of about 1,200. Burnt Church First Nation, the Indian council, has accused the law enforcers from the DFO of attempted murder and demanded that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police investigate the charge.

The raid, the most recent and violent in a series that began early last month, was carried out last Tuesday when federal fisheries officers swept into the reservation's fishing grounds, confiscating 900 lobster traps.

Twenty-two DFO and police patrol boats and Zodiacs (inflatable rafts), crewed by up to 100 armed law enforcers in riot gear, swooped into Miramichi Bay at 2.30am. The fisheries officers, armed with 9mm pistols, pepper spray canisters and batons, were joined by two police emergency response teams toting semi-automatic weapons. Their mission was to seize lobster pots, but the operation turned nasty. The Feds were joined at daybreak by 14 native craft that swarmed around the larger vesselsto protect their equipment. Nearly 100 Burnt Church locals watched from the shore as federal vessels charged at small native boats, swamping and sinking two, forcing the occupants to leap overboard.

Moments later, a powerful DFO vessel charged towards another native boat, an aluminium craft, ramming its stern. Its Mi'kmaq passengers abandoned ship just before impact. Fishermen hurled stones and bricks at the law and in turn were sprayed with mace gas and struck with batons. There were minor injuries on both sides.

James Ward, a Mi'kmaq fisherman and head of Burnt Church's own fishery management plan, was the first man on the water - and the first in it. 'We only had three boats in the water at that point,' he said. 'The officers pinned my boat with two Zodiacs. The hull of our boat was cracked and taking in water. Their boat came down on top of us. I was slightly injured. It didn't take long.

His brother, Danny Ward, fared worse. 'He was in a skow, a two-man boat. They ran him over and filled the boat with water, forcing him overboard. They started macing him while he was in the water and beating him with batons. Then they handcuffed him and slammed his face down on the boat - his nose was cut open.'

The confrontation was captured on video and broadcast across the nation in what has probably been the worst public relations disaster in the DFO's history. Indian nations across Canada are declaring solidarity with Burnt Church by refusing financial compromises to settle similar disputes.

Some chiefs have called for the resignation of Fisheries Minister Herb Dhaliwal. A meeting between Dhaliwal and Burnt Church Chief Wilbur Dedam is likely to take place tomorrow.

Bob Allain, DFO official in East New Brunswick, told The Observer the incident was 'regrettable'. 'The department has begun a post-operational review of the situation. I'm not going to suggest reasons for why this [incident] has happened, that will be covered in the official report.' Allain says fisheries officials will continue to monitor 'all developments' in the area. Will there be further raids? 'We won't comment in advance. At the moment, the monitoring situation could turn into an enforcement issue at any time.'

Karen Somerville, spokeswoman for Burnt Church First Nation, has witnessed 'raid upon raid', but nothing so 'drastic' as last Tuesday's. 'The fact is, non-native fishers have put a lot of pressure on the DFO and the officers to "keep us in line".'

The dispute began on 10 August when the Mi'Kmaq Burnt Church Band decided to follow its own fishing policy, citing a 240-year-old treaty granting them control of their own fishing management. The treaty right was upheld by a Supreme Court ruling last year allowing natives to fish all year round and without quotas.

The government disagrees, saying the court also ruled the Indian nation would be subject to gov ernment regulations - hence the DFO raids to seize fishing equipment considered to be illegal.

The Burnt Church First Nation insists it is within its rights. Somerville explains: 'If we continue fishing lobsters, it's got nothing to do with defiance. People are grateful about being able to exercise their treaty right, they were restrained from doing so for many years.

'That right has been re-affirmed and reconfirmed by the Supreme Court. It's not illegal in our eyes, it's legal fishing. The issue for the DFO is that we want to manage ourselves.'

webTitle: Athletes in asthma crisis as pollution soars

fields.headline: Athletes in asthma crisis as pollution soars
fields.trailText: High-achieving athletes are risking permanent lung damage, a conference of international experts has revealed. Startling new evidence shows that asthma is more prevalent among some types of athletes than among smokers.
fields.body:
High-achieving athletes are risking permanent lung damage, a conference of international experts has revealed. Startling new evidence shows that asthma is more prevalent among some types of athletes than among smokers.

It comes after yesterday's Lancet published research showing that traffic fumes are causing serious lung disease to people across Europe, accounting for at least one in 20 deaths.

The study that found pollution from cars and lorries was the cause of 25,000 cases of chronic bronchitis and more than half a million asthma attacks in France, Austria and Switzerland. The research by Dr Nino Kunzli of Basle University showed that the health cost of air pollution from vehicles was higher than that of road accidents.

Now experts at the lung disease conference in Florence have expressed grave concern about the consequences of intensive training on the lungs of sportsmen and women in the run-up to the 2000 games in Sydney. Two of Britain's Olympic contenders told The Observer they were seeing rises in respiratory problems among colleagues, and both put the problem down to UK athletes training in polluted air.

Up to 50 per cent of athletes competing in long-distance running, cycling, swimming and cross-country skiing events are developing the problem.

The reasons are unclear since the causes of asthma are not known, although pollution, smoking and diet are known to be contributory fac tors. However, scientists claim cold air is a factor for skiers, and chlorine in pools a factor for swimmers.

Paula Radcliffe is one of the UK's brightest hopes for a gold medal in Sydney. The 10,000 metre runner has been suffering from asthma since she began seriously training as an athlete at the age of 14. The pollen and pollution in Sydney may hinder her performance. Although she refuses to see asthma as a handicap, she believes her condition is exercise-induced.

'I find the number of ath letes suffering from asthma quite shocking,' she said. 'I put it down to an increase in pollution, especially as it is mostly among those who trainin the open air.'

The World Congress on Lung Diseases in Florence yesterday heard that half of the Olympic cyclists who had competed in the 1996 Atlanta games had asthma.

British cyclist Chris Boardman said: 'I would blame it on pollution. I spend most of my life gasping for breath.'

fields.headline: Suu Kyi's roadside protest ends as police raiders go in
fields.trailText: A raid by nearly 200 Burmese riot police ended a nine-day roadside protest by the Nobel peace prizewinner Aung San Suu Kyi. The opposition leader was forced to return to her house arrest in the capital, Rangoon, ordered by the military regime.
fields.body:
A raid by nearly 200 Burmese riot police ended a nine-day roadside protest by the Nobel peace prizewinner Aung San Suu Kyi. The opposition leader was forced to return to her house arrest in the capital, Rangoon, ordered by the military regime.

Suu Kyi, 55, had been camping in a suburb of the city since her convoy of cars was prevented by police from travelling to the countryside.

fields.headline: Moscow
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: There is  to be dancing in the streets of Moscow today - but only modest displays will be permitted.
fields.body:
There is to be dancing in the streets of Moscow today - but only modest displays will be permitted. City authorities have ruled that the noisy carnival processions which traditionally weave their way to Red Square on the first Sunday of September are this year out of keeping with the national gloom, and all except the most discreet of events have been cancelled.

But while the festivities of Moscow Day (a post-Soviet attempt at institutionalised fun) have been toned down, many will be experiencing a sense of unfeigned delight. The real cause for celebration is nothing more than the passing of August. That month has taken on apocalyptic connotations. Rarely is it mentioned without being qualified by the words cursed, dreaded or damned.

August is one of the few months when Russians ought to be cheerful. The days are long, the skies more or less blue, the chances of snow slim. In recent years, however, events have been conspiring to sour the national mood. 'I feel I should be relieved to have survived the last month,' said Dennis Anelin, manager at a dealership selling expensive jeeps to Russia's new rich. 'There's been fire, there's been water. It's been catastrophic.'

The August phenomenon this year began with a powerful explosion beneath Pushkin Square, a few hundred yards from the Kremlin walls. The bomb went off at the peak of the evening rush-hour in an underground walkway, crowded with commuters and stall-holders. Eleven people were killed. Four days later on 12 August, two explosions on board the Kursk nuclear submarine sent the 118 men on board to their deaths at the bottom of the sea. The government embarked on a doomed strategy of obfuscation and scarcely had time to recover from its PR failures before it had to grapple with a new calamity. This time no attempt was made to disguise the full scale of the problem. Not even the most poker-faced of Kremlin officials could have denied the inferno at the top of the world's second tallest building, Moscow's Ostankino broadcasting tower - not least because it transformed television screens across the capital into shivering dots.

This catalogue of disasters has become such standard fare for a Russian August that few journalists dare to leave their desks for these four weeks. The same month last year saw a bomb go off in the capital's most prestigious shopping centre, by the gateway to Red Square - the first of a series of devastating, still unresolved, bomb attacks throughout the city in which more than 200 people died. Fighting began in Dagestan, precipitating the war in Chechnya, the then President Boris Yeltsin sparked an unexpected political upheaval which saw the old Prime Minister sacked and the unknown Vladimir Putin appointed in his place. The events of the year before were more debilitating still. August 1998 saw the collapse of the rouble and Russia's decision to default on its debts, prompting the disastrous destabilisation of the fragile economy as well as a new political crisis. Many recall the abortive Communist putsch of August 1991, which led to the Soviet Union's collapse.

Paper-seller Natasha Lyutin, 45, has been one of the few to benefit from the month's disasters; television's absence made newspaper sales rocket. But this did nothing to lift the former history teacher's gloom. 'What kind of country do we live in when someone like me with two university degrees is forced to stand on street corners selling newspapers? This August has been cataclysmic - but it's our entire lives that are unbearably hard.'

webTitle: Hope and tension after contact with Sierra Leone hostages

fields.headline: Hope and tension after contact with Sierra Leone hostages
fields.standfirst: Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: Negotiations with the gunmen holding six British soldiers hostage in the jungles of Sierra Leone reached crisis point last night amid tense speculation that a rescue mission is imminent.
fields.body:
Negotiations with the gunmen holding six British soldiers hostage in the jungles of Sierra Leone reached crisis point last night amid tense speculation that a rescue mission is imminent.

Although the Ministry of Defence last dismissed the rumours as unfounded, The West Side Boys, the maverick militia group who kidnapped the men eight days ago, were reportedly sticking to the harsh political demands they made at the end of last week, which are almost impossible for the Sierra Leonean government to meet.

The MoD did say, however, that 'more proactive measures' were being considered. 'We hope that negotiations will lead to the safe return of our men... but if they don't then we will obviously consider other options,' a source said.

Units of specialist soldiers, possibly from the Special Air Service, are understood to have been stationed in Sierra Leone since the first British troops arrived in May. Five soldiers released on Friday were yesterday being debriefed by the army in a bid to establish how the heavily-armed British patrol - part of a force stationed just outside the Sierra Leonese capital Freetown - were captured. Their Land Rover, complete with heavy machine guns, is reportedly being driven around by their captors.

Negotiations continue via a British army satellite phone given to 'Colonel Cambodia' - the WSB leader - last week. However, fears are growing that only military action will force the militia, loosely allied with the official Sierra Leonese government, to give up their remaining hostages.

Though the MoD stress that the men are safe and well, there are concerns about their well-being. The major leading the unit was badly beaten by the WSB - known for alcohol and drug abuse - when captured. 'It's far from an ideal situation,' said a military source. There are also increasing tensions between the United Nations peacekeepers and the British Army. British troops landed four months ago to prevent Freetown falling to the brutal Revolutionary United Front rebels after UN peacekeepers had failed. Last week both the UN and the British criticised each other.

fields.headline: Peugeot recalls 40,000 cars
fields.trailText: About 40,000 Peugeot 206s are being recalled by the French carmaker following claims that they are fitted with faulty - and possibly lethal - side airbags.
fields.body:
About 40,000 Peugeot 206s are being recalled by the French carmaker following claims that they are fitted with faulty - and possibly lethal - side airbags.

The worldwide recall follows news that a German magazine is about to publish a report that the airbags could inflate spontaneously, threatening to cause accidents. The magazine documented at least 60 cases of this happening.

'The process is already under way in some countries,' said a Peugeot spokesman. The faulty devices were fitted to 206s made between June 1999 and 14 March this year. The problem is not thought to affect the operation of the airbags in case of an accident.

Airbags are thought to have saved thousands of lives and are becoming standard features on many cars, but concerns have grown recently that they could have caused several deaths. The British government is to fund research into their safety after recent disclosures of at least two cases where motorists died after their airbags inflated.

Christella Sergi, 69, died in October, 1998, when the airbag of her Vauxhall Corsa inflated, only 10 months after Jennifer Reichardt, 47, was killed when her Rover 400 was in a head-on collision with another car.

Reichardt's father George 78, from Leicester, said the funding for the research was welcome but 'long overdue'.

'When Jennifer died we knew it was because of her airbag. At her inquest, the coroner gave an open verdict. He could not be sure it was an accident,' he said.

The recall is not the first involving faulty airbags. Ford ordered back nearly 124,000 cars in 1998.

fields.headline: RUC parts feuding loyalists
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: A massive  security operation involving hundreds of RUC officers and troops kept rival loyalists apart during a paramilitary parade through Belfast's Shankill Road area.
fields.body:
A massive security operation involving hundreds of RUC officers and troops kept rival loyalists apart during a paramilitary parade through Belfast's Shankill Road area.

Scores of army and RUC vehicles were deployed in the feud-torn loyalist stronghold during an Ulster Volunteer Force commemoration rally yesterday.

Members of the rival Ulster Defence Association were held back from thousands of UVF members and their supporters as they gathered for the annual Brian Robinson memorial march. Robinson was shot dead by an undercover army unit after carrying out a sectarian murder in nearby Ardoyne.

A line of police officers and soldiers stretched across Agnes Street, the de facto boundary between the UDA-dominated Lower Shankill and the UVF strongholds on the middle and upper part of the road.

Army vehicles were also in position across Heather Street in the Middle Shankill, in a protective cordon around a social club frequented by the UDA.

A dozen or so UDA members watched UVF members gather from comparative safety behind army lines.

The bitter loyalist in-fighting which flared at a UDA-organised band parade along the Shankill road two weeks ago has seen three people killed and several wounded including an 11-year-old girl. Seventy families have been forced from their homes.

fields.headline: Sedative drug ban for under-5s
fields.trailText: The use of Ritalin for pre-school children is to be banned, in effect, in Britain amid growing fears over the increasing use of drugs to treat hyperactivity.
fields.body:
The use of Ritalin for pre-school children is to be banned, in effect, in Britain amid growing fears over the increasing use of drugs to treat hyperactivity.

The controversial calming drug treatment for disturbed and aggressive children has been regarded by many parents as a lifeline since it was first prescribed in Britain.

Its use has grown rapidly, with the number of prescriptions tripling in the 1990s. Now the National Health Service's 'best practice' watchdog is to issue guidelines advising caution on its use for very young children.

There are concerns that the use of the medication can mask emotional or other causes of troubled behaviour. Psychiatrists have warned that toddler tantrums, for example, may be confused with more serious disorders.

Ritalin, methylphenidate, was referred by Health Secretary Alan Milburn to the National Institute for Clinical Excellence, the independent watchdog which rules on the appropriate use of drugs.

It recommends that Ritalin should not be given to under-fives. Although older children may continue to receive it, there will be clearer definitions of the conditions for which it can be beneficial as part of a specialist treatment programme.

A recent study found prescription of stimulants to American children under four, suffering from conditions including Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), increased threefold between 1991 and 1995, with the trend still rising.

Gill Mead, of ADHD Support For Families, said parents of younger children would be 'disappointed' if they were refused medication. 'Most parents start coming to us when their children first enter social situations - nursery school. The touch-paper is ignited, the minute you put them into situations that trigger anxiety,' she said.

'Some parents are very anti-medication. I can recall a sad case of two headteachers with a son diagnosed with ADHD. They said,"We don't need medication and we don't need to pump our son full of drugs" - they came back to me and said they wished they had tried drug treatment because he is now up for GBH.'

Mead firmly believes that Ritalin works, 'not only for the child but for the parents, who are given enough of a breathing space from troubled behaviour to assist the family to maintain the love for that child'.

Ministers, manufacturers and patients have a few weeks to challenge the findings before they are officially released to doctors.

webTitle: Politicans seek more information on adverse reactions to the meningitis C vaccine

fields.headline: Call for probe on meningitis death 'demands answers'
fields.trailText: Concerned politicians are pressing the Scottish Health Minister for more information on possible adverse reactions to the meningitis C vaccine after The Observer's revelations last week that parents were being denied access to statistics.
fields.body:
Concerned politicians are pressing the Scottish Health Minister for more information on possible adverse reactions to the meningitis C vaccine after The Observer's revelations last week that parents were being denied access to statistics.

New figures released last week revealed that there have been 12 associated deaths, including that of 14-year-old schoolboy footballer Keith MacGregor from Inverurie in Aberdeenshire, who died in March five days after being vaccinated.

Brian Adam, Scottish Nationalist MSP for North West Scotland and a biochemist, tabled a parliamentary question asking if there was an independent probe into Keith's death.

The question is one of six he tabled on Friday evening. Adam also asked for details of meningitis cases in Scotland this year and of the number of adverse reactions to the vaccine recorded north of the border.

He also asked where clinical trials of the vaccine were done, whether other countries approved it, and why NHS accounting procedures for the vaccine differ from standard practice.

'I have no desire to create a scare. Meningitis C is a serious source of infection and steps to reduce the risk are welcome,' said Adam. 'But we would be failing in our duties if we did not investigate as far as possible.'

Kay Ullrich, the SNP Shadow Health Minister, plans to table questions about the vaccine on Monday. She will ask whether GPs were warned not to give the vaccine to any vulnerable groups after the Medicines Control agency was told some patients who had been injected suffered heart problems and convulsions.

Factfile

What is meningitis? It is an inflammation of the meninges, or the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. It can be caused by a range of bacteria, the most notorious of which is the meningococcus, and by various viruses. Bacterial meningitis is the most serious, with symptoms including vomiting, fever and rashes, possibly resulting in death.

Victoria Beckham has the viral form of the disease

What is the new vaccine for? It covers the meningococcal Group C infection, which is responsible for four out of 10 cases of meningococcal meningitis, and is most closely associated with outbreaks among young teenagers. It is being offered to all those aged under 18 across the country. It offers no protection against the B infection.

How effective does the Government say it is? The Government said that it has cut cases by 85 per cent. Official figures show that in the 15-17-year-old group, in the past 12 weeks, six cases of the disease were reported compared with 26 in the same period last year

How effective is it really? There have been 587 cases since the beginning of the year, compared to 713 in the same period last year, a drop of 18 per cent. In London, East Anglia and the West Midlands, there has even been a rise in cases.

What are the risks? GPs have reported 16,527 adverse reactions.

fields.headline: Branson U-turn on £1m jackpot pledge
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson's bid to run the lottery faced fresh controversy last night after his consortium admitted it could scrap its guarantee to pay million-pound prizes if too many players come up with the right numbers.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson's bid to run the lottery faced fresh controversy last night after his consortium admitted it could scrap its guarantee to pay million-pound prizes if too many players come up with the right numbers.

The concession came after a senior lottery expert with close links to the National Lottery Commission said the People's Lottery could end up bankrupting the game, potentially to the tune of billions.

His explosive charge is the latest blow to the Virgin tycoon and comes as further doubts are raised over whether AWI, the US company in charge of implementing the gaming technology for Branson's consortium, can deliver the system in time.

Branson has proposed that his Millionaires game will guarantee winners a million pounds each. But informed sources say the move could backfire because too many people could end up claiming the jackpot, meaning ruinous payouts. A spokesman for the People's Lottery said last night: 'In this improbable case there is a stipulation that we won't guarantee million pound payouts. The chances of this happening are extremely remote.'

But the lottery expert said: 'I find it a remarkably risky strategy. It's no longer about winners dividing the pot. Once you start guaranteeing things, somebody has to be the guarantor.'

For the Millionaires game, players select six balls from 53 in the main lottery and buy an additional number for £1 in a supplementary draw. Anyone matching five numbers from six in the main draw and then selecting the correct ball from the additional draw is guaranteed a £1m prize. But lottery experts point out players often cluster around the same numbers. For instance, every week 40,000 people playing the current Lottery choose 7, 14, 21, 28, 35 and 42.

'If those numbers come up that would mean the lottery would have to pay out £40bn. It would go bust, it's credibility would be damaged totally and nobody would ever play it again,' the source said.

It is extremely unlikely that as many people will choose to spend an additional pound and play the Millionaires game, thus reducing the potential demand for a massive payout. And the People's Lottery Consortium has pledged to find £50m to cover up any shortfall in cash prizes. But sceptics argue it is still running a significant risk.

'The odds on lots of people winning at any one time might seem extreme, but it has happened in the UK already. In mid-February 1995 there were 123 jackpot winners and around 240 bonus ball winners. The winners got around £50,000 each from the pot. You shudder to think what would have happened if they had all been guaranteed £1m,' the source said.

A further question mark has been raised over whether AWI, the US gaming company partnering Branson's consortium - which will effectively takeover from Camelot's partner GTech - can ensure that the People's Lottery will have 36,000 online ticket terminals up and running by next September.

The Observer has seen extracts of a New York State Lottery report written in November last year, when the licence was up for grabs, which concludes that AWI had 'a weakness in the area of game design' and lacked 'sufficient internal personnel and experience'.

The New York lottery licence was subsequently re-awarded to GTech, the controversial US company responsible for Camelot losing the right to run the UK game. The state's evaluation committee concluded that AWI's plan to convert the New York lottery to its technology 'was over-optimistic based on the personnel offered by AWI'.

Last week it emerged that AWI had been fined by both the Minnesota and Maryland state governments for failing to deliver lottery systems as promised.

The committee also questioned whether AWI had the scope to run the state's lottery, arguing that it 'lacked confidence in the breadth, depth and scope of AWI's internal corporate capabilities to achieve full business potential in the future'.

Given the fact that the New York lottery operates only 14,000 terminals, the committee's findings pose further questions about whether AWI will be able to deliver a system in time.

The People's Lottery did not return calls yesterday, but its chief executive Simon Burridge has in the past expressed his confidence in AWI, pointing out his consortium had done a 'huge amount of due diligence' on the company before awarding it the contract.

webTitle: Study shows dieting middle classes drive young daughters to eating disorders

fields.headline: Parents' food fads fuel tide of obesity
fields.standfirst: Study shows dieting middle classes drive young daughters to eating disorders
fields.trailText: Girls as young as five are being driven towards obesity and eating disorders by unwitting parents desperate to prevent them becoming overweight, according to new research.
fields.body:
Girls as young as five are being driven towards obesity and eating disorders by unwitting parents desperate to prevent them becoming overweight, according to new research.

The work, to be outlined in Glasgow this week, reveals that some middle-class parents are putting pressure on their daughters to stay thin from such an early age that they develop unhealthy preoccupations with their weight by the time they start school.

With childhood obesity rising at an epidemic pace globally, the American study of five-to-nine-year-olds found that girls whose parents stopped them from eating foods they condemned as fattening were at much greater risk of suffering weight and eating problems.

They lost the ability to regulate their own food intake and, unable to understand cues from their bodies telling them whether they were hungry or not, binged on the restricted food whenever their parents were not around to stop them.

According to the researchers, it was the mothers who were most concerned about their own weight and who dieted most often who were most likely to risk their daughters' health and self-image by attempting to restrict their diet.

The studies have so far focused on affluent, white American families. Scottish doctors are now carrying out research on three to five-year-olds in Glasgow amid concerns that youngsters are developing similar problems in Britain, where obesity is about to overtake asthma as the biggest threat to child health.

Leann Birch, professor of child nutrition at Pennsylvania State University, who will outline her findings to a child nutrition conference at Glasgow University on Wednesday, told The Observer: 'Essentially, mothers who used more restriction had daughters who, in the absence of hunger, ate more snack foods when they were available. This indicated a heightened response to the presence of palatable food and a consequent reduction in the ability to regulate energy intake in response to hunger and satiety cues.' Revealingly, girls were far more likely to demonstrate this effect than boys.

The phenomenon, according to the study, appears to be connected to affluence.

While many middle-class mothers were obsessed with keeping themselves and their daughters thin, low-income parents were more concerned with feeding their children enough and so were far less likely to restrict their diet.

John Reilly, a senior lecturer in child nutrition at Glasgow University who is leading the Scottish research project, said: 'Obesity is fast becoming the single biggest child health problem in this country Clearly, it is not a good thing for five-year-olds to be preoccupied with their weight and shape.'

The research also provides startling new evidence of the extent to which young children are susceptible to notions of the ideal body shape.

The latest research shows that even the youngest girls, picking up cues from their mothers, feel under pressure to lose weight. Half of the 200 five-year-olds interviewed gave worryingly informed responses to questions about dieting and weight loss. Asked why people dieted, some responded that it was to get thin so they could 'get more dates'.

Birch said: 'We have found that these kids are are already concerned about their weight and shape and are talking about being too fat. This is behaviour you wouldn't normally expect before they reached puberty. It is horrifying.'

Sara McCluskey, a doctor at the Chrysalis Centre, a juvenile eating disorder unit in Kent, said: 'The findings are very depressing. Our society puts so much emphasis on what people look like, and children are picking that up from a younger and younger age.'

fields.headline: Police snub Blair's DNA bank
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's flagship scheme to store the genetic fingerprints of every criminal in Britain was thrown into disarray last night as it emerged police officers are refusing to co-operate.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's flagship scheme to store the genetic fingerprints of every criminal in Britain was thrown into disarray last night as it emerged police officers are refusing to co-operate.

The Prime Minister announced earlier this week that three million samples have now been collected from arrested suspects, to be matched against evidence gathered from unsolved crimes in order to unmask offenders.

But the scheme is in danger of being undermined by troubles facing its 'brother' database, which stores samples voluntarily given by police and civilian staff so that traces of their DNA unwittingly left by them at the scene of a crime can be ruled out from investigations.

Fewer than half the officers targeted by a £33 million Home Office campaign have so far come forward to give samples, although the deadline is for the end of this month.

'If we don't get the takeup, the database will be no good and we will never secure a conviction because the elimination process won't be secure,' said Dave Rodgers, vice-chair of the Metropolitan Police Federation.

'This is extremely serious. There's an element of mistrust because people think this might be used to investigate disciplinary matters.'

He said the federation believed that safeguards had been put in place to prevent officers' samples being misused. Last minute appeals have been placed in both the Metropolitan Police and Police Federation magazines urging officers to come forward.

The Met's commissioner, Sir John Stevens, even publicly donated his own DNA last week in an effort to encourage his own officers. But only 3,000 of the 15,700 targeted in the London area have volunteered.

The tests are taken with a swab from the mouth. They are stored on a separate database to those taken from criminals, and officers have been assured their samples will only be used to eliminate them from enquiries they have themselves worked on.

The DNA database has been hugely controversial because of its civil liberties implications. The pressure group Liberty has challenged its legality, and is particularly concerned that samples should be destroyed if suspects are found to be innocent.

'Police officers value their privacy as much as anyone else, so if they are reluctant to provide samples it is not really very surprising - especially if they have read the recent Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary report which found 50,000 DNA samples from members of the public were held unlawfully,' said a spokeswoman for Liberty.

A Home Office spokesman yesterday insisted that despite the low takeup rate the scheme had been a success.

fields.headline: Scottish hunt lobby in ad cash row
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: The Scottish hunting fraternity is getting financial help from big English landowners such as the Dukes of Marlborough and Westminster for a controversial £250,000 advertising campaign against moves to outlaw fox-hunting north of the border.
fields.body:
The Scottish hunting fraternity is getting financial help from big English landowners such as the Dukes of Marlborough and Westminster for a controversial £250,000 advertising campaign against moves to outlaw fox-hunting north of the border.

Anti-hunt groups have accused the Scottish Countryside Alliance of using English money because it does not have enough home-grown support for its Get The Priorities Right campaign.

The alliance has hired Media House, the public relations agency which masterminded Stagecoach tycoon Brian Souter's much-criticised 'Keep the Clause' campaign, to run the advertising blitz which is due to be launched tomorrow.

Using the same shock tactics the agency employed to embarrass the Scottish Executive over its attempts to repeal Section 28, the campaign hopes to stir up a groundswell of public opposition to the ban on hunting.

According to Countryside Alliance documents, however, the Scottish operation is completely reliant on funding from its English parent organisation. It is backed by big landowners such as the Dukes of Marlborough, Westminster and Northumberland, the meat tycoon and close friend of Prince Charles, Lord Vestey, and the Marquess of Hartington, chairman of the British Horseracing Board and the Queen's representative of Ascot.

In a letter to members seen by The Observer , David Duff, the SCA chairman, wrote: 'Over the course of this year we must become financially self-sufficient... There are currently 3,500 members of the SCA. We need at least 10,000 to cover the costs of our core programme.'

The annual report of the Countryside Alliance reveals that the cost to the parent body of establishing and running its Scottish operation - described as 'Priority A' - is £200,000 a year.

Les Ward, chairman of the Scottish Campaign Against Hunting with Dogs, told The Observer: 'With only 10 hunts in Scotland with a few hundred followers, it is obvious that this money was not raised in Scotland. We are appalled that there is an attempt to buy Scottish democracy - and not even with Scottish money. The political process cannot be bought by expensive advertising campaigns.'

Anti-hunt campaigners are also furious about the images to be used in the campaign. It will focus on depicting graphic images of poverty in Scotland and claiming that Ministers will be wasting parliamentary time banning hunting when there are more urgent issues to be addressed.

Posters will line main roads into Edinburgh from tomorrow, while an ad-van will circle the Scottish Parliament's temporary home on the mound. An ad-van will also be doing the rounds in the Glasgow Cathcart constituency of Lord Watson, the Labour MSP who is sponsoring the Bill, which this week enters a crucial phase when the rural affairs committee begins hearing evidence.

Watson said: 'This is synthetic concern from the Countryside Alliance. When have they ever spoken out on the issue of poverty? I've campaigned all my life, as a trade union official, as an MP and now as an MSP.

'If they were really concerned about poverty and deprivation, then why don't they donate the money they are spending on this campaign to the homelessness unit and the women's refuge in Glasgow? They have lost the argument on the issues and they are now desperately trying to stop the Bill.'

An independent report by the Macauley Land Use Research Institute revealed that the average wage earned by a part-time hunt employee was £2,047 a year.

'The hypocrisy of saying that poverty should be the focus of Parliament when the Scottish hunts pay their staff poverty wages is a disgrace,' said Ward. 'The huge sum they are wasting on advertising would be better spent on preparing to switch to draghunting, the humane alternative once hunting with dogs is banned, and at the same time use the money to increase wages for their staff.'

But a Media House spokesman dismissed the accusations. 'There is nothing sinister about the Scottish Countryside Alliance getting money from the Countryside Alliance. The SCA is part of the CA, they are not two separate entities. By virtue of the way it is organised, the SCA has a close relationship with the people in England but it has its own membership.'

webTitle: UN chief helped Rwanda killers arm themselves

fields.headline: UN chief helped Rwanda killers arm themselves
fields.trailText: The former Secretary-General of the United Nations, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, played a leading role in supplying weapons to the Hutu regime which carried out a campaign of genocide against the Tutsis in Rwanda in 1994.
fields.body:
The former Secretary-General of the United Nations, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, played a leading role in supplying weapons to the Hutu regime which carried out a campaign of genocide against the Tutsis in Rwanda in 1994.

As Minister of Foreign Affairs in Egypt, Boutros-Ghali facilitated an arms deal in 1990, which was to result in $26 million (£18m) of mortar bombs, rocket launchers, grenades and ammunition being flown from Cairo to Rwanda. The arms were used by Hutus in attacks which led to up to a million deaths.

The role of Boutros-Ghali, who was in charge at the UN when it turned its back on the killings in 1994, is revealed in a book by Linda Melvern.

In A People Betrayed: The Role of the West in Rwanda's Genocide, Boutros-Ghali admits his role in approving an initial $5.8 million arms deal in 1990, which led to Egypt supplying arms to Rwanda until 1992. He says he approved it because it was his job as Foreign Minister to sell weapons for Egypt.

The deal was never disclosed: the weapons were smuggled into Rwanda disguised as relief material. At the time there was an international outcry at human rights abuses by the Hutu government as thousands of Tutsi were massacred.

Asked about the wisdom of an arms deal at such a sensitive time, Boutros-Ghali said he did not think that a 'few thousand guns would have changed the situation'. His contacts with the Hutu regime have never been investigated.

webTitle: Bruton calls for Ahern action in Omagh hunt

fields.headline: Bruton calls for Ahern action in Omagh hunt
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: John Bruton, the leader of the Irish opposition, challenged the Taoiseach yesterday to exert more pressure on Sinn Fein to help catch the Omagh bombers.
fields.body:
John Bruton, the leader of the Irish opposition, challenged the Taoiseach yesterday to exert more pressure on Sinn Fein to help catch the Omagh bombers.

The Fine Gael leader said Bertie Ahern should call on Sinn Fein to ask the republican community to provide information about the Real IRA gang behind the atrocity.

Bruton also questioned why anti-terrorist legislation brought in by both the British and Irish governments had not been deployed against the Real IRA.

Addressing a meeting of the Irish Association at Belfast's Waterfront Hall, he said: 'Republicans are being advised not to give information and this has not been challenged to the degree it should have by the Taoiseach. And I also believe there are questions being asked about all the emergency powers that were put through in the wake of Omagh and why they are not being used. When the legislation was introduced the government must have felt it would be useful. If that was their position and they haven't used it then either they were wrong in their initial analysis or they are choosing not to use it.'

Sinn Fein leaders have refused to call on republican supporters to co-operate with police forces on both sides of the border searching for the Omagh bombers.

Only one person has been charged in connection with the atrocity that claimed the lives of 29 men, women and children two years ago. RUC and garda detectives working on the case know the identity of the gang that planned and carried out the attack. However, they complain that while they have detailed intelligence on the Real IRA, they have little hard evidence to convict those responsible. The inquest into the massacre will begin in Omagh on Wednesday.

Bruton also ruled out any possibility of Fine Gael entering a coalition with Sinn Fein following the next general election. 'They would have to end their links with paramilitarism before we would even consider it,' he said.

The former Taoiseach rejected unionist claims that there was no difference between Sinn Fein being in government in Northern Ireland and entering a possible coalition in the Republic.

'It is different because the Executive in Northern Ireland does not have the power over the military and police. Power is exercised in London on those matters but in the Dail the government controls policing and the military powers. Therefore no party with paramilitary links can be in that government.'

webTitle: Letters to the editor:   C4 committed

fields.headline: C4 committed
fields.trailText: I was confused by Karl Sabbagh's broadside against Channel 4 (Review, last week). The channel's Director of Programmes, Tim Gardam, has never said he is 'not interested in ideas that come from outside'
fields.body:
I was confused by Karl Sabbagh's broadside against Channel 4 (Review, last week). The channel's Director of Programmes, Tim Gardam, has never said he is 'not interested in ideas that come from outside' - last year Channel 4 transmitted programmes made by 412 independents. The channel remains absolutely committed to supporting independent suppliers, but neither every producer nor every idea can be guaranteed space in our schedules.

Michael Jackson
Chief Executive, Channel 4
London SW1

webTitle: Letters to the editor:  Not a bouncer

fields.headline: Not a bouncer
fields.trailText: Regarding the 'Nail bomber trapped by fake pen pal' article (News, 2 July), I am not a nightclub bouncer. It is a previous occupation of mine, but that was five years ago.
fields.body:
Regarding the 'Nail bomber trapped by fake pen pal' article (News, 2 July), I am not a nightclub bouncer. It is a previous occupation of mine, but that was five years ago. I am now a successful author having had three books published in three years. I have never 'fooled' or sold stories about Ronnie Kray. I have never 'fooled' or been paid for stories about the Taylor sisters. I have only received £3,000 in relation to the David Copeland case for letters which were produced as evidence. I have campaigned to prove both the innocence and guilt of many prisoners over the years at my own expense as the judicial system is something of immense interest to me.

Bernard O'Mahoney
Peterborough

webTitle: Letters to the editor: Soya slur

fields.headline: Soya slur
fields.trailText: As a healthy vegan of 10 years standing, and knowing vegans of 20 years or more, I was shocked to see soya being portrayed as the cause for practically every known modern disease by a vociferous group of detractors (Life, last week).
fields.body:
As a healthy vegan of 10 years standing, and knowing vegans of 20 years or more, I was shocked to see soya being portrayed as the cause for practically every known modern disease by a vociferous group of detractors (Life, last week). One has to ask who is bankrolling this soya research and the protagonists? If soya is as dangerous for man and beast as this research claims, why is it then the mainstay of livestock diets? A question that the anti-soya 'independent' lobby should be asking of their paymasters.

Toni Vernelli
East Grinstead
W Sussex

webTitle: Letters to the editor:  Kenya recovery

fields.headline: Kenya recovery
fields.trailText: Far from 'shirking responsibility for Kenya's woes' (World, last week), the Kenya government, with international backing, is implementing a major economic recovery programme
fields.body:
Far from 'shirking responsibility for Kenya's woes' (World, last week), the Kenya government, with international backing, is implementing a major economic recovery programme in the teeth of the worst natural disaster since independence. It is time that this was recognised.

Nancy Kirui
Kenyan High Commissioner
London W1
