fields.headline: The magic walkabout
fields.standfirst: Robert Hughes travels around Australia and is riveting. Clunes and Morrissey travel around Australia
fields.trailText: Beyond the Fatal Shore | Men Down Under | Safe as Houses | Down To Earth
fields.body:
Beyond the Fatal Shore BBC2
Men Down Under BBC1
Safe as Houses ITV
Down To Earth BBC1

On my small balcony there is a tiny but flourishing gum tree, in honour of my antipodean roots: I'm English born, of Australian parents; am, therefore, thoroughly English apart from that part of me which is somehow, oddly, Australian. This isn't, I suspect, a result of DNA as much as it is a series of Pavlovan (sic) reflexes - that's pavlova as in the fine Aussie dessert of meringue topped with fruit and whipped cream. The snapshot memories of a year spent in Australia at the age of three are my earliest: ancient, sunburnt, dusty-red earth; the bogey-cum-swagman whom I imagined lurked, waiting to grab a stray ankle, at the bottom of cattle grids; the rich lanolin stink of a freshly-sheared sheep; the sharp, heady tang of a scrunched-up dried gum leaf... 'Now what's that accent I can hear?' asked the Aussie doctor I met a few weeks back. Only an Aussie ever picks it up, but it's there.

I tell you this only so that you know how excited I was by the prospect of the first episode of Robert Hughes's portrait of Australia, Beyond the Fatal Shore. Partly because if anybody can turn 2-D TV into a scratch-and-sniff experience it is Hughes, but also because I would get the chance to ogle my home-from-home like a sad voyeur sat at the window with night-sight binoculars, waiting for people 12,000 miles across the road to provide me with a cheap vicarious thrill. To this end, with any luck, I'd get some top-quality sunset action, a bit of sexy surf, a few sensual, swooping airborne shots of the world's most beautiful modern city (that's Sydney for the record, not Canberra) and, well, blow me down, there's voyeurism - and then there's... isn't that a buck-naked Bruce having his flaccid manhood fluffed by a bodice-ripped, bare-breasted Sheila?

Given his survival of a near-fatal car crash, near Broome (which is not a place a man would want to die but a place where, without ever being involved in a crash, he may feel that he might), Hughes's journey was always going to be idiosyncratic. Suddenly chased by the spectre of his own mortality and declaring that his 'need to know Australia was stronger' as a result, Beyond the Fatal Shore evolved into a trip inside Hughes's head, providing glimpses of the Greatest Living Australian's own Dreamtime. Which, unsurprisingly, was revealed to be a place with no space for clichés, however pretty.

Hughes's definitive big Australian picture turned out to be smaller and quirkier but even better than I'd hoped. Whether visiting his old school, St Ignatius, and pinning a postcard of De Chirico's 'The Mystery and Melancholy of the Street' to a noticeboard - there perhaps to inspire a nascent art critic as he had himself been inspired as a schoolboy - or visiting the bug-ridden bush location for a porn movie (in Australia, alfresco sex is a bit like starring in a Lilliputian Walking With Dinosaurs) during which, perhaps in a bid to distract both himself and us from the sticky business at hand, he asked the appropriately journalistic but probably unanswerable question: 'So how many X-rated films get made in Australia per year?', even if you don't know your wowsers from your larrikins, Hughes has made a singularly unmissable documentary series. It's already been screened (and slated) in Australia, but Hughes has lived in the US for 35 years and his proud-but-parochial homeland has never quite forgiven him for his objectivity.

After Hughes, I was infinitely richer in spirit but still starved of the cheap Oz-porn I craved. Never mind modernity - where was the country I knew (a land described affectionately in 'The Aussie Bush IT Terminology' email that is currently doing the rounds among expats and interested pom parties, where Logging On still means heating up the barbie, Software simply refers to the plastic knives and forks you get at Red Rooster, and Search Engine is what you do when the ute won't go)? Still, who better than Martin Clunes and Neil Morrissey to pander to my baser telly instincts? Unfortunately, like men pretty much everywhere, Men Down Under suffered from an identity crisis. We were told at the top of the show that Morrissey and Clunes were there to follow the path of the Olympic flame, but it turned out they were just visiting some of the places en route. Clearly this low concept had to be beefed up a bit higher, so they were also to be going in search of the real Australian male - or just as many Les Pattersons as they could find to reinforce the cliché of a nation of men who couldn't give a collective XXXX.

It's not hard. Outside of the sophisticated cities, Australia truly is the last bastion of Bloke. So much so that Clunes and Morrissey were shown up to be a right pair of Bacardi Breezers in a world of fleshly six-packs. From Alice Springs (it may have a girl's name but, boy, it's a man's man's man's man's town) to the Birdsville races (one pub, a dirt racetrack, several thousand punters, some horses and a hangover bigger than Uluru), via the monosyllabic workforce at Mount Isa where 3,500 men (and a few women) are chased by the prospect of their mortality while plundering the world's biggest mine a mile underground ('You have to keep reminding yourself it's not a Bond set!' said an awed Morrissey), our lads found the lads they needed for their job. It was, of course, all a bit crass and sniggerly, but then crassness and sniggering are as much a part of Australia as is the sweet-scented dreamscape of dangerous beauty and transcendent light. Better book that flight.

Twenty-seven hours from my house to Sydney; 27 minutes to New Southgate. No transcendent light - no competition. But Southgate, in all its English suburban gloom, was the setting for Safe as Houses, which was billed as a one-off but as my tape arrived clearly marked 'pilot', I think we can assume it will return. The first five minutes nearly lost me but I'm glad I stuck with it. Ricky Tomlinson was a widower and butcher whose business had gone pork belly-up and was now having a ham-fisted go at sales, in which he was tutored by an arrogant young Saab-driving buppie, Gabriel - 'Black? Who's black? I haven't got time to be black!' - played by Paterson Joseph. So far, so sitcom, but this was a far darker, subtler, more writerly beast. Still, the excellent Joseph got so many of the best lines in the first half hour that I did wonder whether Tomlinson was wasting his time, but of course it turned out to be a game of two halves. 'Once upon a time I was three times the man you think you are,' shouted Tomlinson, later, from inside his beard. 'And I bet you've got the faded snaps to prove it!' retorted Joseph. Part comedy, part gentle morality tale, this was mostly, however, a surprisingly touching story about men struggling with their perceived redundancy, both professional and emotional, and had quite the sweetest final scene I can remember, in which Tomlinson tenderly slipped a pair of sparkly shoes on to his sleeping daughter's feet.

It was an excellent week for leading men who lack Brad Pitt good looks. While Tomlinson invariably gives beardies with Plasticine noses everything to play for, Warren Clarke is always good news for cuddly toad-alikes. In Down to Earth, he plays another redundant male, forced to sell his London flower shop and relocate three kids and wife, Pauline Quirke, to Devon, because 'If Only are the two saddest words in the English language'. In the country, the family trade lines like 'your DKNY shirt is on the ironing pile' for 'go and get my cow book, it's in the kitchen'. With a first episode screened over the Bank Holiday, when so many families will have returned home, reluctantly, from their own 'If Only' idylls, I think this one will run and run. Right now, with Australia still on my mind, I know the feeling.

Whether visiting his old school, St Ignatius, and pinning a postcard of De Chirico's 'The Mystery and Melancholy of the Street' to a noticeboard - there perhaps to inspire a nascent art critic as he had himself been inspired as a schoolboy - or visiting the bug-ridden bush location for a porn movie (in Australia, alfresco sex is a bit like starring in a Lilliputian Walking With Dinosaurs) during which, perhaps in a bid to distract both himself and us from the sticky business at hand, he asked the appropriately journalistic but probably unanswerable question: 'So how many X-rated films get made in Australia per year?', even if you don't know your wowsers from your larrikins, Hughes has made a singularly unmissable documentary series. It's already been screened (and slated) in Australia, but Hughes has lived in the US for 35 years and his proud-but-parochial homeland has never quite forgiven him for his objectivity. After Hughes, I was infinitely richer in spirit but still starved of the cheap Oz-porn I craved. Never mind modernity - where was the country I knew (a land described affectionately in 'The Aussie Bush IT Terminology' email that is currently doing the rounds among expats and interested pom parties, where Logging On still means heating up the barbie, Software simply refers to the plastic knives and forks you get at Red Rooster, and Search Engine is what you do when the ute won't go)? Still, who better than Martin Clunes and Neil Morrissey to pander to my baser telly instincts? Unfortunately, like men pretty much everywhere, Men Down Under suffered from an identity crisis. We were told at the top of the show that Morrissey and Clunes were there to follow the path of the Olympic flame, but it turned out they were just visiting some of the places en route. Clearly this low concept had to be beefed up a bit higher, so they were also to be going in search of the real Australian male - or just as many Les Pattersons as they could find to reinforce the cliché of a nation of men who couldn't give a collective XXXX. It's not hard. Outside of the sophisticated cities, Australia truly is the last bastion of Bloke. So much so that Clunes and Morrissey were shown up to be a right pair of Bacardi Breezers in a world of fleshly six-packs. From Alice Springs (it may have a girl's name but, boy, it's a man's man's man's man's town) to the Birdsville races (one pub, a dirt racetrack, several thousand punters, some horses and a hangover bigger than Uluru), via the monosyllabic workforce at Mount Isa where 3,500 men (and a few women) are chased by the prospect of their mortality while plundering the world's biggest mine a mile underground ('You have to keep reminding yourself it's not a Bond set!' said an awed Morrissey), our lads found the lads they needed for their job. It was, of course, all a bit crass and sniggerly, but then crassness and sniggering are as much a part of Australia as is the sweet-scented dreamscape of dangerous beauty and transcendent light. Better book that flight. Twenty-seven hours from my house to Sydney; 27 minutes to New Southgate. No transcendent light - no competition. But Southgate, in all its English suburban gloom, was the setting for Safe as Houses, which was billed as a one-off but as my tape arrived clearly marked 'pilot', I think we can assume it will return. The first five minutes nearly lost me but I'm glad I stuck with it. Ricky Tomlinson was a widower and butcher whose business had gone pork belly-up and was now having a ham-fisted go at sales, in which he was tutored by an arrogant young Saab-driving buppie, Gabriel - 'Black? Who's black? I haven't got time to be black!' - played by Paterson Joseph. So far, so sitcom, but this was a far darker, subtler, more writerly beast. Still, the excellent Joseph got so many of the best lines in the first half hour that I did wonder whether Tomlinson was wasting his time, but of course it turned out to be a game of two halves. 'Once upon a time I was three times the man you think you are,' shouted Tomlinson, later, from inside his beard. 'And I bet you've got the faded snaps to prove it!' retorted Joseph. Part comedy, part gentle morality tale, this was mostly, however, a surprisingly touching story about men struggling with their perceived redundancy, both professional and emotional, and had quite the sweetest final scene I can remember, in which Tomlinson tenderly slipped a pair of sparkly shoes on to his sleeping daughter's feet. It was an excellent week for leading men who lack Brad Pitt good looks. While Tomlinson invariably gives beardies with Plasticine noses everything to play for, Warren Clarke is always good news for cuddly toad-alikes. In Down to Earth, he plays another redundant male, forced to sell his London flower shop and relocate three kids and wife, Pauline Quirke, to Devon, because 'If Only are the two saddest words in the English language'. In the country, the family trade lines like 'your DKNY shirt is on the ironing pile' for 'go and get my cow book, it's in the kitchen'. With a first episode screened over the Bank Holiday, when so many families will have returned home, reluctantly, from their own 'If Only' idylls, I think this one will run and run. Right now, with Australia still on my mind, I know the feeling.

webTitle: Rolls-Royce is trying to dig its way out of the doldrums

fields.headline: Aero without the bubbles
fields.standfirst: Rolls-Royce is trying to dig its way out of the doldrums, says Oliver Morgan
fields.trailText: Rolls-Royce is trying to dig its way out of the doldrums.
fields.body:
'Don't laugh,' said a veteran industry observer last week as he reflected on the latest vicissitudes of one of Britain's most famous and venerable 'old-economy' concerns. 'This company is like what a successful dotcom will be in five to 10 years.'

The company's name? Rolls-Royce, the aero-engine, marine and energy engineering group.

Is this an absurd attempt to attract attention to a once-mighty British national champion in an ignored and undervalued sector? No, maintains the analyst, Sandy Morris of ABN Amro. Rolls-Royce may have been as good as giving away its main product [the Trent aero engine], but it has created a high-value product and has a guaranteed subscriber base in future. 'It now has nearly 60,000 engines out there, which will be needing maintenance and repairs. And this is a subscriber base that won't churn.'

Maybe. But a less flattering comparison with dotcoms is Rolls's ability to burn cash in the scramble for market share. Rolls has poured money into developing and discounting its Trent engines to grab 35 per cent of the civil aircraft engine market and lucrative maintenance work down the line.

So, despite being profitable, cashflow has been gobbled up by development costs. And the shares have been uninspiring - Rolls has underperformed the market by 50 per cent in the last five years.

Another similarity with dotcoms is the difficulty management has had in explaining the logic behind the company, and its propensity for springing nasty surprises. Last month Rolls shed 22 per cent off its shares - seeing them slump to below their 1987 privatisation price of £1.70 - after chairman Sir Ralph Robins and chief executive John Rose issued a profits warning and abandoned their aspiration to deliver double-digit earnings growth.

The Rolls announcement was bungled. The Financial Times's influential Lex column remarked: 'There is no reason why Rolls-Royce should do such an awful job of telling investors what is going on.'

Rolls' management was also in the firing line last year when it unveiled a lightning deal to buy the marine and defence group Vickers for £576 million - a 53 per cent premium. Analysts didn't like the surprise, nor did they immediately take to the assets Rolls acquired - an ill-fitting defence business and a marine propulsion operation.

Rolls chief executive John Rose sees it differently. He could not spread the news earlier because Rolls was in its closed period, and it only became aware of all the problems in early August.Asked whether targeting double-digit growth was making a rod for the company's back, he admitted: 'Yes, but we all have PhDs in hindsight. It was important to show we believed we could still increase profits with a heavy R&D programme.' Profits he insist, will grow again from 2002.

The uncharitable old hands of British industry will mutter that this is yet another example of problems going back decades. Roll-Royce, a beloved name in Britain's industrial pantheon, has disappointed investors and Ministers for decades. Its nadir came in 1971, when it had to be bailed out by the Heath government. The reason is haunting for investors in modern Rolls. The company - which then included the auto manufacturer - spent fortunes developing the Trent's predecessor, the RB211 aero engine, to win business from US competitors General Electric and Pratt & Whitney on aircraft made by Boeing and the then fledgling Airbus.

Rolls was investigated by the Government's Industrial Organisation Committee, which expressed concern about the RB211 development draining cash, and Rolls' preference for engineering over financial control.

Warnings were loftily ignored. The Heath government gave £42m to the RB211 programme. This was not enough, and receivers were called in in February 1971. The Government was forced to nationalise it - floating off the car manufacturer shortly afterwards.

In state hands throughout the Seventies, Rolls concentrated on developing the RB211 to compete for market share, and flirted with alliances with GE and Pratt & Whitney.

After privatisation in 1987, Rolls won business from Airbus and Boeing, most recently in last week's important order by the giant International Lease Finance Corporation for the Airbus A3XX superjumbo, on which ILFC has specified Trent engines.

But that good news has not stopped City disquiet. Double-digit growth was undermined in part because of the unexpected end of service for around 100 Tri Star and other aircraft which are powered by the RB211 - taking a nasty chunk out of the high-margin repair and maintenance work upon which profitability and cashflow is largely dependent.

Alongside this came problems with the industrial variant of Trent, used to produce energy, which fell foul of emissions standards.

Experts believe the problems for Rolls are bound up with the business model. Cut-throat competition between the three big players means that if engines are not given away free - as GE and Pratt & Whitney have claimed about former Rolls deals with buyers such as Singapore Airlines - then they have been deeply discounted by up to 80 per cent of the estimated $10m price. With a development cost of around $2 billion for Trent, plus other R&D spending throughout the group, this does violence to the balance sheet. Morris says: 'There is huge investment up front. The problem for Rolls as opposed to, say, a telecoms company is that the paybacks in aerospace are so long-term - up to 30 years.'

This is all very well if the second part of the Rolls business model works: reaping the 60 per cent plus margins from maintenance work. But at best this is 10 years away. At worst planes can be retired early - as were the Tristars - or development costs for future projects can cancel out the benefits from repair work.

But Rose insists the future is brighter. The average age of planes with R-R engines is getting younger - from nine years to 8.5 years, with a 2005 target of eight years - meaning more maintenance work before planes are taken out of service.

Rolls'US competitors, particularly Jack Welsh's GE, have acted to break this cycle by offering leasing packages to airlines, which spreads purchase and maintenance costs in payments over the life of the engine. Rolls has tried to deal with these problems by spreading the risk and investment on development with partners, and it now has a complicated and obscure web of relationships, which it claims brought in £156m in the first half of this year.

Bigger questions exist over Rolls' partnership options. Some observers can see the sense in the Vickers deal as the specialist shipping market is due to grow by 8 to 12 per cent.Vickers gives Rolls the ability to go to shipping operators and offer complete propulsion systems rather than simply engines.

But a question hangs over what it will do with the Vickers defence business, whose value lies in its order book. With a full one it could fetch up to £150m, but digging Rolls out of the doldrums will need something bolder.

The biggest questions hang over aero-engines. 'The only sensible acquisitions it could make here would be independent repair and maintenance shops,' says one analyst. 'Unfortunately GE and Pratt & Whitney have stolen a march, and there is not much left to buy.' Rolls has had to go into partnerships with engineers - such as in Singapore and Hong Kong - building greenfield facilities.

Rolls could itself be a takeover target. But a partnership, most likely with Pratt & Whitney, would make more sense. This was rumoured at the turn of the year, when the European Commission let it be known it would not be happy about the competition implications, and the effect on prices - the only rationale for the link. So that looks unlikely.

In the absence of a big deal, the company desperately needs to explain itself better. Sandy Morris concludes: 'The thing is that everyone wants this bloody thing to succeed so much and they get so frustrated when things don't go just right.'

More, at least, than can be said for dotcoms.

Rolls-Royce powers through the decades

1884: Henry Royce sets up electrical and engineering company FH Royce

1904: Royce builds his first car, meets car dealer Charles Rolls

World War One: Royce designs the Eagle, Rolls-Royce's first aero engine

World War Two: Rolls-Royce Merlin engines power Hurricane and Spitfire fighters as well as Lancaster bombers. 160,000 engines produced, launching Rolls-Royce into the major league of aero engine manufacture

1944: Rolls-Royce engines power Britain's first jet fighter - the Gloster Meteor

1948: Viscount airliner fitted with Dart gas-turbine engines

1954: The 'flying bedstead', first non-helicopter vertical take off aircraft powered by Rolls-Royce engines

1966: Rolls-Royce merges with Bristol Siddeley, consolidating UK aero engine manufacture

1969: Harrier jump jet enters service, powered by Pegasus engines

1970s: Rolls-Royce enters partnership with Pratt & Whitney on engine development - abandoned in 1977

1971: Problems with RB211 bring Rolls-Royce first into receivership then into state ownership

1973: Rolls-Royce motor car business floated as separate business

1984: Partnership with General Electric but agreement terminated two years later

1987: Rolls-Royce plc privatised

1995: Acquires leading US engineer Allison

1999: Buys Vickers

fields.headline: Granada to sell Forte hotels
fields.trailText: Granada Compass, the television and catering giant, is set to put its hotels up for sale following a strategic review. The sale of the Posthouse, Le Meridien and Heritage chains, which could fetch more than £3 billion, marks a U-turn following intense pressure from City institutions.
fields.body:
Granada Compass, the television and catering giant, is set to put its hotels up for sale following a strategic review. The sale of the Posthouse, Le Meridien and Heritage chains, which could fetch more than £3 billion, marks a U-turn following intense pressure from City institutions.

It means the unravelling of one of the most bitter takeover battles of the Nineties: Granada's £3.8bn hostile takeover of Forte in 1996.

The group was formed from the surprise £17.5bn merger of Gerry Robinson's Granada and Francis Mackay's Compass last May. Since then it has spun off 20 per cent of Granada Media and is due to demerge the rest next spring.

At the time of the merger, the group said it was committed to keeping the hotels, Britain's biggest chain with a turnover of nearly £1bn. Since then, however, its share price has suffered as the City sees fast-growing catering activities as more attractive than cyclical hotels.

'The action will happen after the hospitality demerger next year,' one source close to Granada Compass said. 'Posthouse will be first. It's at the tough end and Granada had been trying to flog it for years. The big one is Meridien, which will take longer.'

The group is also selling its Signature group of four Lon don hotels, the Cavendish, Strand Palace, Cumberland and Regent Palace. The Cavendish is currently under offer for £65 million from a private buyer, industry sources say.

The hotels business had net assets of £2.6bn last year, but this includes the 195 budget Travelodge roadside hotels, which Granada Compass intends to keep for now.

Analysts estimate the mid-market Posthouse chain could fetch around £1bn, with Whitbread or Accor of France as potential buyers. The 47- strong Heritage chain of coaching inns could be worth over £300m and would also be of interest to Whitbread.

Le Meridien is the most valuable part of the division, comprising 125 luxury hotels with 32,000 rooms around the world. Of these, 37 hotels are owned and the rest managed or franchised.

Analysts estimate they could fetch more than £2bn. Hilton has already indicated an interest in buying Meridien, City sources say, and other possible bidders include Bass, Starwood, Carlson, Hyatt and Marriott.

'A sale of the hotels would definitely be positive for the shares,' said analyst Tony Shepard at broker Charles Stanley. 'There's no convincing logic of any synergy.'

There has also been backstage rivalry between Robinson and Mackay over who got the best of the merger.

webTitle: Dividend cut deepens gloom over Corus

fields.headline: Dividend cut deepens gloom over Corus
fields.trailText: Beleagured steel group Corus, the former British Steel, will this week slash its dividend in half because of bleak trading conditions exacerbated by the strength of sterling.
fields.body:
Beleagured steel group Corus, the former British Steel, will this week slash its dividend in half because of bleak trading conditions exacerbated by the strength of sterling.

Analysts are expecting an interim payout of between 1p and 1.5p to be declared on Tuesday, with a 4.5p payout at the year end.

That compares with the 10p dividend, which British Steel declared before it formed Corus with Dutch partner Hoogovens. A combined pro forma payout from both would have totalled 7.7p last year.

Erik Sardaine of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson says there is no hope of Corus paying out 6p for the year, with 2p coming at interims. 'That would be far too high,' he said.

On top of exchange-rate difficulties, analysts are predicting difficult global trading conditions next year, with high output from US and Japanese producers and record US inventories. Jeremy Fletcher of CSFB estimates a further 2,000 UK job losses next year to add to the 4,000 already announced this year.

Sardaine estimates profits for the first six months to June of virtually zero, but Fletcher thinks a £65 million loss in the last three months will take the half-year loss to around £40m.

Corus - which is almost certain to be ejected from the FTSE 100 this month - will point to recent rises in the prices for some steel products.

fields.headline: In vino veritas
fields.standfirst: The standard of wine-label blurb is lamentably low. So, skip the formulaic hype and trust your own palate
fields.trailText: The standard of wine-label blurb is lamentably low. So, skip the formulaic hype and trust your own palate.
fields.byline: Best cellars Four red-hot Sauvignon Blancs  Illustration Frazer Hudson
fields.body:
'Oh, man, what do I write this time?' I can still remember the winemaker's anguished expression as he looked up from his desk. He'd been told to come up with a dozen back labels by lunchtime, and he was struggling like a man wading through porridge. Once upon a time, being a winemaker began and ended with the stuff in the bottle; nowadays you have to be a copywriter too.

Not a very good one, mind you. Most back labels are virtually interchangeable; wit and insight are rare. Believe me, reading a few hundred examples is mind-bendingly tedious. You long for a little honesty, a tasting note couched in the style of Roy Brooks, the estate agent who developed a reputation for telling the truth. 'This vintage was a total bummer. It never stopped raining, the grapes were in terrible condition and our assistant winemaker consumed industrial quantities of Prozac. But, what do you know, we still managed to make something drinkable. Enjoy!'

To keep my spirits up, I concocted a composite back label, suitable for any New World red. 'The grapes for this hand-crafted (fill in variety) were harvested before dawn from sun-kissed vineyards in the foothills of the world-famous (fill in location) region, where a combination of warm days, cool nights and free-draining soils produces wines with rare finesse. This truly outstanding wine is the result of skilful winemaking. It is rich and complex with velvety tannins and a luscious vanilla undertone from ageing in prime French oak. Ideal with meat, pasta, pizza, cheese, curries, fish and vegetarian dishes, it is also enjoyable before or after a meal. Stored horizontally, this wine will age indefinitely. Phil Blanks (BSc, Oenology).'

Who is to blame for all this verbiage? Sometimes it's the winemaker himself, anxious to share every detail of what he gets up to in the cellar; but, more often, it's the winery owner or his cynical marketing department. The conviction out there is that the more information you give the consumer - however bland, erroneous or sanitised - the more likely he (or more commonly she) is to buy your product. This is particularly true of New World back labels, many of which are pointless: one part chemistry lab to two parts holiday brochure.

Back labels can serve a useful purpose, giving us details of grape varieties and region of origin as well as some idea of what to expect when we pull the cork. But I agree with Helen McGinn of Tesco when she says, 'We don't need a description of the grower's left armpit to find out what a wine tastes like.' Come to think of it, I don't think we need food and wine recommendations either. Why not let the customer decide? I'm a great fan of the back label I saw in California on a bottle from Sean Thackeray last year. 'This red wine,' it pointed out with a seemingly straight face, 'goes well with the sorts of things red wines go well with.'

This is my second favourite back label of all time. My favourite, written by the Polish-American painter 'Big' Frank Chludinski for his Vin de Pays Deep Pink Rosé (£3.99, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up, Victoria Wine) goes as follows: 'I'm fed up with writing the normal pile of rubbish. Yes, we picked it when the grapes were ripe. Yes, we fermented it at low temperatures. Yes, it's great with fish, barbecues and red meats. My wife likes it with chocolate mousse_ but that's her problem. I'm afraid the only way to decide if you like my Deep Pink is to buy a bottle, take it home, pull out the cork and drink it.'

I don't know about you, but this is one piece of advice that I'm more than happy to follow.

Best cellars

1999 Firefinch Sauvignon Blanc
(£3.99, Tesco).
I'm not sure how the eccentric Abrie Bruwer manages to produce Sauvignon this good in the heat of the Cape, but this full-flavoured, gooseberry-and-green-bean style white is great value at under £4.

1999 Terra Mater Estates Sauvignon Blanc, Select Cuvée, Casablanca Valley
(£5.99, Safeway).
Chilean Sauvignon Blanc is not always the genuine article - it is frequently inferior Sauvignonasse - but this honeyed, weighty, tropical, fruity example shows how well the grape can perform in the Casablanca Valley.

1999 Pouilly-Fumé Chatelain
(£8.49, Waitrose).
A modern, stainless-steel fermented Loire Sauvignon Blanc showing the smoky, minerally aromas and taut, grassy, knife-edge flavours that are so typical of Pouilly-Fumé. Textbook stuff.

1999 Villa Maria Reserve Sauvignon Blanc, Wairau Valley
(£9.99, Wine Rack; Bottoms Up; Safeway; Unwins; selected branches of Victoria Wine; Tesco).
One of a number of excellent Sauvignons produced by the winemakers at Villa Maria in the Wairu Valley region, this is among New Zealand's best whites. Classic gooseberry and grapefruit characters are underpinned both by its zesty acidity and its stony complexity.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: It started out as a bet after she was made redundant, but when Lisa Jewell started emailing the chapters of her novel to Yasmin Boland, it inspired her friend to start writing, too. Now, they are two of Chick Lit's rising stars
fields.trailText: It started out as a bet after she was made redundant, but when Lisa Jewell started emailing the chapters of her novel to Yasmin Boland, it inspired her friend to start writing, too. Now, they are two of Chick Lit's rising stars.
fields.body:
Lisa Jewell: I was made redundant from a job as a PA in a shirt-making company in 1996. I was devastated. I had been there for three years and it was a job I really liked. Before I left, I had met Jascha, the man who was to become my husband, and through him a big gang of friends, including Yasmin, an Australian journalist working in London.

Ten of us went off to Malta and stayed in a large villa. We were all reading High Fidelity at the time, passing it around and remarking how easy it must have been to write it. That was stupid, I realise that now. Nick Hornby's a genius. Very late one night, Yasmin and I had a few drinks and got talking about life. She asked me what I was going to do about my life now that I was jobless.

I'd planned to sign on with some temping agencies. But she challenged me about what I really wanted to do. I confessed that I'd like to write a female version of High Fidelity.

It was before the 'chick lit' thing happened, and I honestly thought you had to have loads of life experience and depth of character to do it. There weren't any young female writers - even Bridget Jones's Diary wasn't a phenomenon at that point.

Yasmin pointed out that Jascha had a computer, I had £1,000 redundancy money and I didn't have to start temping for a month.

Why didn't I just do it? Speaking to my stomach, she said, 'I'll take you out to your favourite restaurant if you do it, and if you don't, then you have to take me.'

So I started the next Monday morning. I tried to write about my first marriage in a fictional version, but got two pages into it and realised it was too personal. Then I came up with an old-fashioned love triangle, which became the plot for Ralph's Party.

I wrote three chapters and thought it was a pile of shit, but as I'd promised Yasmin, and she kept telling me it was so good, I thought I'd better send it out. I sent it to 10 agents and got nine rejection letters. Then I got a letter from Judith, who was to become my agent, saying it needed a lot more work, but she'd like to see the rest of it.

I was too broke to pay rent so Jascha invited me to move in with him. Yasmin moved back to Sydney, so I started emailing Yasmin each chapter as it was finished. A year later, Ralph's Party was complete, I was offered a £120,000 two-book deal, got a great meal and my life changed altogether.

Yasmin Boland: When I first met Lisa I was a little wary. She was still married to her first husband and I was worried that my friend Jascha was going to be a transitional relationship to get her out of her marriage. But I slowly realised she was serious about him.

In fact, it was their wedding that brought me to London last month and that trip also resulted in me signing my own UK book deal.

It's so strangely organic, the way our lives have connected. When we first made the bet, I thought, Yeah everyone wants to write a novel. By chapter five, I thought, Oh my god, she's writing a book! I live in Bondi and I have a nice balcony overlooking the beach. Whenever the next installment came, I'd make a big ceremony of it. I'd print it out, sit on the balcony with a cup of tea, and devour it.

Fiction-wise, I'd only ever written one short story - I have a weekly astrology column and also write about feng shui and health - but I thought, I'm going to do this, too. It wasn't a competitive thing, Lisa just inspired me. So I started on my own book, a New Age romance called Carole King is an Alien. Lisa was about six months ahead of me and every time she managed to do something it showed me that it was possible. Her finishing her book spurred me on. Our relationship is very symbiotic. Lisa's much more a first-time-right writer, whereas I'd make 72 rewrites.

Lisa finishing her book was also 'truth time'. I thought, Bloody hell, I hope I'm not the only one who likes this book because I would have falsely raised her expectations. Then it came out and sold 200,000 copies, and I was so relieved I hadn't misled her.

I don't think I'd have got to the end of my book if it hadn't been for Lisa saying, 'Keep going, keep going.' We talk at length about our stories - Lisa helps me focus on the psychology of my characters.

When Lisa came to Sydney for my book launch in March, it was like completing the circle. We even did a novel workshop. We sat in the flat one night and went through all the problems we were having on the current books we were writing. I was the journalist, but it was Lisa who has helped open up a whole new aspect of writing.

fields.headline: Centrica targets 3m BT customers
fields.trailText: Centrica, with interests from energy to roadside repairs, will tomorrow launch its telecoms strategy in a bid to poach a tenth of British Telecom's 28.5 million fixed-line customers.
fields.body:
Centrica, with interests from energy to roadside repairs, will tomorrow launch its telecoms strategy in a bid to poach a tenth of British Telecom's 28.5 million fixed-line customers.

The new telecoms service is expected to give discounts to customers of as much as 25 per cent compared with BT.

Centrica is looking to win 3 million customers for services including fixed line and mobile options as well as an Internet package. It will be the latest in a long line of utilities - including National Grid and Scottish Power - looking to tap into higher growth opportunities in the telecoms sector. The service will be offered through Centrica's British Gas subsidiary and added to a range of 'home products' from gas and electricity supply to central heating installation and home insurance.

Centrica has already proved that it is effective at winning customers by undercutting existing suppliers - at its interim results announcement on Thursday it is expected to announce that it has won 3 million electricity customers from regional supply companies.

Its strategy is to target higher-value customers to maximise revenues. Analysts expect it will aim to capture customers whose bills are 50 per cent above the average £230 a year - targeting £300 as an average annual bill.

Centrica has lined up Cable and Wireless and Kingston Communications as partners, along with Vodafone Airtouch for its mobile offering. Analysts are expecting chief executive Roy Gardner to unveil strong first-half results, buoyed by high demand for gas at interim results to be presented on Thursday. Demand was improved by the opening of a gas interconnector to Europe allowing Centrica to take advantage of higher spot prices. Simon Flowers at Merrill Lynch points to profits before tax of £334 million - up 53 per cent on interims last year, with earnings per share at 8.4p.

fields.headline: Ginger nut
fields.standfirst: Forget the sickly sweet supermarket ginger beers. A small bottle of Fentimans gets Sybil Kapoor rooting for more
fields.trailText: Forget the sickly sweet supermarket ginger beers. A small bottle of Fentimans gets Sybil Kapoor rooting for more.
fields.body:
I have a confession to make: I am a closet ginger beer drinker - one of a select band who have had to suffer in silence at our favourite brew's slow decline into sickly sweetness. Recently, however, I noticed an intriguing brown-glass bottle on the supermarket shelves. It was labelled as Fentimans botanically brewed ginger beer. I couldn't resist. I poured myself a cold glass and sniffed. My nostrils burned from its peppery effervescence. I took a cautious sip. My mouth filled with a tingling lemony-ginger fluid that made me want to gulp it down. I resisted. This was too good to hurry.

Not recognising the name, and feeling a little suspicious of its 'traditional' claims, I decided to investigate further. It seems that Eldon Robson, the current managing director - his mother is a Fentiman - restarted the family company in 1994 (the original business closed in the 70s, unable to compete with the supermarkets). Robson, meanwhile, realised that the drinks market was moving towards natural, herbal ingredients and very sensibly took another look at the old family recipe.

The dried Chinese ginger root was milled before being simmered in water in sealed copper vats to release its flavour. Sugar, lemon juice, brewer's yeast and cream of tartar were then added to create a mildly alcoholic, slightly erratic brew, prone to occasional explosions if not bottled in thick, glass flagons. Clearly it still needed some work.

He added a little chilli to enhance the natural heat of the ginger, and some extract of yarrow, juniper and speedwell. 'It's the brewer's yeast, capsicum and lemon that give it the full-bodied flavour,' says Robson, 'along with the powdery ginger sediment you find in the bottle.' He then made it more stable by pasteurisation, and reduced the alcohol content so it could be sold as a soft drink.

Now, it seems, the deliciously intense taste of Fentimans is fast becoming a must-have mixer in London's cocktail bars. You may find yourself sipping it in a Pimm's cocktail or a Dark and Stormy, with some rum and lime. Not quite what the Victorians intended, but who cares when it tastes so good.

fields.headline: Five of the best...
fields.standfirst: From grouse to girolles, September brings a bounty of fresh flavours
fields.trailText: From grouse to girolles, September brings a bounty of fresh flavours.
fields.body:
Never mind the Glorious Twelfth: the good thing about September, according to chef David Cavalier, is that the price of grouse goes down. It's true - you would have to be a very grand restaurant indeed to put them on the menu in August, when they still cost £25 per bird. Cavalier has other reasons to rejoice in the season, too: after some years closeted in the private club, Mosimann's, the former star of Cavalier's, L'Escargot and Chapter One is back in a high-street restaurant, 'exposed to the glare of the critics' at the brand new High Holborn, 95-96 High Holborn, London WC1 (020 7404 3338). The challenge fills him with enthusiasm. 'And it's a great time,' he says. 'I love September because you have all the summer vegetables and the late berries, as well as the game and mushrooms of autumn.'

Not everyone loves game, of course. I remember with shame the time a kindly old gentleman along the road gave me some grouse he had shot. Thrilled and bemused, I hung them from the fire escape outside my flat, bringing them in a week later to rip the feathers off over the bath. This resulted in torn skin and the release of a thoroughly putrid smell. I ended up stuffing the precious gamebirds in the bin and slinking off to Selfridges to buy my dinner.

A better way to participate in the harvest season might have been to rent an apple tree. Several growers around Britain now run such a scheme, including Lathcoats Farm, Beehive Lane, Galleywood, Chelmsford, Essex (01245 266 691), where £10 per annum guarantees you 13kg of fruit from your chosen tree of any variety (if nature's bounty falls short, the weight is made up with apples from the farm's own orchards). The farm has 40 varieties of apple in all, but the most popular is Cox's, followed by Gala, then Lord Lambourne and Bramley's.People travel from miles around to pick the sweet, bluey-green plums known as Marjorie's Seedling at Clive's Fruit Farm, Upton-upon-Severn, Worcesterhire (01684 592 664). Jane Clive reports that Cropper plums, a cooking variety 'with a twang' is also eaten raw by people who like their fruit with a bit of a zing, but the great thing here is the farmer's own recipe book, Let's Get Fruity, which features every sort of fruit sold through PYO and the farm shop. The recipes are for whole meals, from glazed duck with plums to a wholesome Germanic apple cake with crumbly topping.

The Clives, like the Simkins of Essington Fruit Farm, Bognop Road, Essington, near Wolverhampton (01902 735 724), also take their produce to the people by attending local farmers' markets. Essington Fruit Farm gladdens the hearts of squash lovers at this time of year with its colourful range of Cucurbita. There are te green-skinned, grapefruit-sized Rolet, he golden onion squashes, the football-sized pumpkins whose names - Spellbound and Ghostrider, for example - give a clue to their ultimate, Hallowe'en use, and the small Pie Star or Crown Prince, which are green outside, orange within and have a distinct, nutty flavour. They are not at all expensive, from 50p to £. Mr Simkin gives out his sister's pumpkin soup recipe with every one.

It's hard to imagine a two Michelin-starred chef gathering his own ingredients, but Martin Blunos of Lettonie, 35 Kelston Road, Bath (01225 446 676), likes nothing better than to do spot of elderberry picking. He makes his own jewel red, elderberry vinegar. Blunos's parents are from Latvia, and he thinks it's a crying shame to hollow out a jack o' lantern without turning the flesh into a uxurious pumpkin pie ('squash tart'), which would light up anyone's evening.

There are te green-skinned, grapefruit-sized Rolet, he golden onion squashes, the football-sized pumpkins whose names - Spellbound and Ghostrider, for example - give a clue to their ultimate, Hallowe'en use, and the small Pie Star or Crown Prince, which are green outside, orange within and have a distinct, nutty flavour. They are not at all expensive, from 50p to £. Mr Simkin gives out his sister's pumpkin soup recipe with every one. It's hard to imagine a two Michelin-starred chef gathering his own ingredients, but Martin Blunos of Lettonie, 35 Kelston Road, Bath (01225 446 676), likes nothing better than to do spot of elderberry picking. He makes his own jewel red, elderberry vinegar. Blunos's parents are from Latvia, and he thinks it's a crying shame to hollow out a jack o' lantern without turning the flesh into a uxurious pumpkin pie ('squash tart'), which would light up anyone's evening.

fields.headline: Low life, high risk
fields.standfirst: Low tar, low alcohol, low fat... it's time we took manufacturers' claims with a pinch of salt (low sodium, of course). Helen Foster reports
fields.trailText: Low tar, low alcohol, low fat... it's time we took manufacturers' claims with a pinch of salt (low sodium, of course). Helen Foster reports
fields.body:
When it comes to the pursuit of a healthier lifestyle, there are, apparently, many ways in which we can have our cake and eat it. The proliferation of products that come with a 'low' prefix means that low-fat foods, low-tar cigarettes and low-alcohol drinks are all out there to be consumed with impunity - or so we believe. Yet one of these products has just been banned and others may not be as beneficial as you think.

Cigarettes

By 2003, you will no longer be able to smoke a Marlboro Light, Silk Cut Ultra Low or any other low-tar cigarette in the UK. The European Commission has banned these terms from being used, seeing them as misleading, given that the reduction in health risks that 'low-tar' cigarettes offer over their counterparts is negligible. 'The fact is, many consumers don't realise this is a con,' says Clive Bates, director of ASH (Action on Smoking and Health).

Low-tar cigarettes do not use different ingredients from high tar - there's no such thing as tar-free tobacco, for example. Instead, the tar level is lowered using filters inserted into the cigarette's end which trap tar as the smoke is drawn through. Very low-tar products further ventilate the filter with tiny holes that dilute the smoke even more. So, while a normal Benson & Hedges cigarette yields 12mg of tar in laboratory tests (where a machine smokes the cigarette and measures the tar produced), a low-tar cigarette yields just 1mg - dramatically reducing its potentially carcinogenic effects. 'The trouble is that people aren't machines in laboratories,' says Dr Martin Jarvis from the Imperial Cancer Research Campaign. 'People smoke cigarettes to get nicotine, and this is cut along with the tar in a filtered cigarette. Therefore, to ensure that they still get the level their body "needs", smokers change the way they smoke low-tar brands.'

How they do this varies, and is often determined by the brand they smoke. Those smoking 'light' cigarettes (which rely primarily on the filter action alone) tend to take more puffs per cigarette than average, or inhale more deeply, thereby increasing the amount of nicotine that gets through the filter intact. With ultra-low brands that use ventilation filters, smokers physically block the holes with their fingers or lips - in one trial, 76 per cent of cigarettes showed evidence of this. The end result is that the smokers take in far more tar than the companies calculate. In fact, in a previous test carried out by The Observer together with ASH in 1998, the average yield from a low-tar cigarette (a Silk Cut Ultra) smoked with the filter holes blocked, was 12mg of tar - exactly the same as a Benson & Hedges Special Filter.

'The result is that you're just as likely to die from smoking a low-tar cigarette as a normal one,' says Clive Bates. 'Which is bad news for all those people who decided that instead of quitting smoking, they'd switch to a low-tar brand. And we know there are thousands of them out there.'

Alcohol

Since his recent Priory visit, Ronnie Wood has reportedly been spotted nursing a bottle of Kaliber, which, according to Dr Abdulla Badawa, consultant clinical biochemist at Cardiff's Whitchurch Hospital, is no bad thing. 'Alcohol-free and low-alcohol drinks are certainly better for you than alcoholic drinks,' he says. 'Alcohol is toxic for our body. Even the slightly protective effect it gives our heart is cancelled out by the negative benefits it produces in the rest of the body. Therefore, anything you can do to reduce someone's alcohol intake is a good thing - and these products do that.'

In general, alcohol-free beer contains less than 0.05 per cent alcohol per volume. This means a pint doesn't even register on the scale of 'healthy units' - and explains why Ronnie isn't breaking any rehab rules. Low-alcohol beers do contain alcohol - between 0.5 and 1.2 per cent per serving. However, normal beer ranges from 3 to 11 per cent, so to reach alcohol levels even close to two pints of beer, you'd have to consume 10 standard-sized cans of 1.2 per cent low-alcohol beer. So far so good. Low-alcohol wines are slightly different, however. To earn the title, a wine only has to be at the lower end of the alcohol limit for wine - normally around 12 per cent. While products such as brand leader Eisberg are technically alcohol free (ie, levels are so low as to be negligible), according to Alcohol Concern other 'low-alcohol' wines can be as much as 5 per cent, which equates to just under 1 unit per average pub measure. Three or four could therefore see you getting close to the legal limit before driving.

Problems also occur if you switch to low-alcohol drinks after drinking regular alcohol. Studies by Dr Badawa and his team at Cardiff found that men who'd consumed enough alcohol to leave them just under the legal limit for driving (normally two to three pints of beer) went over that limit after just half a pint of 1.2 per cent low-alcohol lager consumed on top. 'It's a mistake to think that switching to low-alcohol lager when you are near your alcohol limit for driving is a reliable way to stay within the law,' Badawa says. And the danger is even greater for women, who don't metabolise alcohol as well. Badawa therefore recommends that drivers stick purely to low-alcohol drinks - or switch to soft drinks after one or two alcoholic ones. His choice would be orange juice, as the natural sugar increases the speed at which you metabolise the alcohol drunk so far. The orange-juice switch will also prevent you having to experience the real problem that comes with low-alcohol drinks: the taste. According to one recent Mintel survey, 42 per cent of people won't drink low-alcohol drinks because they taste foul - or at least nothing like the product they are meant to be replacing.

Food

Of course, neither low-tar cigarettes nor low-alcohol drinks are the real success stories of the 'low' industry. This prize goes to low-fat foods, which occupy increasing amounts of supermarket shelf. But, warns Dr Susan Jebb from the Medical Research Council Food and Nutrition Unit in Cambridge, 'lowered-fat foods are only a healthier option if they are used in an intelligent and informed way. The trouble is that manipulation by the food industry and our own attitudes mean this is not normally the case.'

A big problem is that the different ways of labelling low-fat foods can mean widely different things, and some labels can hide foods containing high levels of fat and large amounts of calories. By law, 'virtually fat-free' foods can contain no more than 0.15g of fat per 100g of food. 'Low-fat foods' can contain no more than 3g of fat per 100g of food, and if you stuck only to products labelled in this way, your low-fat eating plan would be healthy. However, more tempting products - such as biscuits, crisps and curries - come with a totally different set of labels.

Foods marked '5 per cent fat' - or similar - just use a different way of telling you how many grams of fat per 100g they have. Obviously the closer to three this is, the closer they are to truly being low fat. Then there's the '85 per cent (or similar) fat-free' school of labelling. It sounds impressive, but all it means is that the other 15 per cent of the food is fat, so it boasts 15g of fat per 100g of food. A 500g '85 per cent fat-free' ready meal would therefore contain more than a woman's entire day's fat allowance of 70g. Similarly, 'reduced'-fat foods - generally used as a label on higher-fat foods such as crisps and cakes - are foods that legally have to contain at least 25 per cent less fat than the standard version of that food - but that doesn't mean that a high-fat food has become low fat and a healthy option. A chocolate bar is still, relatively speaking, a high-fat product even when its fat content has been reduced.

Susan Jebb also says that because most of us err on the side of optimism about how healthy our diet is, 'we tend to think that making any changes at all will mean huge gains for our health. This isn't the case - swapping to semi-skimmed milk and 85 per cent fat-free digestives will not protect you from heart attack if the rest of your diet is bad.'

The final sting in the tail with low-fat food products is that their calorie count is often not dramatically different from that of the product they are replacing. 'When fat is taken out of a food, it's normally replaced with some kind of carbohydrate,' says Sue Dibbs, co-director of the Food Commission. 'This could be some kind of starchy filler, in the case of savoury foods, but in sweet foods it's more likely to be in the form of a sugar - maple syrup is very common - and this boosts the calories removed with the fat.' Studies show that the result is that most people who eat low-fat foods consume exactly the same number of calories as those who don't make the switch - and in the US, it has been shown that they eat even more, consuming say two or three low-fat chocolate bars where they would have had only one 'normal' one.

'If you want lowered-fat foods to be healthy, you have to use them correctly,' says Jebb. 'If, every time you were going to eat a high-fat food, you swapped it with the lowest-fat alternative to that food available - and you didn't snack on extra foods because you think that low-fat foods don't count - then you would make significant health gains. It's just that most of us don't do that.'

Stephen Langley, president of the Association of Naturopathic Practitioners, feels that 'with all doctored products, a moderate amount of the real thing is better for our bodies than large amounts of the replacement. When a product's been manipulated to make it "healthier", there's always some payback for our bodies. You have to look at the products concerned and ask if they outweigh the risks of moderate consumption in the first place. Time and time again, the answer will be no.'

fields.headline: Barefoot Doctor
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: looking on the bright side, and how best to boost the immune system
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: looking on the bright side, and how best to boost the immune system.
fields.body:
There is no such thing as a neutral thought. In any one moment, this one, for instance, you have the choice - and the right to exercise that choice - between responding negatively or positively to any new influx of information, in whatever format it may appear (this piece, for example).

As infants, we internalise both negative and positive aspects of our impressions received from parents, peers and teachers, in other words, we create (imaginary) characters based on them, with whom we people the internal world of our psyches. Without realising, we tend to delude ourselves into believing our thoughts are under their command. This works in our favour where the internalised qualities are positive and to our detriment where negative. Very few of us have or have had 'perfect' childhoods, so if unchecked, our minds generally tend to react negatively when faced with new information. Indeed, if you've been habitually responding negatively for years, suddenly telling yourself to think positively instead feels like a con trick to train yourself to respond positively to whatever life throws up.

And that's because it is - a trick you play on yourself, requiring for its successful operation your exercise of self-confidence: as I believe, so shall it be.

It's a trick that's been used effectively for aeons. It is taught as fundamental self-preservative knowledge by every spiritual path from Buddhism to New-Ageism, including Christianity. Jesus purportedly used positive-thinking power to heal as in, 'Pick up your bedding and walk!' and the patient, being momentarily infused with the healer's positivity, was so convinced by it that he picked up his bed and walked (if you go with the Chinese whispers as to the way it all happened).

You choose the way your mind responds to reality, and reality in turn tends to respond to the way your mind responds to it - 'when you're smiling, the whole world smiles with you', etc.

When 'things' appear to be going against you, and you discipline yourself to focus on the benefits of the situation, however tenuous, your willingness to be positive not only makes you more pleasant to be around for yourself and others, but tends to encourage events to turn more swiftly in your favour.

Obviously, however highly disciplined, no one can remain exclusively in the positive state - it would defy the laws of physics. Even the Buddha had his bad-hair days (or at least bad-pate days). According to the fundamental principle of yin and yang - what goes up must come down - you can't know positivity without knowing its opposite. The idea is to strike a balance between them tilted at least 51 per cent into the positive most of the time. This is best achieved not by focusing on eliminating the negative - what you focus on tends to expand in influence - but on increasing input and development of the positive. The negative will then naturally fall away by itself.

The quickest way to reprogramme is through giving commands to yourself, commonly known as 'doing affirmations', in the form of writing each command at least six times. (It has been found to require a minimum of six repetitions to penetrate the unconscious fully.) Obviously, it also helps to have them scrolling across your computer screen or fixed with a magnet to your fridge door, to repeat them in your mind or out loud while stuck in traffic, and even to shout them from the rooftops, if you think you've got what it takes. The point is to inculcate positive thoughts in your circuitry to override the negative ones, by repetition.

You can use any words you like, as long as you keep it positive. The unconscious mind only recognises the positive part of any given command. If I said, 'Don't be happy now', your mind would only register, 'Be happy now.'

Imagine you've got deadlines to meet. You're talking on one phone, the other one's ringing, and the 80 emails you've just replied to have just replied back, along with 69 new ones. If you take a moment out to write down six times, 'By relaxing my mind and body, breathing and staying focused on one thing at a time, I am able to achieve superhuman amounts easily, effortlessly (even miraculously)', you may be surprised at how easily the work gets done.

Self-help bookshelves are crammed full of books on the topic, so let me not bore you now with more detailed explanations except to say that the most powerful and straightforward affirmation is to say 'yes'. Say 'yes' to life and whatever it throws in your path. Say 'yes' to optimising your experience of life, whatever the circumstances. As an exercise, try it now: when I ask, 'Don't you feel a little more uplifted after reading this?', you reply...

Dear Barefoot, Four years ago, my daughter had surgery for peritonitis caused by an infection. She has just been diagnosed as having Crohn's disease, which she is recovering from without medicine. Her legs have large red weals from, we are told, her immune system breaking down. If she is given medication to treat this, what else can she take to boost her immune system?
Phyllis Johnson,
Padstow, Cornwall

It's encouraging that your daughter has overcome the Crohn's without medication - it shows that her life-force is strong. Chinese herbs, shiatsu and homeopathy can be extremely helpful in soothing and cooling the intestines and keeping the colon from constriction. If you decide to use allopathic medication, inform the consultant, as herbal preparations may be contraindicated when used together. For the immune system, it is generally safe to take a basic multivitamin and mineral with ginseng supplement and to visit a homeopath for a constitution builder like 'calc carb'. T'ai chi and chi gong are also great ways to boost the immune system and are effective in relieving bowel disorders. I wish her well.

 Barefoot Doctor is author of 'Handbook for the Urban Warrior' and teaches Taoism, meditation, Chinese medicine and t'ai chi. He has been in practice for more than 20 years, specialising in personal-crisis management. If you have any problems you'd like answers to, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him on barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: ... Creating SPARKS
fields.trailText: ... Creating SPARKS.
fields.body:
Art and science, those traditionally uneasy bedfellows, are being brought together in a three week-long festival in London's South Kensington. In an attempt to bridge the cultural divide and blur the boundaries between the disciplines, Creating SPARKS will explore the mischievous marriage of art, science and technology through more than 400 events, ranging from the symbolic (a highwire walk between the Natural History Museum and the V&A) to the practical (a series of mass-participation experiments).

Encompassing all the museums in the area, the highlight of the festival is a carnival which will take over Exhibition Road next Sunday, filling it with street performers reflecting scientific themes through the arts. Entry to the museums will be free, with Scarabeus Theatre abseiling around the Earth Galleries of the Natural History Museum, a video wall broadcasting digital performance, and Kitsou Dubois's dance company performing in zero gravity.

Matters get more weighty in the talks and workshops which take place throughout the Creating SPARKS festival, the pick of the bunch being Susan Greenfield on the brain of the future, Richard Dawkins discussing art and evolution, astronaut Buzz Aldrin in conversation, and a broadcast of Any Questions?

More ambitious still is the bid to create a new genre of art - 'medico-politico' - through Pharmacopoeia, an exhibition by GP Liz Lee and artists Susie Freeman and David Critchley at the Royal College of Art. By mixing traditional materials with pharmaceutical products, they provide an explicit contemporary commentary on our relationship with medicines - the 'Come Dancing' ball gown (pictured left) is made with 6,550 contraceptive pills, the quantity an average woman would take over 26 years. Not necessarily a whole new school of art, but thought-provoking, nonetheless.

fields.headline: Daring Wearing
fields.standfirst: Gillian Wearing doesn't conform to the usual YBA stereotypes - she's shy, reluctant to talk about herself and loves a mug of hot Ribena. But when Miranda Sawyer took the Turner Prize-winner to Alton Towers she let her mask slip...
