fields.body:
Alton Towers, August 2000. At the highest point of Oblivion, just before you make the screaming, vertical 60m plunge into the black hole of the earth, your seat tips forward so that you hang for a few seconds, facing the ground, contemplating the inevitable. It's terrifying. Too much perspective. Then the car drops straight down, there's a flash of light and you hurtle into darkness, a strangely cold, wet darkness... until, just as it feels as though you really will have a heart attack, you level out, shoot round a corner and surface. Premature exhilaration. 'It's all about death, isn't it?' says Gillian Wearing cheerfully, as we collect our souvenir picture. She studies it quizzically. 'Next time,' she says, 'we should try and look nonchalant.'

Artists are meant to be odd bods; it's part of their job description. But the recent crop of so-called YBAs (Young British Artists: Damien Hirst, Sarah Lucas, Tracey Emin, et al), while not exactly conventional, have always seemed more approachable, more understandable, less bohemian, isolated and disengaged from reality than the artist stereotype. YBAs get drunk and rowdy. They like pop music and TV. They dress like your mates. They make work that is about everyday life and everyday death (and they don't paint it in oils, which is possibly why they have so much time to socialise). So it's no surprise that when you first meet Gillian Wearing, YBA, BA (Goldsmiths), winner of the 1997 Turner Prize, you think: oh, she's dead normal. Gillian, 36, has a young face and long, straight black hair, and she wears men's trousers and patterned shirts. She drinks hot Ribena; she talks about Big Brother. There's nothing particularly attention-seeking about her (unlike, say, Tracey or Damien): she seems a bit shy, though not unfriendly.

We meet at Gillian's home in unsalubrious Borough, south London, a Peabody-type flat that's far too tiny for her and her artist boyfriend Michael Landy. Kitchen, sitting room, bedroom, bathroom, all of tiddly proportions. No evidence of a DIY ethic: the sitting room is a teetering clutter of boxes and videos and magazines; the walls are grubby white. There are no pictures, anywhere, other than a large photograph of a young girl with her writing underneath, pinned to the sitting-room wall. Clearly some of Gillian's work. I have a quick look: 'Oh, it's not finished yet,' says Gillian nervously. 'I feel funny about people seeing work when I haven't quite worked out what to do with it.'

From 14 September to 29 October, the Serpentine Gallery in Kensington Gardens will be host to a Gillian Wearing solo exhibition. Sponsored by The Observer, the show will include older work, such as Dancing in Peckham, Sasha and Mum, 2 into 1 , Homage to the Woman..., plus some new stuff: Drunk, Trauma. None of this may mean anything to you, but you'll have had a taste of Gillian's art, even if you've never been to one of her shows.

You know that VW advert that shows a security guard, a harassed mother and others holding up a handwritten sign that says what they're supposedly feeling (the security guard's one says 'Sensitive', the mother's 'Sex Chocolate Sex Chocolate'). Well, that's a, ahem, tribute to one of Gillian's photographic works: 1993's Signs that say what you want them to say and not signs that say what someone else wants you to say.

Gillian's sign-holders were real people, strangers that she approached on the street and got to write down what they happened to be feeling at the time. The results were unexpected, and unexpectedly touching. The one that everyone remembers is the young businessman whose sign reads, 'I'm Desperate', although I have a soft spot for the chap who displays, with some pride, 'I've thought about being a gigolo but I'm worried about the health risks'. After another advert - for a computer game - again drew on one of Gillian's pieces ( 2 into 1, where the voice of a mother and her sons are transposed, so that the boys speak the mother's words and vice versa), Gillian made a public protest. 'It did really annoy me,' she says now. 'I was annoyed that the advertisers passed it off as though they'd had this unique idea. It's not like you've taken a scene out of a film that everyone knows. There's no references. It's just theft.'

Gillian's work is often funny, always human, humane and democratic. It's easy to understand, too, which is probably why it's appropriated by ad agencies; it draws on real life. In Dancing in Peckham , she dances wildly, without music, in a South London shopping centre. Confess all on video. Don't worry, you will be in disguise. Intrigued? Call Gillian shows people in strange masks (Neil Kinnock, George Bush) telling their secrets.

Phaidon have a lovely book of Gillian's work: when I went through it, I thought she'd make a brilliant journalist, or documentary maker. She reveals details of people that mostly remain hidden; she talks to people - down-and-outs, kids - who mostly pass unnoticed. She says she thinks of much of her work as portraiture, but portraits where the subject has some personal voice, 'because it's too easy for a photograph to make people look like something they're not'. That's why the picture of the girl on the sitting-room wall has the girl's own carefully rounded writing underneath it.

Gillian hasn't got a studio at the moment, which partially explains the chaos of her flat. And it is chaos. There's no hidden system: when she tries to find a video of the preparation she did for Dancing in Peckham , she spends a good quarter of an hour trying to locate it. 'It is here somewhere,' she murmurs. 'I saw it just before you arrived.' She rummages through boxes. The cat hides behind the sofa. Probably a good time to go through Gillian's history.

Gillian Clare Wearing was born on 10 December 1963, in Handsworth, Birmingham, the middle child of three - older sister Jainne-Ann, younger brother Richard. Her dad, Brian, sold televisions; Jean, her mum, was a butcher; the family lived in a three-bedroomed house in Great Barr. ('A city kid. I still am. I'd rather see the countryside in a film; I stay in the car when people go for walks.') Gillian's parents split up when she was in her early teens: she says she can't remember exactly when, because her dad had phases of living elsewhere, 'in other women's houses, I think. It's vague territory.'

I ask her which of her parents she thinks she's most like. To my surprise, she's entirely thrown by the question, stares at me, starts swallowing her words: 'I, um, er, I, I, well, I've, um never thought about it.' She's not unhappy about me asking; it's just that she genuinely hasn't a clue how to answer. She calls Michael out of the kitchen, asks him what he thinks. He says he hasn't met her family often enough to tell. After five minutes deliberation, Gillian finally offers, with a laugh: 'Well, my father liked to argue things out. Not have shouting arguments, but argue, meaning discussion.' Gillian herself appears very non-confrontational. But then, perhaps she's hit her post-adolescent mellow period: 'I was put on report on my first day in secondary school. I hit a teacher.' Blimey. Why? 'She hit me.'

On the same day, Gillian met Christine Knight. She approached her because 'her shoes were much better than mine' (they were platforms). Christine and Gillian became friends, went to Aston Villa football matches together. Throughout her teens and early twenties, Gillian would have one close girlfriend, maybe two: when she grew apart from Christine, Michelle Markam became Gillian's closest mate. Gillian and Michelle listened to music together, tried out make-up, began to bunk off school. One day, while they were wagging, they bumped into Gillian's dad: 'We were all dolled up: it was our punk phase, we must have been 14. And we saw him. He walked about 10ft away from us, stared straight through us. I never worked out if he'd actually recognised us or not.'

School wasn't going too well. Outside school was getting better and better. Punk happened, swiftly followed by ska and rude boy, then new romantic, then Goth. Gillian had a haircut for each. he shows me a picture of the three Wearing children on holiday in Cornwall. Jainne-Ann has a perm and a saucy look; Richard is pulling faces and giving the thumbs up. Gillian is at the back, in her rude-girl phase, hair and face just so, hin up, all bravado and no smiling. About 15 years old. She's barely recognisable.

Looks were very important to Gillian, when she was young. She recalls the hours she'd spend on white, pancake make-up, fussing with her unco-oporative hair, drawing lines around her eyes to make them bigger, squeezing into a ridiculous taffeta skirt so tight that 'I could only make fairy steps.' On Saturday nights, she'd go round to Michelle's to go out. But Michelle took even longer than Gillian to get ready. 'By the time we caught the 51 bus and made it all the way into town, it was time to catch the last one back again. Still,' says Gillian, wryly, 'at least everyone on the bus saw what we looked like.'

The girls started to go to nightclubs (though 'we never drank. We couldn't afford it'), places like Rumrunner, where pre-fame Duran Duran and Boy George hung out. Sometimes, George would catch the bus with Gillian. She recalls seeing him dance: he had this move where he waggled his hand in front of his face (she demonstrates: it appears that the lovely George was trying to flush himself down the toilet). Gillian thought George's dance was just fantastic.

It's simplistic, but you could say that Gillian's teenage years and passions eventually turned themselves inside out and became her work. She herself notes that it wasn't until she went to art school that she gave up putting so much artistry into her own appearance. Up until then, she was her own canvas. Yet, despite her look-at-me outer shell, she was a quiet, shy person, drawn to others, like Boy George, like Christine and Michelle, whom she considered more interesting than herself. Now, such people inform her work: Gillian's art is other people. Now, shy as she is, she will approach someone in the street just because they've 'got something about them'; talk to them, explain she's an artist, ask if they'd mind having their photo taken. What do you look for? 'I dunno. Someone who reminds you of someone in your childhood or of yourself. I dunno what it is, but it's there and sometimes it can click when you see people.'

Sometimes, when she lacks the courage to approach someone, she kicks herself for weeks afterwards. One such occasion was when she spotted a woman with a bandaged face on a road in south-east London. The woman was out with friends, going clubbing, enjoying herself, entirely ordinary except for her white swaddling mask. Gillian didn't talk to her, but found her so inspiring that she made a work, Homage to the Woman with the Bandaged Face I Saw Yesterday Down Walworth Road , where she wrapped her own face up in bandages and walked the length of the Walworth Road, filming people's reac tions. She was incredibly nervous - 'I could have bumped into my neighbours' - and had to have a couple of whiskies before she went out. Why did you do it?

'She stood out. I'm transfixed by people that I see that do stand out, whether they want to or not. It was seeing what it's like to be able to do that and to have some kind of kinship with it. Cos I'm actually quite a shy person, but I like seeing if you can be able to be more outrageous than you are, being able to be disinhibited, see if you can feel like not being so shy.'

Her shyness is another important, though unseen, factor in her art. It's what fires Gillian: the reason why she doesn't repeat her work is that she believes that as soon as the process becomes less nerve-wracking for her, as soon she relaxes and isn't nervous, then her art deteriorates. Once she became easy with approaching people for Signs, she noticed that the thoughts they wrote down became less interesting. Unusually, her shyness isn't hard work: she's very restful to be around.

She communicates her liking for you through subtle little gestures, funny snuffly laughter. Actually, she's turned her shyness into an asset, I think. You can see why she strikes up friendships with tramps and kids, how she can work with people whom others can't. She's shy, so she never dominates or talks down. She gives you space to express yourself and she doesn't mind if that expression is unformed or inarticulate. She doesn't mind, because she herself finds it very hard to talk. In all senses: she hates talking about herself - 'I don't talk personally about anything with anyone. I'm totally opposite to what I try and create in my work' - and she can't physically do it, anyway. Gillian can't speak properly. Her words are jerky and swallowed, as though she's trying to suck them back as soon as she's uttered them, and she sometimes misses out vital phrases. Sometimes, her speech is almost incomprehensible. This is what she says when she tries to explain.

'I actually was, I can talk a lot more now, but a few years ago I tried to talk, and I have changed a lot in my ability to talk, I couldn't just talk, talk to people, I've never been a great talker or just trying to think about, try to, try to be able to talk for many years. For years, still sometimes when I go to places I have to breathe to get my head lightheaded because I'm so nervous about, I can still have these kind of blocks where I can't, or if I do you can tell that I'm so nervous and what I'm saying is so bad. It's not to do with ideas at all, it's just the idea of talking really, just the talking about anything.' She laughs, composes herself, takes a breath. 'It's like I'm thinking more about my presence than I'm thinking about how you communicate.'

Once, when she was temping, two of her work colleagues noticed: 'They said, "You can't form a sentence can you?" And it had never occurred to me before because in the relationships I had with my friends it wasn't actually about talking so much, it was just a laugh.' Gillian was working for an insurance company, so her colleagues made her work the counter, just to see if she could speak. 'And I did, and didn't actually say anything, just sort of nn uh yuh un uh.' Language, schmanguage: Gillian stopped reading books at 14. She left school two years later with no qualifications. At 18, she, Michelle and another girl called Kimberley all moved to London: Gillian temped and primped and tried to save for her rent. She stayed in hostels and lived off Mars Bars. And then, at 22, she managed to get a place on an art course, a B-Tech in Chelsea. From there, she went to Goldsmiths, in 1987; two years behind the breakthrough Hirst Frieze year. There, she was forced to speak.

'In Goldsmiths, you had to explain why you were doing what you were doing,' says Gillian. 'And one of the first things I did was cutting up books. It was something to do with language and my inability to use it. They asked me why I was cutting books, in front of all the students, and all I could say was, I don't like 'em.'

Yet another of her adolescent traits that came good in her art. She explores language beautifully now - allowing people to speak as they wish, freeing them by letting them hide behind masks, or write things down, or by, in the case of Drunk, letting her subjects - a group of local homeless people - express themselves, yet not really speak properly at all.

Gillian - still shy, still inarticulate, still interested in others and not in herself - shows just how eloquent lack of eloquence can be. The day after we meet, Gillian phones me up. Her speech is scattershot: she says she feels as though we'd gone through a very intense experience. 'When I was talking to you,' she says, 'I started thinking that the answers I was giving were just what I thought at that moment. Sometimes not even that. They were just answers because that's what you're meant to do when someone asks you a question.' She suggests meeting up to do something more light-hearted. Fine, but what? A spot of prodding and Gillian spits it out. She really, really loves roller coasters. So we decide to go to Alton Towers.

When we get there, Gillian confesses that she likes funfairs so much that she persuaded Michael to go to one on their first date. Which shows how keen he was, because he hates scary rides, apparently. She'd met him at Goldsmiths and she liked him because 'he was so smiley and friendly. He can talk to anyone' - but they didn't get it together until four years ago. Anyhow, when they did, they went on a trip around England's theme parks: Blackpool, Alton Towers, Chessington. They stayed in the Alton Towers Hotel, but couldn't afford a themed room. Still, there were people dressed as animals wandering through the foyer all night: 'It was amazing,' sighs Gillian. I like roller coasters, and we have a lovely time.

We buy a commemorative all-action photo whenever we can, and treat ourselves to a gourmet McDonald's at the end. During the day, we chat about this and that. About the Turner Prize (she got very drunk, made 'a really embarrassing speech that no one could understand', went to the Atlantic Bar, and fell asleep; she didn't produce any work for about a year afterwards). About music (she hated Pulp's Common People, but loved their last, dark LP). About food (she got the sack from McDonald's because she was so slow that all the customers asked for their money back). And city kid Gillian misreads the Alton Towers map and leads us literally up a very long garden path. She huffs and puffs all the way.

And I change my mind about Gillian. She's normal, but not in the way I thought. What's nice about her is that, actually, she's an unusual, quite eccentric person, a 'proper' artist - but that's all hidden behind her easy-going mask of ordinariness. She's like her subjects. She's like everyone else. Normal, but not at all underneath. An undercover correspondent sending weird dispatches back from the frontline of the mundane. 'Oh, I don't think anyone's ordinary,' says Gillian Wearing. 'Everyone's different. Everyone has something special about them.'

 Gillian Wearing, the Serpentine Gallery, Kensington Gardens, London W2 (020 7402 6075), from 14 September to 29 October Sponsored by Selfridges & Co in association with The Observer

Sometimes, when she lacks the courage to approach someone, she kicks herself for weeks afterwards. One such occasion was when she spotted a woman with a bandaged face on a road in south-east London. The woman was out with friends, going clubbing, enjoying herself, entirely ordinary except for her white swaddling mask. Gillian didn't talk to her, but found her so inspiring that she made a work, Homage to the Woman with the Bandaged Face I Saw Yesterday Down Walworth Road , where she wrapped her own face up in bandages and walked the length of the Walworth Road, filming people's reac tions. She was incredibly nervous - 'I could have bumped into my neighbours' - and had to have a couple of whiskies before she went out. Why did you do it? 'She stood out. I'm transfixed by people that I see that do stand out, whether they want to or not. It was seeing what it's like to be able to do that and to have some kind of kinship with it. Cos I'm actually quite a shy person, but I like seeing if you can be able to be more outrageous than you are, being able to be disinhibited, see if you can feel like not being so shy.' Her shyness is another important, though unseen, factor in her art. It's what fires Gillian: the reason why she doesn't repeat her work is that she believes that as soon as the process becomes less nerve-wracking for her, as soon she relaxes and isn't nervous, then her art deteriorates. Once she became easy with approaching people for Signs, she noticed that the thoughts they wrote down became less interesting. Unusually, her shyness isn't hard work: she's very restful to be around. She communicates her liking for you through subtle little gestures, funny snuffly laughter. Actually, she's turned her shyness into an asset, I think. You can see why she strikes up friendships with tramps and kids, how she can work with people whom others can't. She's shy, so she never dominates or talks down. She gives you space to express yourself and she doesn't mind if that expression is unformed or inarticulate. She doesn't mind, because she herself finds it very hard to talk. In all senses: she hates talking about herself - 'I don't talk personally about anything with anyone. I'm totally opposite to what I try and create in my work' - and she can't physically do it, anyway. Gillian can't speak properly. Her words are jerky and swallowed, as though she's trying to suck them back as soon as she's uttered them, and she sometimes misses out vital phrases. Sometimes, her speech is almost incomprehensible. This is what she says when she tries to explain. 'I actually was, I can talk a lot more now, but a few years ago I tried to talk, and I have changed a lot in my ability to talk, I couldn't just talk, talk to people, I've never been a great talker or just trying to think about, try to, try to be able to talk for many years. For years, still sometimes when I go to places I have to breathe to get my head lightheaded because I'm so nervous about, I can still have these kind of blocks where I can't, or if I do you can tell that I'm so nervous and what I'm saying is so bad. It's not to do with ideas at all, it's just the idea of talking really, just the talking about anything.' She laughs, composes herself, takes a breath. 'It's like I'm thinking more about my presence than I'm thinking about how you communicate.' Once, when she was temping, two of her work colleagues noticed: 'They said, "You can't form a sentence can you?" And it had never occurred to me before because in the relationships I had with my friends it wasn't actually about talking so much, it was just a laugh.' Gillian was working for an insurance company, so her colleagues made her work the counter, just to see if she could speak. 'And I did, and didn't actually say anything, just sort of nn uh yuh un uh.' Language, schmanguage: Gillian stopped reading books at 14. She left school two years later with no qualifications. At 18, she, Michelle and another girl called Kimberley all moved to London: Gillian temped and primped and tried to save for her rent. She stayed in hostels and lived off Mars Bars. And then, at 22, she managed to get a place on an art course, a B-Tech in Chelsea. From there, she went to Goldsmiths, in 1987; two years behind the breakthrough Hirst Frieze year. There, she was forced to speak. 'In Goldsmiths, you had to explain why you were doing what you were doing,' says Gillian. 'And one of the first things I did was cutting up books. It was something to do with language and my inability to use it. They asked me why I was cutting books, in front of all the students, and all I could say was, I don't like 'em.' Yet another of her adolescent traits that came good in her art. She explores language beautifully now - allowing people to speak as they wish, freeing them by letting them hide behind masks, or write things down, or by, in the case of Drunk, letting her subjects - a group of local homeless people - express themselves, yet not really speak properly at all. Gillian - still shy, still inarticulate, still interested in others and not in herself - shows just how eloquent lack of eloquence can be. The day after we meet, Gillian phones me up. Her speech is scattershot: she says she feels as though we'd gone through a very intense experience. 'When I was talking to you,' she says, 'I started thinking that the answers I was giving were just what I thought at that moment. Sometimes not even that. They were just answers because that's what you're meant to do when someone asks you a question.' She suggests meeting up to do something more light-hearted. Fine, but what? A spot of prodding and Gillian spits it out. She really, really loves roller coasters. So we decide to go to Alton Towers. When we get there, Gillian confesses that she likes funfairs so much that she persuaded Michael to go to one on their first date. Which shows how keen he was, because he hates scary rides, apparently. She'd met him at Goldsmiths and she liked him because 'he was so smiley and friendly. He can talk to anyone' - but they didn't get it together until four years ago. Anyhow, when they did, they went on a trip around England's theme parks: Blackpool, Alton Towers, Chessington. They stayed in the Alton Towers Hotel, but couldn't afford a themed room. Still, there were people dressed as animals wandering through the foyer all night: 'It was amazing,' sighs Gillian. I like roller coasters, and we have a lovely time. We buy a commemorative all-action photo whenever we can, and treat ourselves to a gourmet McDonald's at the end. During the day, we chat about this and that. About the Turner Prize (she got very drunk, made 'a really embarrassing speech that no one could understand', went to the Atlantic Bar, and fell asleep; she didn't produce any work for about a year afterwards). About music (she hated Pulp's Common People, but loved their last, dark LP). About food (she got the sack from McDonald's because she was so slow that all the customers asked for their money back). And city kid Gillian misreads the Alton Towers map and leads us literally up a very long garden path. She huffs and puffs all the way. And I change my mind about Gillian. She's normal, but not in the way I thought. What's nice about her is that, actually, she's an unusual, quite eccentric person, a 'proper' artist - but that's all hidden behind her easy-going mask of ordinariness. She's like her subjects. She's like everyone else. Normal, but not at all underneath. An undercover correspondent sending weird dispatches back from the frontline of the mundane. 'Oh, I don't think anyone's ordinary,' says Gillian Wearing. 'Everyone's different. Everyone has something special about them.'  Gillian Wearing, the Serpentine Gallery, Kensington Gardens, London W2 (020 7402 6075), from 14 September to 29 October Sponsored by Selfridges & Co in association with The Observer

fields.headline: Dispatches
fields.standfirst: For 30 years, Charlie Haughey dominated Ireland's political stage. He was a regular at the White House and Downing Street, and was a close friend of President Mitterrand. But when a coked-up retail billionaire tried to jump from a Florida hotel, no one could have guessed that Charlie's game was up

But when a coked-up retail billionaire tried to jump from a Florida hotel, no one could have guessed that Charlie's game was up.
fields.body:
It was a fairly routine Orange County police call; a man was threatening to commit suicide by diving off the 17th floor of the Hyatt Regency Grand Cypress Hotel, just two miles from Disneyworld, Florida.

When they reached the balcony just before 10am on 20 February 1992, police officers found a deranged 42-year-old man perched on the balcony ledge. Police officer Stan Spanich spent 40 minutes coaxing the man back into his room, 1708. Inside, flat out on the bed suffering a cocaine overdose was 22-year-old Denise Wojcik from the local Escorts-in-a-Flash agency. Denise said she and an 'associate', Sherri, had spent the night in the room's sunken Jacuzzi with the would-be suicide snorting cocaine through rolled up $100 bills. The big man, 6ft 4in, paranoid on coke, said he was Irish, he was a businessman, and his name was Ben Dunne.

None of it meant very much to the Florida police officers; arresting people strung out on cocaine was a daily occurrence in the Sunshine State. But 3,000 miles on the other, wetter side of the Atlantic in Ireland, Ben Dunne was a very big man indeed. Dunne was one of the most prominent businessmen in the Irish State. His billion-pound supermarket retail empire supplied the majority of Irish households with the food for their tables and the shirts on their backs. Dunne was also, in secret, a major benefactor of the Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey.

For 30 years Haughey, whose hero was Napoleon, had bestrode the narrow Irish political stage dominating friend and foe. Charlie, as he was universally known, had held every major office of state and was Taoiseach of Ireland four times.

Haughey was rich. He lived in a glorious 18th-century mansion, filled with art, on the outskirts of Dublin. In the 270 acres of his Kinsealy estate he ran a horse stud and bred racecourse winners. He owned an island off Ireland's west coast, Innishvicillaun, that was so remote the building materials for his house had to be helicoptered in. He had an ocean yacht. He spent lavishly, £700 Charvet shirts from Paris, £1,000 meals in Dublin's most exclusive Le Coq Hardi restaurant, the best wine, vintage Cristal champagne, and even in Catholic Ireland, the best of mistresses. As Taoiseach he rubbed shoulders with the great and powerful - President François Mitterand was a friend, and there were the usual St Patrick's Day lunches at the White House and tea, albeit it frosty given the state of Anglo-Irish relations, with Prime Minister Thatcher in Downing Street.

But the fall out from Dunne's cocaine binge would tortuously but relentlessly, destroy the achievements, the fortune and the entire reputation of a man who was once frequently compared to the legendary, romantic IRA leader Michael Collins.

These days Haughey is still at the cen tre of the Irish political stage. But he is no longer welcoming Europe's leaders to EU summits in the splendour of Dublin Castle. Instead, for two hours every day, he is in the witness box at an anti-corruption tribunal answering questions as to where all the money for the mistress, the mansion and the racehorses came from.

For the last two years lawyers at the specially convened Moriarty Tribunal have combed through every Haughey bank statement, every invoice, every property deal he was involved in over the past 30 years in search of evidence of bribery. What they found is damning. Haughey was a career politician whose annual salary even as Taoiseach in the 90s never exceeded £75,000 per annum. Yet more than £8.5m flowed through Haughey's secret bank accounts to fund his lavish lifestyle.

The hidden accounts, the secret transfers, and the network of the rich and powerful who made out their cheques to 'Charles Haughey & Co' point to one conclusion; that Charles Haughey ran for public office to make himself rich and then ran Ireland and the Irish State for the benefit of his cronies. It was a neat quid pro quo and the quid ended up in Charlie's pocket.

'He was the boss. We all looked up to him, the whole Irish nation looked up to him. He stood up to Mrs Thatcher. But all that is undermined by the fact that he was conning us. What really cuts is that all he wanted was to be in power, to have power. And he abused it,' said Steven Kelly, a student who queued to be in the public gallery of the tribunal.

Haughey may be unloved, but he is not defeated. Citing ill-health and age, he is 74, he is only allowed to be questioned for two hours a day. He is far from contrite.

In the witness box, hood-eyed, he scowls at his interrogator as he is minutely led through one damning document after another highlighting his extravagance, his mysterious land-developer friends and their coincidental business dealings with the Irish State. His answers are a never-ending stream of denials, omissions and evasions. 'I can't remember, I do not recollect, not in any detail, I do not have any recollection.' When he is not taking the Irish equivalent of the Fifth Amendment - about self-incrimination - on the basis of his now allegedly faulty memory, Haughey lays the blame on his old financial manager and secret bagman Des Traynor who is wonderfully, discreetly, but indisputably dead.

It is a bravura performance. But it cannot alter the truth. For the past 40 years, bribery and corruption, rather than elections, were the life-blood of Irish politics. The next Irish general election is less than two years away, but a political revolution is coming. All the established parties are facing wipe-out. The beneficiaries will be some of the smaller parties and Gerry Adams's Sinn Fein - fighting as the squeaky-clean newcomers.

The taint of scandal has even touched the current Taoiseach Bertie Ahern, Haughey's protégé. Testifying to the Moriarty Tribunal, he admitted signing entire books of blank cheques for his former leader - cheques drawn on an Irish government account that Haughey later used to pay his Paris shirt bills. 'What Haughey says about Ireland is not very good. It says Ireland is a small coun try and a lot of people in the professions, pillars of the establishment, covered up for him out of fear and greed. It's easy to be abusive about Haughey now, but standing up to him 20 years ago was a different matter. All the stuff about Mafia-style leadership was not a joke,' said Joe Joyce, author of The Boss , a hostile biography of Haughey.

In Haughey's potato republic, only little people paid their taxes. It was government of the people in favour of the few. But the web of power around Haughey was impenetrable. It would take Ben Dunne's suicide bid and a high-stakes legal battle for the Dunnes retail empire to finally expose the rotten core of Haughey's Ireland.

Haughey was the Juan Peron of Irish politics. Like the glamorous Argentinian dictator, he inspired a fanatical following with his peculiar blend of nationalist fervour, right-wing views and appeasement of powerful trade union leaders. He was master of the small political gesture - granting tax exemption to artists and free travel to retirees - and was hugely popular. He was also the supreme practitioner of the Irish political art of 'cute hoorism' ('a clever whore'), slyly outmanoeuvring his opponents with backstage deals. He cultivated his image as the man of power, the man of decision, the very embodiment of the Irish nation.

Party conferences were carefully orchestrated to create an aura around the leader with a personalised theme tune, 'Arise and Follow Charlie'. He loved photo-calls but hated reporters' prying questions; he was always acutely self-conscious of his height, 5ft 6in, and avoided situations where he physically looked up to those he politically looked down upon.

'If you opposed him you were seen as not just being disloyal to him as an individual, but to the party and the country - words that were always mentioned in the same breath - as well. That's why it was so hugely dangerous and that's where you got the slightly fascist overtones of the whole thing,' said his bitter political rival Des O'Malley, who was expelled from the ruling Fianna Fail party on Haughey's orders.

Irish corridors of power hummed with fear and tales of his cutting sarcastic tongue. Haughey, always aloof and imperious, once called a senator into his office to give him a furious dressing down. After a tirade of insults, Haughey dismissed him and returned to the work on his desk. The stunned senator, confused by the wood panelling, could not find his way out. After a few moments Haughey looked up. The hapless senator explained his predicament. 'Then why don't you jump out the fucking window,' retorted Haughey.

Far from being shocked, the Irish fell in love with a politician whose earthy nature and soaring ambition they somehow saw as a better reflection of themselves than his bumbling saintly Fine Gael political rival Garret Fitzgerald. Charlie may have been a bit of a crook but, his followers reasoned, he was our sort of nice crook.

He had chutzpah. One of his first acts as Taoiseach was to lecture the Irish people about living beyond their economic means. At the same time his own extravagance wildly outstripped his income. For decades he ran up a crippling personal IR£750,000 overdraft with one of Ireland's major banks, Allied Irish, when his annual salary at the time was IR£5,500. Demands by the bank for repayment were met by threats and pointed remarks about his political power. 'It was blatantly obvious that he was living a lifestyle he could not afford. It was staring everyone in the face, the helicopters, the ridiculously expensive girlfriend. He was up to something,' says Vincent Browne, one of the few Irish journalists ever to question Haughey openly about his wealth.

Haughey certainly needed money and lots of it. Although he married Maureen Lemass, the daughter of a former Taoiseach, and had four children, he also had a high-profile affair with a Dublin gos sip columnist. His mistress, Terry Keane, was a woman who expected and received the very best her lover could lavish upon her from vintage Cristal champagne at £200-a-bottle, jewellery from Tiffany's in New York to luxurious holidays abroad. Like his hero Napoleon, Haughey was no movie star, but he oozed, according to Keane, sex appeal and had 'the most beautiful mouth of anybody I'd ever seen'.

Keane, now 60, is no longer quite the beauty that turned a Taoiseach's head, but she remains a spirited, spiky woman with an unashamed fondness for fur coats, heavy-set gold jewellery and la dolce vita. It was not, she insists, love at first sight, but it did become a tempestuous passion. 'We were both chancers and we shared the same cynical sense of humour. I knew it would be a mistake to let him know how mad I was about him. We often drank too much when we could get away together and had terrible rows, but usually we had them in private,' said Keane, who remained married to her husband, a Supreme Court judge.

The couple met for weekly trysts in luxury hotels around Dublin or dined privately at their favourite restaurant Le Coq Hardi. 'Charlie was great fun, a great raconteur, and a good companion. He had an unwavering belief in himself. He always seemed very certain of where he was going and what he was going to achieve. He was never daunted by the obstacles, they were always challenges.'

The affair, which began in 1972, was soon an open secret in Dublin media circles. Keane anointed herself with the semi-official title of Taoiseach's Mistress and terrorised those beneath her in the rigid Irish social pecking order, including once an unfortunate young policeman who had the audacity to give her a parking ticket. 'I am,' she would declare, 'the most powerful woman in Ireland; wife of a Supreme Court judge and mistress of a Taoiseach.' She even regularly hinted about 'sweetie' in her weekly gossip column for a Dublin newspaper.

Keane was less popular in other Dublin circles where she was regarded as vain, empty-headed and bitchy. But the true nature of her relationship to Haughey, which would have scandalised a country that still banned condoms for unmarried couples, was never revealed to the Irish people. Ireland's strict libel laws kept Haughey's adultery off the front pages, even when he denounced attempts in 1986 to introduce divorce. Ireland was still too small a country, its ruling elite too tiny, for such secrets to be shared with the masses. For years the same cloying subservience towards power would protect Haughey's secret financial affairs.

The source of Haughey's wealth may have been mysterious, but the scale of it certainly wasn't. In 1969, after a decade as a full-time government minister, Haughey bought Abbeville, the James Gandon-designed mansion that had been the summer home of the English Lord Lieutenants of Ireland, for IR£120,000. The 10-bedroom Georgian mansion, on the outskirts of Dublin, complete with 270 acres, was an astounding purchase. Gandon's other buildings in Ireland include the majestic Four Courts, home of the Irish judiciary, and the historic Dublin Custom House - a drawing of which adorns the back of Irish IR£5 bill.

Abbeville is one of the greatest houses in Ireland, the renovation and upkeep alone consumed vast sums, yet Haughey's ministerial salary in the 60s never exceeded IR£5,500, a 20th of the purchase price. Nor was there any family wealth - Haughey had been brought up in a council house and money was tight. But when pressed about the origins of this impressive wealth, he refused to disclose his finances. 'Talk to my bank manager,' he retorted.

Conveniently, Haughey's bank manager, Des Traynor, a secretive accountant who controlled all of his master's finances, did not give interviews. Indeed, Traynor, despite being on the board of a whole network of prestigious Irish companies - including the state airline, Aer Lingus - was virtually unknown to Irish journalists.

Haughey's four administrations, in the 80s and 90s, were awash with scandals from the illegal bugging of journalists, to the discovery of a wanted double murderer in the attorney general's apartment and even to the arrest of Haughey's personal election agent Pat O'Connor Pat O'Connor, as he humorously became known, for voting twice in the same 1982 election. Most scandals were financial and, although not proven, were never far from Haughey's door.

In early 1992, Haughey's luck finally ran out when an old phone-tapping scandal about the illegal bugging of journalists' telephones resurfaced. Haughey had blamed his minister of justice Sean Doherty and denied all personal knowledge of the telephone intercepts. Doherty willingly took the rap and was forced from government. But 10 years later, Doherty changed his story and said Haughey had ordered the bugging. Haughey resigned on 11 February 1992, with a vintage performance in which he quoted Othello. 'I have done the State some service, they know't; no more of that.'

Nine days later, Ben Dunne's Florida escapade hit the Irish newspapers. Headlines come and go, but for Dunne's siblings, particularly his sister Margaret Heffernan, members of the Dunne family trust that had overall control of the retail chain of stores, it was the final straw. For years, the family had been angered by their brother's autocratic behaviour; she decided to oust him from the Dunnes' board. A full-scale family war for the billion-pound empire broke out during which details of Dunne's secret gifts, actually company money, to Haughey were revealed to Heffernan for the first time. She was amazed. Her late father, Bernard Dunne, the store's founder, had detested Haughey. Heffernan had a simple response: she wanted the money back.

According to Dunne, he first learned that Haughey was in financial difficulties in 1987. Traynor, Haughey's accountant and secret bagman, had phoned up Dunne's legal advisor and asked for cash. Dunne agreed to pay IR£1.3m from secret accounts within the far-flung Dunne empire. Traynor acted as a cut-out; the money was routed into offshore bank accounts. There was nothing to connect Dunne and Haughey.

But then, by chance, in early November 1991, Dunne called on Haughey in Abbeville after playing a game of golf nearby. Haughey, besieged by the latest crisis in his government, looked uncharacteristically down. Dunne happened to have three blank sterling bank drafts for £70,000 each in his pocket. He handed them to Haughey. 'Look, that is something for yourself.' Haughey responded: 'Thank you, big fellow.' The exchange of drafts was over within seconds, but it would in the end crucify Charles Haughey.

Despite Dunne's evidence to Heffernan's lawyers, Haughey, now in retirement, continued to deny that he had ever received money. Heffernan went to Abbeville and confronted him. Haughey, playing for time, was careful to neither deny or affirm receiving the money There was no proof.

Haughey's sophistry cut little ice with either legal team in the Dunnes' dispute. Dunne's payments to Haughey, indicative of Ben Dunne's abuse of the firm's finances, had become a weapon in their own legal clash. Haughey, despite his carefully studied aloofness on his personal finances, was in a panic. He knew that public disclosure of the Dunne money, and all the embarrassing questions it would raise about his wealth, would destroy him.

Suddenly it was Charles Haughey who started making begging phone calls, 11 in total, to Dunne's lawyer. He invited Heffernan back to Abbeville to urge her to resolve the family feud in private. In November 1994, just days before the case reached open court, the Dunnes' legal dispute was settled with a huge IR£85m payment to Ben Dunne. Evidence of Dunne's secret 'gifts' was consigned to the legal dustbin. Haughey thought he had survived. There was even talk in 1996 of a run for the Irish presidency.

But then in 1997 his carefully constructed façade collapsed. Ben Dunne was caught out making illegal payments to another government minister. It was hugely embarrassing for the then Fine Gael government and it was forced to appoint a tribunal of enquiry to investigate payments to members of parliament by Dunne. Within days the tribunal, under the formidable Honourable Mr Justice Brian McCracken, was on the track of Charlie.

This time there was no escape. Statements from the Dunnes' legal battle were retrieved from the archives, witnesses were called, and lawyers interrogated in the full public gaze of an open tribunal. Haughey stonewalled, prevaricated, hoping he could brazen it out, but the tribunal's investigators were relentless in their pursuit. They uncovered an elaborate financial system, organised by Traynor, which could be used to disguise the payment of bribes and the systematic defrauding of the Irish state of tax revenue.

The system was simple but ingenious. Traynor, chairman of the small legitimate merchant bank Guinness Mahon, had established an offshore bank, Ansbacher Cayman Ltd in the Caribbean tax haven of the Cayman Islands, and acted as the Irish agent for its deposits. Money deposited would theoretically be held offshore beyond the scrutiny of the Irish tax authorities. Ansbacher Cayman then redeposited its funds in a consolidated account with Guinness Mahon in Dublin.

Internal auditors for both banks expressed concern at the exposure to risk of mismanagement and fraud by Traynor's operation of the Ansbacher deposits. At one stage these reached IR£38m and comprised one third of Guinness Mahon's liabilities. Access to the operations of the Ansbacher accounts and the coded names of the estimated 120 secret depositors was kept separate from all other bank business. None of the usual banking controls, paper documentation, independent supervision of staff, operated. The 'bank' was little more than a box of records that Traynor kept in the corner of his office.

None of the money ever left Irish shores. When Haughey needed money Traynor simply transferred funds out of the hidden accounts and into the legitimate companies Haughey used to fund his lifestyle.

'The guys running the show were ripping off taxes and all of it was being organised by Des Traynor. Charlie was a great Taoiseach to have around even if they did have to give him a bit of money. He was not exactly going to order an investigation into offshore accounts or give the revenue commissioners a new set of computers,' said a close observer of the tribunal proceedings.

Despite the evidence against him Haughey still continued to deny all knowledge of money from Dunne until the very last moment. But the evidence of the bank drafts he had personally received from Ben Dunne was irrefutable. He was forced to issue a statement saying he had 'mistakenly' instructed his legal team and, yes, he had taken the money. He was a proven liar.

Bizarrely, apart from Ben Dunne being top of the Haughey family wedding invitation list, McCracken found no evidence that Dunnes' companies received any favours from Haughey. 'Charlie would have had such a sense of noblesse oblige that he would think it was his entitlement. And he certainly would not have felt he was under an obligation. I suppose like Napoleon he went a bit barmy,' said his lover Keane.

McCracken was not the end of Haughey's fall from grace; it was the beginning. McCracken was soon replaced by the Moriarty Tribunal tasked with trawling through his entire financial records. It discovered that businessmen keen for his favours invested tens of thousands of pounds in the Haughey family helicopter firm Celtic Helicopters. One such investor was Guy Snowden, the disgraced former American director of the national lottery firm Camelot, who lost his libel trial against Richard Branson over corruption allegations.

As leader of Fianna Fail, Haughey also had control of the funds that the Irish state pays its political parties to help with staff and research costs. Money from that account, countersigned unknowingly by Bertie Ahern, ended up being used to pay his Charvet shirt bill, IR£15, 000, and his bill, IR£14,000, at Le Coq Hardi. An IR£20,000 donation to the cancer fund of his seriously ill foreign minister Brian Lenihan, who received a liver transplant at the Mayo Clinic, ended up in the account of Celtic Helicopters.

The new Ireland, a country of computer firms and the vibrant economically successful Celtic Tiger, was shocked and outraged at its hidden past of sleazy deals, bribery and Charles Haughey. The people turned. Instead of the saviour he was now the scoundrel of the nation. 'Haughey represents the corruption that ran through Irish society. He represents the centre of it all,' said Kevin Scally, a teacher who also queued to see Haughey in the witness box.

Finally, even his mistress Terry Keane betrayed him by selling her story, and some highly embarrassing pictures of the couple kissing, to a Dublin newspaper in May 1999 for IR£65,000 and auctioning off his old love tokens. To Haughey's fury, Keane also appeared on a popular Irish television chat show to expand on their relationship. Their 27-year relationship ended in a terse phone call the following day. 'Charlie didn't so much think that he would not get caught, he thought it would not matter if he did,' said Keane tartly.

Like his hero Napoleon, Haughey, when he is not in the witness box, spends his final days in a gilded mansion, Abbeville, that has become his prison. He is deserted and alone, railing against his enemies and lamenting what could have been. Nothing will erase the ignominy, the shame, of his fall. It may be just, but it is a bitter end to an illustrious career. Even Charles Haughey might be forgiven for cursing that Florida police officer, far away across the Atlantic, who stopped Ben Dunne, and his secrets, from jumping from the Hyatt Regency's 17th floor balcony.

None of it meant very much to the Florida police officers; arresting people strung out on cocaine was a daily occurrence in the Sunshine State. But 3,000 miles on the other, wetter side of the Atlantic in Ireland, Ben Dunne was a very big man indeed. Dunne was one of the most prominent businessmen in the Irish State. His billion-pound supermarket retail empire supplied the majority of Irish households with the food for their tables and the shirts on their backs. Dunne was also, in secret, a major benefactor of the Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey. For 30 years Haughey, whose hero was Napoleon, had bestrode the narrow Irish political stage dominating friend and foe. Charlie, as he was universally known, had held every major office of state and was Taoiseach of Ireland four times. Haughey was rich. He lived in a glorious 18th-century mansion, filled with art, on the outskirts of Dublin. In the 270 acres of his Kinsealy estate he ran a horse stud and bred racecourse winners. He owned an island off Ireland's west coast, Innishvicillaun, that was so remote the building materials for his house had to be helicoptered in. He had an ocean yacht. He spent lavishly, £700 Charvet shirts from Paris, £1,000 meals in Dublin's most exclusive Le Coq Hardi restaurant, the best wine, vintage Cristal champagne, and even in Catholic Ireland, the best of mistresses. As Taoiseach he rubbed shoulders with the great and powerful - President François Mitterand was a friend, and there were the usual St Patrick's Day lunches at the White House and tea, albeit it frosty given the state of Anglo-Irish relations, with Prime Minister Thatcher in Downing Street. But the fall out from Dunne's cocaine binge would tortuously but relentlessly, destroy the achievements, the fortune and the entire reputation of a man who was once frequently compared to the legendary, romantic IRA leader Michael Collins. These days Haughey is still at the cen tre of the Irish political stage. But he is no longer welcoming Europe's leaders to EU summits in the splendour of Dublin Castle. Instead, for two hours every day, he is in the witness box at an anti-corruption tribunal answering questions as to where all the money for the mistress, the mansion and the racehorses came from. For the last two years lawyers at the specially convened Moriarty Tribunal have combed through every Haughey bank statement, every invoice, every property deal he was involved in over the past 30 years in search of evidence of bribery. What they found is damning. Haughey was a career politician whose annual salary even as Taoiseach in the 90s never exceeded £75,000 per annum. Yet more than £8.5m flowed through Haughey's secret bank accounts to fund his lavish lifestyle. The hidden accounts, the secret transfers, and the network of the rich and powerful who made out their cheques to 'Charles Haughey & Co' point to one conclusion; that Charles Haughey ran for public office to make himself rich and then ran Ireland and the Irish State for the benefit of his cronies. It was a neat quid pro quo and the quid ended up in Charlie's pocket. 'He was the boss. We all looked up to him, the whole Irish nation looked up to him. He stood up to Mrs Thatcher. But all that is undermined by the fact that he was conning us. What really cuts is that all he wanted was to be in power, to have power. And he abused it,' said Steven Kelly, a student who queued to be in the public gallery of the tribunal. Haughey may be unloved, but he is not defeated. Citing ill-health and age, he is 74, he is only allowed to be questioned for two hours a day. He is far from contrite. In the witness box, hood-eyed, he scowls at his interrogator as he is minutely led through one damning document after another highlighting his extravagance, his mysterious land-developer friends and their coincidental business dealings with the Irish State. His answers are a never-ending stream of denials, omissions and evasions. 'I can't remember, I do not recollect, not in any detail, I do not have any recollection.' When he is not taking the Irish equivalent of the Fifth Amendment - about self-incrimination - on the basis of his now allegedly faulty memory, Haughey lays the blame on his old financial manager and secret bagman Des Traynor who is wonderfully, discreetly, but indisputably dead. It is a bravura performance. But it cannot alter the truth. For the past 40 years, bribery and corruption, rather than elections, were the life-blood of Irish politics. The next Irish general election is less than two years away, but a political revolution is coming. All the established parties are facing wipe-out. The beneficiaries will be some of the smaller parties and Gerry Adams's Sinn Fein - fighting as the squeaky-clean newcomers. The taint of scandal has even touched the current Taoiseach Bertie Ahern, Haughey's protégé. Testifying to the Moriarty Tribunal, he admitted signing entire books of blank cheques for his former leader - cheques drawn on an Irish government account that Haughey later used to pay his Paris shirt bills. 'What Haughey says about Ireland is not very good. It says Ireland is a small coun try and a lot of people in the professions, pillars of the establishment, covered up for him out of fear and greed. It's easy to be abusive about Haughey now, but standing up to him 20 years ago was a different matter. All the stuff about Mafia-style leadership was not a joke,' said Joe Joyce, author of The Boss , a hostile biography of Haughey. In Haughey's potato republic, only little people paid their taxes. It was government of the people in favour of the few. But the web of power around Haughey was impenetrable. It would take Ben Dunne's suicide bid and a high-stakes legal battle for the Dunnes retail empire to finally expose the rotten core of Haughey's Ireland. Haughey was the Juan Peron of Irish politics. Like the glamorous Argentinian dictator, he inspired a fanatical following with his peculiar blend of nationalist fervour, right-wing views and appeasement of powerful trade union leaders. He was master of the small political gesture - granting tax exemption to artists and free travel to retirees - and was hugely popular. He was also the supreme practitioner of the Irish political art of 'cute hoorism' ('a clever whore'), slyly outmanoeuvring his opponents with backstage deals. He cultivated his image as the man of power, the man of decision, the very embodiment of the Irish nation. Party conferences were carefully orchestrated to create an aura around the leader with a personalised theme tune, 'Arise and Follow Charlie'. He loved photo-calls but hated reporters' prying questions; he was always acutely self-conscious of his height, 5ft 6in, and avoided situations where he physically looked up to those he politically looked down upon. 'If you opposed him you were seen as not just being disloyal to him as an individual, but to the party and the country - words that were always mentioned in the same breath - as well. That's why it was so hugely dangerous and that's where you got the slightly fascist overtones of the whole thing,' said his bitter political rival Des O'Malley, who was expelled from the ruling Fianna Fail party on Haughey's orders. Irish corridors of power hummed with fear and tales of his cutting sarcastic tongue. Haughey, always aloof and imperious, once called a senator into his office to give him a furious dressing down. After a tirade of insults, Haughey dismissed him and returned to the work on his desk. The stunned senator, confused by the wood panelling, could not find his way out. After a few moments Haughey looked up. The hapless senator explained his predicament. 'Then why don't you jump out the fucking window,' retorted Haughey. Far from being shocked, the Irish fell in love with a politician whose earthy nature and soaring ambition they somehow saw as a better reflection of themselves than his bumbling saintly Fine Gael political rival Garret Fitzgerald. Charlie may have been a bit of a crook but, his followers reasoned, he was our sort of nice crook. He had chutzpah. One of his first acts as Taoiseach was to lecture the Irish people about living beyond their economic means. At the same time his own extravagance wildly outstripped his income. For decades he ran up a crippling personal IR£750,000 overdraft with one of Ireland's major banks, Allied Irish, when his annual salary at the time was IR£5,500. Demands by the bank for repayment were met by threats and pointed remarks about his political power. 'It was blatantly obvious that he was living a lifestyle he could not afford. It was staring everyone in the face, the helicopters, the ridiculously expensive girlfriend. He was up to something,' says Vincent Browne, one of the few Irish journalists ever to question Haughey openly about his wealth. Haughey certainly needed money and lots of it. Although he married Maureen Lemass, the daughter of a former Taoiseach, and had four children, he also had a high-profile affair with a Dublin gos sip columnist. His mistress, Terry Keane, was a woman who expected and received the very best her lover could lavish upon her from vintage Cristal champagne at £200-a-bottle, jewellery from Tiffany's in New York to luxurious holidays abroad. Like his hero Napoleon, Haughey was no movie star, but he oozed, according to Keane, sex appeal and had 'the most beautiful mouth of anybody I'd ever seen'. Keane, now 60, is no longer quite the beauty that turned a Taoiseach's head, but she remains a spirited, spiky woman with an unashamed fondness for fur coats, heavy-set gold jewellery and la dolce vita. It was not, she insists, love at first sight, but it did become a tempestuous passion. 'We were both chancers and we shared the same cynical sense of humour. I knew it would be a mistake to let him know how mad I was about him. We often drank too much when we could get away together and had terrible rows, but usually we had them in private,' said Keane, who remained married to her husband, a Supreme Court judge. The couple met for weekly trysts in luxury hotels around Dublin or dined privately at their favourite restaurant Le Coq Hardi. 'Charlie was great fun, a great raconteur, and a good companion. He had an unwavering belief in himself. He always seemed very certain of where he was going and what he was going to achieve. He was never daunted by the obstacles, they were always challenges.' The affair, which began in 1972, was soon an open secret in Dublin media circles. Keane anointed herself with the semi-official title of Taoiseach's Mistress and terrorised those beneath her in the rigid Irish social pecking order, including once an unfortunate young policeman who had the audacity to give her a parking ticket. 'I am,' she would declare, 'the most powerful woman in Ireland; wife of a Supreme Court judge and mistress of a Taoiseach.' She even regularly hinted about 'sweetie' in her weekly gossip column for a Dublin newspaper. Keane was less popular in other Dublin circles where she was regarded as vain, empty-headed and bitchy. But the true nature of her relationship to Haughey, which would have scandalised a country that still banned condoms for unmarried couples, was never revealed to the Irish people. Ireland's strict libel laws kept Haughey's adultery off the front pages, even when he denounced attempts in 1986 to introduce divorce. Ireland was still too small a country, its ruling elite too tiny, for such secrets to be shared with the masses. For years the same cloying subservience towards power would protect Haughey's secret financial affairs. The source of Haughey's wealth may have been mysterious, but the scale of it certainly wasn't. In 1969, after a decade as a full-time government minister, Haughey bought Abbeville, the James Gandon-designed mansion that had been the summer home of the English Lord Lieutenants of Ireland, for IR£120,000. The 10-bedroom Georgian mansion, on the outskirts of Dublin, complete with 270 acres, was an astounding purchase. Gandon's other buildings in Ireland include the majestic Four Courts, home of the Irish judiciary, and the historic Dublin Custom House - a drawing of which adorns the back of Irish IR£5 bill. Abbeville is one of the greatest houses in Ireland, the renovation and upkeep alone consumed vast sums, yet Haughey's ministerial salary in the 60s never exceeded IR£5,500, a 20th of the purchase price. Nor was there any family wealth - Haughey had been brought up in a council house and money was tight. But when pressed about the origins of this impressive wealth, he refused to disclose his finances. 'Talk to my bank manager,' he retorted. Conveniently, Haughey's bank manager, Des Traynor, a secretive accountant who controlled all of his master's finances, did not give interviews. Indeed, Traynor, despite being on the board of a whole network of prestigious Irish companies - including the state airline, Aer Lingus - was virtually unknown to Irish journalists. Haughey's four administrations, in the 80s and 90s, were awash with scandals from the illegal bugging of journalists, to the discovery of a wanted double murderer in the attorney general's apartment and even to the arrest of Haughey's personal election agent Pat O'Connor Pat O'Connor, as he humorously became known, for voting twice in the same 1982 election. Most scandals were financial and, although not proven, were never far from Haughey's door. In early 1992, Haughey's luck finally ran out when an old phone-tapping scandal about the illegal bugging of journalists' telephones resurfaced. Haughey had blamed his minister of justice Sean Doherty and denied all personal knowledge of the telephone intercepts. Doherty willingly took the rap and was forced from government. But 10 years later, Doherty changed his story and said Haughey had ordered the bugging. Haughey resigned on 11 February 1992, with a vintage performance in which he quoted Othello. 'I have done the State some service, they know't; no more of that.' Nine days later, Ben Dunne's Florida escapade hit the Irish newspapers. Headlines come and go, but for Dunne's siblings, particularly his sister Margaret Heffernan, members of the Dunne family trust that had overall control of the retail chain of stores, it was the final straw. For years, the family had been angered by their brother's autocratic behaviour; she decided to oust him from the Dunnes' board. A full-scale family war for the billion-pound empire broke out during which details of Dunne's secret gifts, actually company money, to Haughey were revealed to Heffernan for the first time. She was amazed. Her late father, Bernard Dunne, the store's founder, had detested Haughey. Heffernan had a simple response: she wanted the money back. According to Dunne, he first learned that Haughey was in financial difficulties in 1987. Traynor, Haughey's accountant and secret bagman, had phoned up Dunne's legal advisor and asked for cash. Dunne agreed to pay IR£1.3m from secret accounts within the far-flung Dunne empire. Traynor acted as a cut-out; the money was routed into offshore bank accounts. There was nothing to connect Dunne and Haughey. But then, by chance, in early November 1991, Dunne called on Haughey in Abbeville after playing a game of golf nearby. Haughey, besieged by the latest crisis in his government, looked uncharacteristically down. Dunne happened to have three blank sterling bank drafts for £70,000 each in his pocket. He handed them to Haughey. 'Look, that is something for yourself.' Haughey responded: 'Thank you, big fellow.' The exchange of drafts was over within seconds, but it would in the end crucify Charles Haughey. Despite Dunne's evidence to Heffernan's lawyers, Haughey, now in retirement, continued to deny that he had ever received money. Heffernan went to Abbeville and confronted him. Haughey, playing for time, was careful to neither deny or affirm receiving the money There was no proof. Haughey's sophistry cut little ice with either legal team in the Dunnes' dispute. Dunne's payments to Haughey, indicative of Ben Dunne's abuse of the firm's finances, had become a weapon in their own legal clash. Haughey, despite his carefully studied aloofness on his personal finances, was in a panic. He knew that public disclosure of the Dunne money, and all the embarrassing questions it would raise about his wealth, would destroy him. Suddenly it was Charles Haughey who started making begging phone calls, 11 in total, to Dunne's lawyer. He invited Heffernan back to Abbeville to urge her to resolve the family feud in private. In November 1994, just days before the case reached open court, the Dunnes' legal dispute was settled with a huge IR£85m payment to Ben Dunne. Evidence of Dunne's secret 'gifts' was consigned to the legal dustbin. Haughey thought he had survived. There was even talk in 1996 of a run for the Irish presidency. But then in 1997 his carefully constructed façade collapsed. Ben Dunne was caught out making illegal payments to another government minister. It was hugely embarrassing for the then Fine Gael government and it was forced to appoint a tribunal of enquiry to investigate payments to members of parliament by Dunne. Within days the tribunal, under the formidable Honourable Mr Justice Brian McCracken, was on the track of Charlie. This time there was no escape. Statements from the Dunnes' legal battle were retrieved from the archives, witnesses were called, and lawyers interrogated in the full public gaze of an open tribunal. Haughey stonewalled, prevaricated, hoping he could brazen it out, but the tribunal's investigators were relentless in their pursuit. They uncovered an elaborate financial system, organised by Traynor, which could be used to disguise the payment of bribes and the systematic defrauding of the Irish state of tax revenue. The system was simple but ingenious. Traynor, chairman of the small legitimate merchant bank Guinness Mahon, had established an offshore bank, Ansbacher Cayman Ltd in the Caribbean tax haven of the Cayman Islands, and acted as the Irish agent for its deposits. Money deposited would theoretically be held offshore beyond the scrutiny of the Irish tax authorities. Ansbacher Cayman then redeposited its funds in a consolidated account with Guinness Mahon in Dublin. Internal auditors for both banks expressed concern at the exposure to risk of mismanagement and fraud by Traynor's operation of the Ansbacher deposits. At one stage these reached IR£38m and comprised one third of Guinness Mahon's liabilities. Access to the operations of the Ansbacher accounts and the coded names of the estimated 120 secret depositors was kept separate from all other bank business. None of the usual banking controls, paper documentation, independent supervision of staff, operated. The 'bank' was little more than a box of records that Traynor kept in the corner of his office. None of the money ever left Irish shores. When Haughey needed money Traynor simply transferred funds out of the hidden accounts and into the legitimate companies Haughey used to fund his lifestyle. 'The guys running the show were ripping off taxes and all of it was being organised by Des Traynor. Charlie was a great Taoiseach to have around even if they did have to give him a bit of money. He was not exactly going to order an investigation into offshore accounts or give the revenue commissioners a new set of computers,' said a close observer of the tribunal proceedings. Despite the evidence against him Haughey still continued to deny all knowledge of money from Dunne until the very last moment. But the evidence of the bank drafts he had personally received from Ben Dunne was irrefutable. He was forced to issue a statement saying he had 'mistakenly' instructed his legal team and, yes, he had taken the money. He was a proven liar. Bizarrely, apart from Ben Dunne being top of the Haughey family wedding invitation list, McCracken found no evidence that Dunnes' companies received any favours from Haughey. 'Charlie would have had such a sense of noblesse oblige that he would think it was his entitlement. And he certainly would not have felt he was under an obligation. I suppose like Napoleon he went a bit barmy,' said his lover Keane. McCracken was not the end of Haughey's fall from grace; it was the beginning. McCracken was soon replaced by the Moriarty Tribunal tasked with trawling through his entire financial records. It discovered that businessmen keen for his favours invested tens of thousands of pounds in the Haughey family helicopter firm Celtic Helicopters. One such investor was Guy Snowden, the disgraced former American director of the national lottery firm Camelot, who lost his libel trial against Richard Branson over corruption allegations. As leader of Fianna Fail, Haughey also had control of the funds that the Irish state pays its political parties to help with staff and research costs. Money from that account, countersigned unknowingly by Bertie Ahern, ended up being used to pay his Charvet shirt bill, IR£15, 000, and his bill, IR£14,000, at Le Coq Hardi. An IR£20,000 donation to the cancer fund of his seriously ill foreign minister Brian Lenihan, who received a liver transplant at the Mayo Clinic, ended up in the account of Celtic Helicopters. The new Ireland, a country of computer firms and the vibrant economically successful Celtic Tiger, was shocked and outraged at its hidden past of sleazy deals, bribery and Charles Haughey. The people turned. Instead of the saviour he was now the scoundrel of the nation. 'Haughey represents the corruption that ran through Irish society. He represents the centre of it all,' said Kevin Scally, a teacher who also queued to see Haughey in the witness box. Finally, even his mistress Terry Keane betrayed him by selling her story, and some highly embarrassing pictures of the couple kissing, to a Dublin newspaper in May 1999 for IR£65,000 and auctioning off his old love tokens. To Haughey's fury, Keane also appeared on a popular Irish television chat show to expand on their relationship. Their 27-year relationship ended in a terse phone call the following day. 'Charlie didn't so much think that he would not get caught, he thought it would not matter if he did,' said Keane tartly. Like his hero Napoleon, Haughey, when he is not in the witness box, spends his final days in a gilded mansion, Abbeville, that has become his prison. He is deserted and alone, railing against his enemies and lamenting what could have been. Nothing will erase the ignominy, the shame, of his fall. It may be just, but it is a bitter end to an illustrious career. Even Charles Haughey might be forgiven for cursing that Florida police officer, far away across the Atlantic, who stopped Ben Dunne, and his secrets, from jumping from the Hyatt Regency's 17th floor balcony.

fields.headline: The perfect...
fields.standfirst: ... cappuccino
fields.trailText: ... cappuccino
fields.body:
I had my most perfect cappuccino in Turin, in a place called Caffè Turino on the main piazza. It's an old-fashioned coffee house, decorated in gold and full of wonderful furniture. It was a real cappuccino, charmingly finished off with a rose traced with the foam on top. I was on holiday, and there is nothing more relaxing than sitting in a café sipping coffee, watching people passing by and maybe bitching a little.

In England, there is a lot of misunderstanding around cappuccinos. Cafés in London tend to use the American method, so there's far too much liquid sloshing around in huge mugs. That's not cappuccino. It reminds me of pediluvium , which is the word they used in Roman times for the water left over from washing feet. A cappuccino should be 3fl oz, maximum.

The perfect cappuccino relies on the quality of the espresso and the milk. Coffee beans should be ground just before use and brewed - if possible - using soft water. You should resist the temptation to use semi-skimmed milk, even though it's easier to froth, because semi-skimmed takes in too much air and lacks substance. Full-fat milk is better, though it is difficult to froth.

Cappuccino needs to be kept hot, so heat the cup first and try to have very fine white sugar on hand for sweetening - it melts quickly. Finally, the whole thing should be dusted lightly with cocoa powder, not hot chocolate.

This is the way they do it in Italy - with flair and serious attention to detail. What we need here is a cappuccino school.
