If the symptoms do not improve within a day or two, however, consult your GP, as you may need to take antibiotics. If so, be sure to complete the prescribed course, even if you start to feel better before you're due to finish it. If you stop prematurely, you could risk exposing your body to another infection or could compromise the effectiveness of any antibiotics you may take in the future. If the antibiotics make you feel sick, you may find that eating a small snack regularly, rather than a large meal, eases your nausea. Ginger tea is also a good nausea-reliever - you can make it by infusing some peeled fresh root ginger in boiling water for a few minutes. As soon as you finish the course, try to replenish your body's natural bacterial balance by including some 'good' bacteria in your diet - eat a small pot of live yogurt containing acidophilus or bifidus every day (don't heat it, as this will kill the beneficial bacteria) or take acidophilus or bifidus tablets (available from health-food shops). I bet you didn't know that eating fruit and live yogurt after sex had so much more to offer than mere organoleptic appeal!

fields.headline: Sir seeks a cash lesson
fields.standfirst: Mike Clayton gave education a second chance and needs savings advice, says  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: Mike Clayton gave education a second chance and needs savings advice, says Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
Vital statistics

Mike Clayton
Age 33
Lives in Southend-on-Sea
Occupation Sports psychology teacher
Earns £17,000
Mortgage None
Debts Graduate loan and car loan
Investments None
Pensions Teachers' Pension
Aims To sort out housing, pension and savings

Mike Clayton always assumed he would end up in the family business. His parents ran a newsagent's shop at the RAF station at Linton-on-Ouse near York, and Mike went to work there straight from school. He had no qualifications: 'I was not at all academic at school,' he says. 'I just played a lot of sport.'

But, when he was 24, his parents sold up and retired. Mike had to make a choice: 'I had to decide whether to buy the store from them and continue running it or do something on my own.'

He decided to go back to education. 'I have done the right thing, but it was very topsy-turvy financially. I was used to having a car, going out and buying clothes, but as a student I was not even eligible for a grant.'

He took an access course and started a medical degree at Liverpool University but switched after two years to a sports science course; last year he did a master's degree at Chester. He is now in his second year teaching A-level sports psychology at Seevic Sixth Form College in Southend, Essex.

He had paid his way at Liverpool with various part-time jobs, including a spell as receptionist in a sports centre, and avoided a student loan. But, to afford his living expenses at Chester, he had to take a £2,500 graduate careers development loan from the HSBC bank. He is paying it back at £57 a month until 2005, but is unhappy that the bank persuaded him to delay payments for a year, which has cost him an extra £200 in interest.

'It was naivete on my part but the bank and I never actually worked out how much the interest would be over that year. I had no idea it would be that much and I am disappointed. If I had known, I would have repaid the loan straight away.'

His only other debt is a car loan costing£150 a month over three years.

He now rents a house with three others from the college but would like to buy eventually, although he cannot decide between getting a house on his own or investing in a larger property and renting out space. 'There are always new teachers living near the college who are looking for rooms.'

He will start thinking about buying this time next year, by which time he might have decided whether to stay in southern England or move back north, where property is cheaper. He has about £250 a month spare spending money, which he leaves in his savings account or HSBC current account. 'I help myself to money when I need it.'

He pays £78 a month to the Teachers' Pension Scheme and wants to use his spare money to increase his pension contributions and start saving.

Adviser 1: Ian Millward

Mike could transfer the £250 a month he pays in rent into a mortgage and, on his current salary, he could borrow up to £60,000. A repayment loan would cost about £450 a month. He could rent out one room for up to £4,250 a year tax-free under the Inland Revenue's Rent-a-Room scheme but, to borrow enough for a larger house, he needs to assure a lender that he will be able to find a lodger easily. He should think about increasing contributions to his Teachers' Pension through additional voluntary contributions (AVCs). The Teachers' AVC scheme is run by the Prudential, which is the most cost-effective route. On his current salary he can contribute no more than £212.50 gross a month to pensions but, as pension contributions are locked away until retirement, it is important to have other savings as well.

He could buy an individual savings account. Depending on how much risk he wants to take, he can choose either a mini cash Isa or a stocks and shares Isa where his capital can fall as well as rise and which should be held for at least five years.

He should also think about protection. His Teachers' Pension scheme pays out twice his salary on his death and this is sufficient while he is single and without dependents. But, if he settles down and starts a family, he should think about increasing the cover.

 Ian Millward works for Bath-based financial adviser Chase de Vere.

Adviser 2: Julie Lord

Buying a house is a good idea, although with Mike's income he will be able to borrow only around £60,000. An interest-only mortgage will cost £350 a month. Of course he also needs to start saving, perhaps in an Isa, to repay the loan.

With the £100 he should have left each month, I urge him to save something in a deposit account so that he has a proper emergency fund. I also suggest he invest in an Isa, such as the Fidelity Managed International Isa, which has flexibility and should give some capital growth.

He may consider making additional voluntary contributions to his pension, or possibly buying added years. If the normal retirement age is 60, and he has been teaching for two years, he can get only 29 years of service and could buy back a further 11 years. I suggest he does this later on rather than commit himself now while his finances are quite tight. In any event, there is an argument that Isas would be better than pension schemes while annuity rates provide relatively small pensions.

I would like to see Mike protect his income against accident, sickness or disability because clearly his whole financial future is at risk if he cannot earn any money. Therefore I think it imperative that he organise an income replacement plan and critical illness cover at least to cover his mortgage.

 Julie Lord is a certified financial planner with Cavendish Financial Management in Cardiff.

Advice is for guidance only.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Watchdog that needs to bark louder

fields.headline: Watchdog that needs to bark louder
fields.trailText: Practically anyone can set up as a credit broker peddling loans to people who cannot afford them
fields.body:
Practically anyone can set up as a credit broker peddling loans to people who cannot afford them.

The Observer knows this because one of our journalists, then a trainee, obtained a licence with few questions asked. That was nearly three years ago but there has been no improvement since in the system for policing credit brokers. The system is run by the Office of Fair Trading, and its shortcomings were highlighted in a damning report on the watchdog's work last week by the Commons Public Accounts Committee. The OFT revoked only 18 out of 150,000 licences between 1998 and 1999. Out of 21,200 applications, only 15 were refused. The report notes that the number revoked had fallen by two-thirds in the three years up to that period.

The committee believes the OFT has not done enough to protect consumers, not only those shopping for credit but in other fields, notably car repairs.

In the OFT's defence, it has undertaken some valuable research, especially in relation to financial prod ucts, and has persuaded banks to undo unfair mortgage penalties.

But the scope and quality of its work is inconsistent. It almost certainly lacks financial resources to act as an effective policeman and is hampered by inadequate legislation in several areas. Fixing this fusty bureaucracy may not be a headline grab ber for the Government, but long term the benefits for consumers could be huge.

INSURER Axa Equity & Law is on the hustings collecting votes from policyholders for its plan to share out 'orphan', or surplus, assets in its life insurance fund. Advertisements reminding policyholders of the 16 October voting deadline paint a rosy view of the management's proposals, but the problem for policyholders is that the structure of this deal is too complicated for most to judge.

It appears that shareholders will do disproportionately well, but bamboozled policyholders will almost certainly vote in favour because they are being offered cash, albeit less than they probably deserve. The best hope for policyholders is likely to be that the Consumers' Association succeeds in mounting a challenge during the court hearing that will follow the vote. Axa policyholders can find out more at www.which.net.

fields.headline: Safer ground for houses
fields.standfirst: The place is lovely but prone to subsidence or floods.  Graham Norton on why it is now easier to take a risk
fields.trailText: The place is lovely but prone to subsidence or floods. Graham Norton on why it is now easier to take a risk.
fields.body:
You've found the dream house. It's just a pity that around the corner is a nuclear plant, or it's in an area known for subsidence, or near a river that floods most winters.

Is it worth the risk?

There are numerous risk areas in the UK. Subsidence is common in the south-east of England, where there is London clay, and in ex-min ing areas like Nottingham and Stoke-on-Trent. Landslip is a particular problem on the southern and eastern coasts. South-west England had 27 flood alerts on a single night earlier this year.

Then there are the rarer problems. Some unlucky houses have had cars crash through their front rooms on more than one occasion, and the inhabitants of Rhos crowther, Pembroke, had an oil refinery explode nearby five years ago. But it now seems easier than ever to surmount the problems of getting a mortgage or insurance if your property is in a difficult or vulnerable area - at a price.

Mortgage lenders will usually lend as normal as long as there is enough insurance cover. 'We don't consider risky areas to be an issue,' says the Nationwide's Eva Ingleson. 'We'd probably send a valuer and if he identified the property as being located in a risk area we'd advise the borrowers and see if they could get insurance. If they couldn't, our specialist insurance services team might go back to the seller and ask where they got it insured originally.

'There are no areas where we simply will not lend. We would ask for special geographical reports, but if the property was structurally sound and could obtain buildings insurance, we'd do it,' says Ingleson.

Subsidence is the most common cause of mortgage and insurance problems. The Association of British Insurers says the industry paid out £375m for subsidence-related claims in 1998, and the Subsidence Claims Advisory Bureau receives between 600 and 700 cases each year from homeowners who have difficulty getting cover after subsidence has been diagnosed.

The ABI said house owners in Australia, South Africa and the US usually paid to put right subsidence themselves. This did not affect saleability.

'In Britain a lot of surveyors don't really know what subsidence is,' according to the bureau's technical administrator, Judith Stovell. 'Many of them see a crack in a 200-year-old building and say it's subsidence, but any building standing for 200 years would develop cracks.'

The bureau is one of a number of agencies to send out specialist surveyors to look at properties whose owners suffer difficulties in getting buildings insurance, and then seek quotes from Lloyd's underwriters.

The expense is increased by the time insurers say they require for assessment before taking action. Properties with tell-tale signs - wide cracks around doors and windows, nearby trees, or known volumes of clay in the soil - are usually monitored for six or 12 months.

Only then will many insurers consider paying out - if the policy includes subsidence in the first place. Some remedial measures tend to be avoided by insurers because of cost: underpinning is usually the most expensive option.

Like lenders, most major insurers claim that there aren't any no-go areas. 'For particular high-risk subsidence areas we may ask for additional information,' says Ray Facer, underwriting manager at Legal and General Insurance.

The company does not ask for any information about the geography of flood areas, even though 1.3 million households are at risk.

There were severe difficulties last winter, mostly in south-west England, and 21 people around Britain died in flood-related accidents.

Worst hit was Devon. Clive Lawrence, landlord of the Maltsters Arms in Harbertonford, near Totnes, was flooded twice in one week. 'The Environment Agency did remedial work during the summer but there was another scare when we had to sandbag the pub a few weeks ago,' he said.

'The insurance is organised through our bank and when it was renewed this year it was hiked up another £2,000. We're shopping around for a better deal.'

There is one advantage, Lawrence says: 'It certainly gives us something to talk about in the pub.'

 The Association of British Insurers: 020 7600 3333; the Environment Agency information floodline: 0845 9881188; Legal and General: 020 7528 6200; Nationwide: 0345 302010; Subsidence Claims Advisory Bureau: 01424 733727.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: People who were sent a tax return earlier this year have until the end of this month to complete the form if they do not want to calculate their tax liability themselves.
fields.body:
Hector's helpers
People who were sent a tax return earlier this year have until the end of this month to complete the form if they do not want to calculate their tax liability themselves. However, the 30 September date is a theoretical, rather than actual, deadline in most cases. The Inland Revenue will still do the sums for people who ask them to, even if the returns are sent in after that date. Officials warn , however, that they may then not be able to do the sums in time for them to meet their tax payment dates. There are no fines for people who miss the 30 September deadline: fines are imposed only on taxpayers who miss the far more important deadline of 31 January.

Rent risks cut
Worried about letting property to tenants who won't pay up, or renting from a landlord who will not return your deposit? The Association of Residential Letting Agents (Arla) has started a service aimed at encouraging own ers and people wanting to rent to deal only with its members. Its 'database of referred tenancies' warns of poor landlords and bad tenants. The database is open only to members, but Arla hopes it will be of general benefit by ensuring 'that bad landlords and tenants avoid coming to Arla agents'. A membership list is available on 01494-431123, or at www.arla.co.uk.

Cut your tax
Advice on cutting your tax bills and increasing your pension are among the issues dealt with in the latest edition of Rosemary Brown's Your Retirement: How to make the most of it , published this week by Kogan Page at £9.99. Available in book shops, on 01903-828800, or by emailing orders@lbsltd.co.uk.

Fuelling up
Age Concern is urging people over 60 to make sure they get their £150 winter fuel payments from the Government.

And it is reminding those receiving income support or income-based Job Seekers' Allowance that they can get up to £2,000 from the new Home Energy Efficiency Scheme Plus.

The fuel payments, due in December, go automatically to most over-sixties. But some need to claim it, including those working and not drawing pensions. The charity offers a free factsheet, 'Help with Heating' (Tel: 0800 00 99 66). The Government's fuel payments helpline is on 08459 151515.

Horse sense
Owning a racehorse is cheaper than you might think, says the British Horseracing Board. It reckons 20 co-owners can pay as little as £40 a week to buy and keep an animal. (Tel: 01753 441198.)

webTitle: Art: Miniaturist Gerrit Dou - Dulwich Picture Gallery

fields.headline: It's the little things
fields.standfirst: Miniaturist Gerrit Dou was a pupil of Rembrandt. Now he's coming out of the shadows
fields.trailText: Gerrit Dou 1613-1675 - Dulwich Picture Gallery
fields.body:
Gerrit Dou 1613-1675 Dulwich Picture Gallery, London SE21, until 19 November

A few years ago, a beautiful Rembrandt in the National Gallery suddenly ceased to be a Rembrandt. Scholars, connoisseurs and the crack detectives of the Rembrandt Research Project had been looking hard at the picture, a grave and tender study of blindness. Maybe there were a few details by the master - some ivy, a little fur, those sightless eyes - but after due deliberation, they decided it was by another artist. The gallery took the drastic but conscientious step of changing the label. Anna and the Blind Tobit was now painted by Gerrit Dou.

A few years later, after some judicious cleaning, the painting is a Rembrandt once more. Nothing has changed, least of all Dou's reputation, which hasn't been dredged from the ocean floor in over a century. There are those who believe Dou also painted The Man with the Golden Helmet, one of Rembrandt's most spectacular pictures. Yet even this extravagant claim hasn't burnished his former glory. You can buy a Dou for a relative pittance these days and practically nobody remembers his name.

Gerrit Dou is the incredible shrinking master. Once he was a colossus - 'unequalled in the Netherlands', wrote one contemporary connoisseur, 'and even in all other countries.' Now he has dwindled to a foot note. Not for nothing is the show that opens at Dulwich next week subtitled 'Rembrandt's First Pupil' - how else to promote this long-forgotten artist?

In the seventeenth century, the Golden Age of Dutch painting, Dou was bigger than Hals, more famous than Vermeer, massively richer than Rembrandt. The smallest of his pictures - and they are very small - could cost as much as a house. Cosimo de Medici traipsed across Europe to buy one, the Queen of Sweden was an avid collector. If Dou hadn't been such a prudent burgher, he could have become, like Van Dyke, a star at the English court. Instead he died a florin millionaire without once leaving his native Leiden.

Nobody travels far in Dou's art, which is resolutely stop-at-home. He paints neat, calm, well-swept rooms, generally lit by a window on the left, otherwise by candle or firelight. His figures sit tight indoors, reading, writing, smoking or dozing, peeling the occasional apple. Sometimes he frames the room within the picture, drawing back a painted curtain to reveal the scenario. Sometimes the figures lean towards you across a high-illusion sill, holding a violin or a paintbrush and palette. With very few exceptions, the nearest Dou gets to the great outdoors is a housewife watering a window box.

His gift is for small-scale detail, reality in perfect miniature. Get up close to these pictures - or as close as the barriers at Dulwich allow - and you see the intimate interiors of seventeenth-century Leiden summarised in little more than eight or nine inches. A hazy mirror, a vial of liquid, the darn in a Persian rug: Dou could paint a broomstick no bigger than a fingernail, moreover, without leaving any trace of his brush. This was no small miracle two centuries before the first photograph.

Dou was the best of Holland's fijnschilders - fine painters - and he worked with the finest materials, three-hair brushes, colours ground on glass, wood instead of canvas which had too much give for his high-finish look. It is said that he waited for every last speck of dust to settle in the studio before selecting a brush. A German visitor claimed that Dou's sitters look intensely bored because the artist took five days to underpaint a single hand. This is hyperbole - Dou's portraits can be lively, quick with observation. But he is known to have charged by the hour.

Set against this amazing all-over detail, however, is the complete lack of any central incident in Dou's paintings. Other than a few textbook genre scenes - doctors paying house visits, quacks selling snake oil to provincial dupes - literally nothing happens. There is no back story, no implicit future, no mystery to his subjects.

Dou is no sort of Vermeer. He doesn't have a particle of Rembrandt's genius for psychology or emotion. No surprise, then, that he began to shrink in the age of red-hot Romanticism. He was barely 15 when he became Rembrandt's first pupil and his early work is a visual record of the experience. He paints Rembrandt's parents, Rembrandt's props, Rembrandt's subject matter, himself as a tiny Rembrandt with brushes and beret. But where Rembrandt's old woman reading a bible is deeply absorbed in the spiritual revelations of the book, Dou's is simply scanning the words. She is no more than her dutiful action.

The curious thing about this painting, unusually big for Dou, is that the bible is larger than life yet the words on the open page are an unreadable blur. Dou's famous sense of scale can be oddly unstable. His trompe-l'oeil still lifes of books, globes and other scholarly paraphernalia are much too small to work, since trompe l'oeil has to be scrupulously life-size. The faces in his seven-inch portraits will be brilliantly realised, but then he'll mismatch them with bodies so tiny they look like children's toys.

Perversely, Dou's talent often comes across better in blown-up reproductions, when all the attributes of his extraordinary skill are apparent to the last candle flicker, droplet and iota of dust. At their best, his details can be really startling - the submerged and eerie world inside a pickled shellfish jar, a blue-black cabbage leaf gleaming like a peacock feather, an hourglass glinting in the midnight shadows. Small pleasures, maybe, but one wouldn't wish to understate them with absurd claims that Dou could ever have painted a single one of the Rembrandts in the National Gallery.

webTitle: Classical: The Berlin Philharmonic leave us spellbound

fields.headline: 'No one coughs or moves... the Albert Hall holds its breath'
fields.standfirst: The Berlin Philharmonic leave us spellbound, but a rendition of Carl Ruggles is a struggle
fields.trailText: Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra | San Francisco Symphony | Salvator Rosa
fields.body:
Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra Royal Albert Hall/Radio 3
San Francisco Symphony Royal Albert Hall/BBC2/Radio 3
Salvator Rosa Dorset Opera, Sherborne School, Dorset

You know a great performance when, like a gripping book, you dread to reach the end. From the mysterious, exploratory opening of Beethoven's Seventh Symphony to the whirlwind finale, the Berlin Philharmonic's performance was one to savour greedily, each bar demanding - and achieving - total concentration from listener and player alike. Attack, detail, dynamics, clarity of phrase and structure, beauty of sound, these are the ingredients of a world-class orchestra, possessed by the Berlin players in abundance and brought to fruition by Bernard Haitink (replacing an indisposed Claudio Abbado). Of course to some extent these matters are subjective, but not entirely: when an orchestra catches the audience's attention, the effect is palpable. No one coughs or moves as if the entire auditorium is engaged in a collective holding of breath - which in a full Albert Hall is quite some feat.

The arrival of the major foreign orchestras at the Proms as they reach their home stretch always adds end-of-season zest and heightens expectation. In two programmes, the Berlin PO chose the standard, mainstream German repertoire for which they are celebrated: Wagner, Bruckner, Strauss, Beethoven and, for an encore, Schubert. Since they still do it better than anyone (sweeping statements must be allowed occasionally), their conservatism is justified - though whether Simon Rattle, when he takes over, will share that narrow view is another matter. To hear Beethoven played with such dazzling purity, in any case, is always an avant-garde adventure.

The brisk performance highlighted the keen economy of Beethoven's score, in which not one note is wasted. How starkly this contrasts with Strauss's sprawling, episodic and somewhat inconsequential tone-poem, Don Quixote, played in the first half of the programme, with Natalia Gutman (cello) and Wolfram Christ (viola) as soloists. Despite using nearly twice the orchestral resources, this hybrid concerto sounds pale and inflated in comparison, the energy spent rather than sustained. Strauss, a conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic for one year in the 1890s, writes virtuosic solos for the orchestra and uses his forces to brilliant, showy effect. But to what end?

The formidable Berliners were followed by that great showman among conductors, Michael Tilson Thomas who could make a pile of stones dance, given the challenge. Since becoming music director of the orchestra in 1995, he has poured his energies into the San Francisco Symphony which plays with renewed life and vigour, if not quite the finesse of its Berlin colleagues.

Always a champion of the new, Tilson Thomas has worked hard to convince audiences of the elusive charms of Carl Ruggles (whose family crest apparently included the word 'struggle', a point not lost on this difficult composer - or his audiences). The irascible American modernist, who lived in a log cabin in New England and took years to complete each of the handful of pieces he wrote in his long life, never won much recognition. As a programme note reminds us, he was heckled at a concert in 1931, prompting his friend the composer Charles Ives to respond: 'You goddam sissy! When you hear strong masculine music like this, get up and use your ears like a man!' (i.e. Say not the Ruggles Naught Availeth). Sun-treader (1926-31), his tribute to Shelley, is loud, apocalyptic, dissonant and doleful. The San Francisco brass revelled in it but even their ardour could not quite convince, intriguing and valid though it was to hear the piece. It certainly warmed them up for an ear-piercing and electrifying account of Stravinsky's Rite of Spring after the interval.

The work which the crowd had come to hear was Schumann's Piano Concerto in A minor, Op 54, played by the renowned Argentinian pianist Martha Argerich, whose public appearances are so rare and treasured that she quite deserves her living-legend reputation. Trying to define her particular qualities, especially a work in which piano and orchestra are evenly matched rather than in gladiatorial combat, is no easy task. Muscularity combined with complete musical and physical control and extraordinary fluidity is about half the story. Her reputation adds to the excitement of her performances, allowing occasional smudges to pass almost unnoticed while for a lesser artist they would matter - such is the unfairness of stardom. She was called back at least five times by a preparedly ecstatic audience.

A brief, belated word of praise for Dorset Opera, a well-established semi-professional company which had the initiative to raise Salvator Rosa, if not from the dead, at least from a very deep sleep. The cue for its revival was this year's 'Brazil 500' festival in celebration of that country's half-millennial anniversary. Carlos Gomes (1836-1896) studied in Rio de Janeiro but spent most of his life in Italy, absorbing the grand operatic styles of Rossini, Donizetti and Verdi. Had Puccini not arrived on the scene and eclipsed this real but lesser talent, Gomes might have remained known today. His four-act opera, based on the life of the seventeenth-century Italian painter, bursts with conflict and bloodshed, grand choruses and pulsating melodies, reminiscent of middle-period Verdi. Dorset Opera, performing in high style on the enchanting, if tiny, stage of Sherborne School, made it enthralling. The very name Dorset conjures up a sleepy rurality: all the more rewarding then to encounter such musical excitement.

webTitle: Today nappies, tomorrow wiping up on Wall Street

fields.headline: Today nappies, tomorrow wiping up on Wall Street
fields.standfirst: How to get kids to click on to matters of pounds and pence, what the syllabus suggests and the new soap that gets personal
fields.trailText: How to get kids to click on to matters of pounds and pence, what the syllabus suggests and the new soap that gets personal.
fields.body:
1920s Germany: a class for teenagers

In a pilot study in Salford, teenagers in a secure unit were taught about the value and nature of money, and the effect of inflation over time by looking at German hyperinflation in the 1920s.

They were shown large facsimiles of old German banknotes and then shown a video where a man went into a cafe, had a coffee, paid and walked out. He is then shown coming back the next day and having a difficult conversation with the waiter when the time came to pay.

The children were asked what could have happened. One possibility put forward was that of a tourist being ripped off - but the real explanation was hyperinflation.

'The lesson was engaging, motivating and challenging,' says Peter McNamara who oversaw the class. 'The children were really responsive. We stimulated their curiosity.'

Your dream shopping list: a brainstorming session for older primary school children

Teaching children that they may need to save if they really want to buy something could be done by asking them to come up with a shopping list of things they would most like to buy. This could lead into a discussion of where they keep the money.

Are there safer places to keep it than in a piggy bank? In a purse or savings account, for example?

Another subject that can flow out of the dream shopping list is planning ahead and considering the possibility of borrowing.

Where does money come from: a class for young primary school children

The class can be taught to see the difference between regular and unpredictable sources of money by being asked to name and discuss some sources.Sources will include earnings, pensions, winnings, benefit payments, pocket money and gifts.

The cost of buying nappies: a class for 14-year-olds

Is it better to use disposable nappies or washable ones? With 750,000 babies born each year, this is a big issue.

A group of 14 year-olds were asked to work out the numbers of nappies used each day and the financial and other costs, including an examination of the environmental consequences.

The lesson could be modified to teach to younger age groups.

Vital lessons for life - what the syllabus says

Age 5-7: Coins and notes

Making choices about money (eg spending v saving); The sources of money and the importance of looking after it; Different choices people make about spending; Social and moral issues.

Age 8-11: Making simple financial decisions

How to spend your cash, including pocket money and charitable donations; Looking after money; Saving; Varying living standards across time and place; Different values and attitudes to money; Calculating simple percentages; Solving problems.

Age 11-13: What influences our financial decisions?

How to be a competent money manager; Paying for local and central government; Insurance and risk; Social and moral dilemmas; How consumer choices can affect other people's economies and environments; Solving complex numerical problems; Calculating percentages, ratio and proportion.

Age 14-16: Financial decision-making

Money management; Budgeting, saving and other financial processes; Sources of financial help and advice; How the economy functions; The rights and responsibilities of consumers, employers and employees; Risk and return in savings and investments; The social, moral, ethical and environmental consequences of financial decisions; Solving complex numerical problems; Interpreting social statistical information.

More detailed information is available in the documents 'Financial Capability through Personal Financial Education', guidance for schools at key stages 1 & 2, and 3 & 4 (on the DfEE website).

Soaps get personal

The first personal finance soap opera, Looking after the Pennies , will be broadcast in March, aimed at 11 to 14-year-olds.

The fictional Penny family, living in the North- west, have their share of financial challenges. How will Scott, 15, fund the pay-as-you-go mobile phone that his father sent him? Will he be able to afford the football season ticket that he craves? Will his girlfriend, Kate, help him, or will he somehow scrape together enough from his paper round?

The three-part series (broadcast from 9.30- 9.55am on three consecutive Fridays from 9-23 March) is part of Channel 4's schools services. The people it portrays are a long way from the Janet-and-John style families of the past. Sally and her second husband, Geoff, have a baby daughter, Lara. Also in the frame are Sally's two children from her first marriage: Scott and student Emma. Emma, 18, is managing a student loan, holding down a part-time job and wondering how to deal with the debts on her store cards. In the background are the grandparents - the wise grandfather who dispenses good solid advice, and his racier wife who is addicted to the lottery.

The soap does not completely follow the format of Brookside, however. The financial issues are to be left open-ended, with the viewing schoolchildren suggesting their own solutions.

fields.headline: And the Dutch score a hat-trick...
fields.trailText: Nederlands Dans Theater - Playhouse and Festival Theatre, Edinburgh
fields.body:
Nederlands Dans Theater Playhouse and Festival Theatre, Edinburgh

Brian McMaster, determined to end the festival dance programme with a bang, invited all three Nederlands Dans Theater companies to bring sure-fire hits for the final week. They have been here before, with enigmatic pieces from their current repertoire: this was our chance to revisit the work that made Jiri Kylian's reputation as a choreographer and director.

After 25 years with NDT, Kylian has handed over his directorial responsibilities to Marian Sarstadt. He remains as 'artistic adviser', and was very much in charge of rehearsals at the Playhouse with Sir Charles Mackerras and the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra. Only an ambitious festival like this could have brought these musicians and dancers together with Mackerras, who had put his ballet-conducting days behind him.

The show-piece of NDT1's triple bill was Sinfonietta, Kylian's 1978 ballet to Janácek's music of the same name. Kylian was commissioned to create a piece at short notice when the Charleston Festival in South Carolina was commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of Janácek's death. The young choreographer's response was so joyously apt that Sinfonietta has remained a favourite with dance audiences ever since. It received a standing ovation in Edinburgh.

The dancers soar on the music, lifted by the updraft from the brass section positioned in boxes at the side of the stage. The men cover space in huge leaps, the women assisted in their flight by their partners. There is a sense of urgency, a pressure to communicate, that is missing from Kylian's later works. Danced with such evident relish, this early piece is irresistible.

Compared with Balanchine's ballets earlier in the festival, however, Kylian's musicality is unsophisticated. His dancers are not an integral part of the score, used as instruments. They wheel instead like instinctive storks, migrating between homelands. In his 1981 Forgotten Land, another emotive reaction to powerful music, Britten's Sinfonia da Requiem , the backdrop by John Macfarlane suggests the reed beds of the fens or Eastern European marshes.

The bleak landscape changes from black and grey to sunlit colour as the community of dancers splits into couples. Mackerras supports them with a thrillingly ominous pulse after the hammer blows of the opening lament. Forgotten Land is one of those angst-ridden pieces to which all too many Kylian imitators resort. Bodies are wracked with grief; spirits rise, only to be dashed; defiant survivors are silhouetted against the dying light.

Kylian has since evolved a more eccentric, almost grotesque, way of moving. His house style is reflected, to some extent, in the work of Paul Lightfoot, the English choreographer who seems his heir apparent. Lightfoot's Speak for Yourself was the centrepiece of NDT1's bill at the Playhouse; his Small Moves dominated the Festival Theatre programme shared by NDT2 and 3, the junior and senior companies.

In both recent pieces, Lightfoot proposes man as the measure of all things. In Speak for Yourself, to Bach fugues, a solitary figure makes the opening and closing statements. A plume of smoke rises from his body, echoed by mists of golden rain that fall on the other eight parched souls. Their slitherings are eloquent, but even less specific than Kylian's couplings. Lean limbs, slicked with water, trace lovely arcs, but there is a kind of rage that relationships - or lives - are so ephemeral.

In Small Moves, for four NDT3 dancers between 40 and 64, the movement becomes increasingly simian: bent knees, dangling arms, shaking heads. The performers, toplit to emphasise their ageing flesh, triumphantly assert their personalities in the face of the indignities inflicted upon them. As in Paulo Ribeiro's New Age for them on the same bill, the challenge is not to appear ridiculous. The company's choreographers share a tendency to make dancers seem dumber than they are - either funny ha ha or funny peculiar, pulling faces and dragging their knuckles along the ground.

Only one brief piece in the Festival Theatre programme, Hans van Manen's Solo for NDT2, enabled its three youngsters simply to get out there and dance. They have been here before, with enigmatic pieces from their current repertoire: this was our chance to revisit the work that made Jiri Kylian's reputation as a choreographer and director. After 25 years with NDT, Kylian has handed over his directorial responsibilities to Marian Sarstadt. He remains as 'artistic adviser', and was very much in charge of rehearsals at the Playhouse with Sir Charles Mackerras and the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra. Only an ambitious festival like this could have brought these musicians and dancers together with Mackerras, who had put his ballet-conducting days behind him. The show-piece of NDT1's triple bill was Sinfonietta, Kylian's 1978 ballet to Janácek's music of the same name. fields.headline: 'If only I'd had cash classes'
fields.standfirst: Money a barrier for single mother
fields.trailText: Money a barrier for single mother
fields.body:
Irene Blaszkiewicz learnt little at school about personal finance - and she wishes she had been taught it formally at her mixed comprehensive in Sutton Coldfield.

Now 42 and a lone parent for the last 12 years, she thinks her tight financial position would have been eased if she had been introduced in the classroom to the benefits of saving.

Since her husband left, she says, 'I have struggled a lot financially. I had nothing to fall back on. I didn't understand about insurances and I didn't like the idea of them, so I didn't bother to save. If I had done, I could have had something maturing now.'

She pays the way for herself and her two teenagers through a part-time job as a mentoring co-ordinator for the National Council for One-Parent Families.

But when her marriage failed she was not prepared for getting into the job market: 'There is a huge gap in your knowledge when you start taking the first steps to get into work. I wouldn't regard myself as totally inept but, once my husband and I parted, the prospect of running a home and getting money in left me quite fearful as to how I would manage.'

She also wishes she had been taught to question more, rather than take an uncritical view of authority. 'People should be taught to shop around, to be more choosy about what they buy, to ask what the pitfalls are.' She was shocked when her insurer said it would not pay her claim on a burnt carpet because, it said, the damage was her fault. 'You need to be taught to look for the loopholes.'

She is extremely enthusiastic about personal finance education. 'There are ways of making it interesting,' she says.

She wants it extended to help people understand basic skills for work: 'When you sit someone in front of a telephone in an office, they have no idea at first.'

webTitle: When one plus  one adds up to an Isa

fields.headline: When one plus  one adds up to an Isa
fields.standfirst: Children heading for school will now find personal finance on the curriculum
fields.trailText: Children heading for school will now find personal finance on the curriculum.
fields.body:
Whether they know it or not, most people have been seriously ripped off several times in their lives. Most of us can think of times we have been badly short-changed - whether it was the endowment policy that we were mis-sold, the insurance cover that was not worth the paper it was written on or the hideously expensive loan we were persuaded to take out.

But, from this week, steps are being taken to try to ensure that consumers are never again treated as fools on such a massive scale. In the revised National Curriculum, personal finance gets its biggest billing yet. The hope is that children will grow into more discerning adults if they learn how to handle money and ask the right questions.

Although teaching personal finance is not compulsory, it is 'the Government's wish to include financial capability as a topic at all key stages,' says the Department for Education and Employment.

Teachers would be within their rights not to teach it, but many are expected to do so. If pressure on schools to include the subject is maintained, it could quickly become almost universal. But much will depend on the attitude of Ofsted inspectors. Will they mark down schools that leave it out? And something as simple as a personal finance question in a GCSE paper would focus teachers' minds.

A personal finance syllabus has been worked out and made available to teachers. The Financial Services Authority - the regulator whose job is to reduce mis-selling and bad buying - advised on the contents. The FSA's Gill Hind, says: 'We are not sure yet how much they will do. In the same slot, they have to deal with issues such as health, sex and drugs.' Peter McNamara, the Salford-based co-ordinator of several pilot schemes on personal finance education, is optimistic: 'Until now, the teaching of personal finance depended on the whim of the teacher. Now, it is much more prominent. We're all living a lot longer in a world that is constantly changing. To be financially competent is probably more important now than ever.'

But the problem for all schools and teachers is lack of time . Much as many may want to look at money issues, they may feel that they have no time left after meeting the requirements to improve basic literacy and numeracy. It can be easy for politicians to urge a new approach but difficult for teachers to get everything into the timetable.

So personal finance has been squeezed uneasily into a ragbag subject called 'Per sonal, social and health education and citizenship'. In its guidance notes to teachers, the DfEE says: 'It is intended that this topic fit within existing structures and require a change of emphasis within the curriculum rather than the introduction of new subject matter.'

So a maths teacher might ask pupils to calculate the return on pension investments or to work out a budget. An English teacher could get pupils to read the small print in financial policies. It is possible, however, that the subject will be made compulsory in future.

The DfEE's guidance to teachers says self-reliance is ever more important in a world that is becoming more complicated financially: 'Changes in working patterns away from a "job for life" ... will have implications for the regularity of income'.

At the same time, however, children may be getting less exposure to financial issues, the DfEE says: 'Experiences of spending pocket money are also changing, as parents become less willing to allow children to go to a shop unaccompanied. The role of cash may be unclear [as many people are] paying for the week's groceries with a plastic card. Increasingly complex adult financial arrangements may mean that children become cut off from the financial planning of their carers.'

If teachers and parents are confused about how they can develop children's financial knowledge and acumen, at least there are some organisations that are willing to help. Educationalists are concerned to see that personal finance is taught in a stimulating way. The FSA is sending a copy of a free booklet to every primary school in England and Northern Ireland, with versions for Wales and Scotland to follow soon.

The guide, Money Counts, gives examples of stimulating ways to teach the subject - such as lessons in which the children act as detectives to find some missing money, or working out how to afford to buy a bike.

The Personal Finance Education Group of educationalists and representatives of financial institutions will continue to lobby to ensure that treatment of the subject is not just tokenistic. It has a website with examples of the way it was taught in pilot studies.

There is also a move to develop a broader approach to general consumer issues. For most of the last decade, teachers have been encouraged to teach these across several subject areas. Children could have learnt, for instance, how to collect information on rival products and make the best decision on which to buy.

But in 1995 the National Consumer Council found that children were no better informed - not least because 'there was confusion over how cross-curricular themes were to be handled, as they were not obligatory,' the council said.

But the subject will receive more emphasis from 2002 when lessons in citizenship, which includes consumer issues, become compulsory for pupils aged between 11 and 16. It would be no surprise if the subject of personal finance developed along similar lines.

£1.50 in his pocket and he knows just how to spend it

Keir, a nine-year-old from north London, already knows which bank he would like to join - Gringott's Bank, in the Harry Potter books. It is a rather more interesting one than those in the high street: Harry uses a roller-coaster to reach the vaults.

Back in the classroom, Keir has started learning the basics about money - 'a quite interesting subject', he says. He would be happy to have more classes on it. The teacher has shown his class some coins and got them to work out, for instance, how many 10p coins there are in £1.

Keir has already seen the practical application of this. He was recently nearly short-changed by a shop-keeper: 'It took me a couple of minutes to realise. I was just walking out the door, and I said: "Can I get the rest of my money, please?" '

Being short-changed is serious for someone like Keir, who only has £1.50 a week pocket money.

He is already quite comfortable with ideas of saving - and even of lending. 'Usually I spend it on sweets but sometimes I save up for Pokémon cards.' This has sometimes involved him saving for five weeks to get a big £7.50 pack of cards. Then, occasionally, he lends the money, he says. 'If I lend money to Mum, she writes out an IOU.'

He is already starting to think about the way the bigger financial system works. One issue that particularly interests him is bank robberies - and he has his own proposed solution to cut down on this crime: 'They should have the bank at the top of the building and the money underground with safety locks.'

Related information

www.dfee.gov.uk/circulars
www.fsa.gov.uk/consumer
www.pfeg.org (personal finance education group)

Teachers can ring Gill Hind at the FSA on 020 7676 0926.

fields.headline: Guy's gangsters are Scorsese lite, but you can't walk away from Renée
fields.trailText: Snatch | Nurse Betty | Whatever | Miss Julie | Twin Falls Idaho
fields.body:
Snatch (102 mins, 18) Directed by Guy Ritchie; starring Brad Pitt, Vinnie Jones, Alan Ford, Mike Reid

Nurse Betty (108 mins, 18) Directed by Neil LaBute; starring Renée Zellweger, Morgan Freeman, Chris Rock, Greg Kinnear

Whatever 120 mins, 18) Directed by Philippe Harel; starring Philippe Harel, José Garcia

Miss Julie (100 mins, 15) Directed by Mike Figgis; starring Saffron Burrows, Peter Mullan, Maria Doyle Kennedy

Twin Falls Idaho (105 mins, 15) Directed by Michael Polish; starring Michael Polish, Mark Polish, Michele Hicks

It would be difficult not to have heard of Guy Ritchie, the writer-director of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, the good-looking, middle-class Englishman with the cockney accent who calls Madonna 'the missus' and last week got Brad Pitt to leave new bride Jennifer Aniston's side to attend the West End premiere of Snatch. He certainly has a feeling for publicity and a slick gift as a movie-maker. But his pictures - both set in a London underworld where it's still Krays after all these years - are like commercials for an undisclosed product or music promos for an unwritten song.

After some jocular credits, Snatch begins promisingly with a robbery of a diamond merchant's office in Antwerp by four thieves disguised as Hasidic Jews. Initially they're seen in black and white on a succession of CCTV screens, then when they reach their target, they're in colour as they grab the guns concealed on the chest of their leader.

Immediately Ritchie ruins things by speeding up the film, revolving the camera and cutting far too fast, establishing an irritating style that never lets up.

The robbers seize an 86-carat stone, big as a plover's egg, and this becomes the MacGuffin that draws together a variety of colourful low-lifers, all murderous, loquacious and none too bright, and most of them racial stereotypes. There are Jewish jewellers (from Hatton Garden and Manhattan); cockney hard men; Russian mafiosi; black thieves and yardies; and a band of Irish travellers led by Brad Pitt, who deliberately talks in a dialect that no one can understand. All have comic nicknames, and apart from chasing the diamond, many of the characters are involved in promoting and betting on illegal bare-knuckle boxing.

The only woman in sight, Sorcha Cusack as Pitt's mother, is known simply as Mum O'Neil and is incinerated in her caravan halfway through.

The violence is relentless, but somehow less oppressive than the stylised dialogue which is spoken at dictation speed - and runs to such lines as (of Boris the Blade): 'He's as bent as the Soviet sickle and as hard as the hammer that covers it.' Snatch is to The Long Good Friday and Performance what the sentimental underworld stories of Damon Runyon are to the novels of Elmore Leonard or Martin Scorsese's GoodFellas.

Neil LaBute's comedy thriller Nurse Betty isn't any more realistic than Snatch and has a scene in which a man is suddenly scalped that's infinitely more violent than anything in Ritchie's film. But it has ideas, genuine wit, and a vision that partly comes from a naturally misanthropic director trying to take a benign view of a sweet-natured, dim-witted girl.

Renée Zellweger is beguiling as Betty, a waitress in a small Kansas town who escapes from an oppressive husband and a drab life by fantasising that she's a nurse in 'A Reason to Love', her favourite medical TV soap opera. She's rather like Mia Farrow in The Purple Rose of Cairo. But Woody Allen's picture takes a surreal turn, while LaBute submits Betty to the traumatic experience of seeing her husband killed by mob enforcers while she's watching the soap in another room. As a result she experiences what psychiatrists call 'a fugue', a form of amnesia brought on by shock that results in the sufferer fleeing from their real identity into another world.

In Betty's case she believes she's the former girlfriend of the soap opera's hero, Dr David Ravell (Greg Kinnear) and heads off to Los Angeles to see him. She's pursued by a philosophical black hitman and his cynical, hip son, played with immense assurance by Morgan Freeman (who calls himself 'a garbage man of the human condition') and Chris Rock. They're after the drugs that the double-crossing husband has stashed in the trunk of the car his innocent wife is driving.

The deftly plotted movie, full of sharp dialogue, is about a society that finds it increasingly difficult to distinguish between fact and fiction and whose citizens seek solace in romantic illusion. Betty is merely a clinical example of a national condition and her encounters with - and entry into - the soap world, are hilariously contrived and, within the comic context, convincing. 'I think you set the official record for staying in character two hours ago,' the admiring soap soap star says of the bemused Betty.

Adapted from Michel Houellebecq's novel Extension du domaine de la lutte, Whatever stars its director Philippe Harel as an articulate, well-off computer expert in his early thirties who has lived alone for two years after the departure of a girlfriend and observes the absurdity of the world around him. Known only as 'Our Hero', he's like the withdrawn, unnamed narrator of Henri Barbusse's novel L'Enfer, Meursault, the protagonist of Camus's L'Etranger to which the film alludes, and the Kevin Spacey character in American Beauty.

There are incidents, but not much plot or development - Our Hero drifts through life, dining with a priest he's known since their student days, visiting provincial towns before Christmas with a cheerful, sad-sack colleague (dubbed 'an economic success but a sexual loser') to instruct company executives in new computer systems, having a minor heart attack and a breakdown. The soundtrack alternates between two narrators, one speaking in the third person, the other in the first, and the film's real interest resides in his wry, despondent, well-turned observations philosophical and social.

Strindberg's intense three-character play Miss Julie is a midsummer night's nightmare in which the wilful daughter of a Swedish count seduces and plays power games with her absent father's valet, Jean, on the family's estate.

Written in 1888, it's probably the first time a heroine's behaviour has been attributed to premenstrual tension, and is a key study of hypergamy, the anthropological term for forbidden sexual or marital relationships between people of different classes that the social anthropologist Geoffrey Gorer introduced to the general reader in the Fifties to link Lady Chatterley's Lover, Look Back in Anger and Room at the Top.

Anita Björk was an unforgettable Julie in Alf Sjöberg's great 1951 film, and probably the best stage version in English to date is Michael Elliott's 1965 National Theatre production starring Maggie Smith and Albert Finney. Mike Figgis's low-budget, highly theatrical Miss Julie isn't in the same class as either of these, and it strikes an early false note when on her first appearance Julie gives Jean a sharp slap in the face rather than the coquettish flick with a handkerchief that Strindberg prescribes.

But Saffron Burrows does well enough, towering over the stocky Peter Mullan, and threatening his Scottish burr with her patronising English accent. Maria Doyle Kennedy is a strong, sensible presence as Christine, the mediating cook, but I found the split screen for the sex scenes distracting in the wrong way.

Something of a cinematic curiosity, Twin Falls Idaho is written by the identical (extremely handsome) twins Michael and Mark Polish, and stars them as mutually reliant, conjoined twins, who've quit the circus to die together in a Californian hotel.

It's a slow, atmospheric affair that fails to deliver on its early promise. I was reminded of the legendary night when our own cinematic twins John and Roy Boulting lay in bed, totally silent, beside Spike Milligan, throughout a performance of Son of Oblomov at the Comedy Theatre. It also occurred to me that if Elisabeth Shue married one of this film's twins she'd be called Elisabeth Shue Polish.

She's rather like Mia Farrow in The Purple Rose of Cairo. But Woody Allen's picture takes a surreal turn, while LaBute submits Betty to the traumatic experience of seeing her husband killed by mob enforcers while she's watching the soap in another room. As a result she experiences what psychiatrists call 'a fugue', a form of amnesia brought on by shock that results in the sufferer fleeing from their real identity into another world. In Betty's case she believes she's the former girlfriend of the soap opera's hero, Dr David Ravell (Greg Kinnear) and heads off to Los Angeles to see him. She's pursued by a philosophical black hitman and his cynical, hip son, played with immense assurance by Morgan Freeman (who calls himself 'a garbage man of the human condition') and Chris Rock. They're after the drugs that the double-crossing husband has stashed in the trunk of the car his innocent wife is driving. The deftly plotted movie, full of sharp dialogue, is about a society that finds it increasingly difficult to distinguish between fact and fiction and whose citizens seek solace in romantic illusion. Betty is merely a clinical example of a national condition and her encounters with - and entry into - the soap world, are hilariously contrived and, within the comic context, convincing. 'I think you set the official record for staying in character two hours ago,' the admiring soap soap star says of the bemused Betty. Adapted from Michel Houellebecq's novel Extension du domaine de la lutte, Whatever stars its director Philippe Harel as an articulate, well-off computer expert in his early thirties who has lived alone for two years after the departure of a girlfriend and observes the absurdity of the world around him. Known only as 'Our Hero', he's like the withdrawn, unnamed narrator of Henri Barbusse's novel L'Enfer, Meursault, the protagonist of Camus's L'Etranger to which the film alludes, and the Kevin Spacey character in American Beauty. There are incidents, but not much plot or development - Our Hero drifts through life, dining with a priest he's known since their student days, visiting provincial towns before Christmas with a cheerful, sad-sack colleague (dubbed 'an economic success but a sexual loser') to instruct company executives in new computer systems, having a minor heart attack and a breakdown. The soundtrack alternates between two narrators, one speaking in the third person, the other in the first, and the film's real interest resides in his wry, despondent, well-turned observations philosophical and social. Strindberg's intense three-character play Miss Julie is a midsummer night's nightmare in which the wilful daughter of a Swedish count seduces and plays power games with her absent father's valet, Jean, on the family's estate. Written in 1888, it's probably the first time a heroine's behaviour has been attributed to premenstrual tension, and is a key study of hypergamy, the anthropological term for forbidden sexual or marital relationships between people of different classes that the social anthropologist Geoffrey Gorer introduced to the general reader in the Fifties to link Lady Chatterley's Lover, Look Back in Anger and Room at the Top. Anita Björk was an unforgettable Julie in Alf Sjöberg's great 1951 film, and probably the best stage version in English to date is Michael Elliott's 1965 National Theatre production starring Maggie Smith and Albert Finney. Mike Figgis's low-budget, highly theatrical Miss Julie isn't in the same class as either of these, and it strikes an early false note when on her first appearance Julie gives Jean a sharp slap in the face rather than the coquettish flick with a handkerchief that Strindberg prescribes. But Saffron Burrows does well enough, towering over the stocky Peter Mullan, and threatening his Scottish burr with her patronising English accent. Maria Doyle Kennedy is a strong, sensible presence as Christine, the mediating cook, but I found the split screen for the sex scenes distracting in the wrong way. Something of a cinematic curiosity, Twin Falls Idaho is written by the identical (extremely handsome) twins Michael and Mark Polish, and stars them as mutually reliant, conjoined twins, who've quit the circus to die together in a Californian hotel. It's a slow, atmospheric affair that fails to deliver on its early promise. I was reminded of the legendary night when our own cinematic twins John and Roy Boulting lay in bed, totally silent, beside Spike Milligan, throughout a performance of Son of Oblomov at the Comedy Theatre. It also occurred to me that if Elisabeth Shue married one of this film's twins she'd be called Elisabeth Shue Polish.

fields.headline: Bloody marvellous
fields.standfirst: Mutilation, torture, cannibalism and lashings of revenge. It's no wonder that Titus Andronicus seems contemporary
fields.trailText: Titus
fields.body:
Titus (162 mins, 18) Directed by Julie Taymor; starring Anthony Hopkins, Jessica Lange, Alan Cumming, Harry Lennix

In the ingenious 1973 Vincent Price movie Theatre of Blood, a ham actor takes his revenge on the critics who panned him by murdering them in the style of various Shakespeare plays, Robert Morley being despatched while eating a pie made from his dogs in homage to Titus Andronicus. In the century that has passed since the first Shakespearean movie (the 1899 Beerbohm Tree production of King John) it's the only time that this ferocious play has featured on the screen. This is all the more surprising when one considers that the Polish scholar Jan Kott, author of Shakespeare Our Contemporary, took advantage of the 1957 visit to Warsaw of the Peter Brook-Laurence Olivier Stratford production of Titus Andronicus to write a famous essay claiming that the cinema had revivified the way Shakespeare is performed and appreciated, helping us experience them again in a Renaissance context.

Now Julie Taymor, the American theatre director who put Disney's Lion King on the stage, has made her cinematic debut with a bold, breathtaking, superbly acted adaptation called simply Titus. Shakespeare our contemporary indeed, and with a vengeance, revenge becoming the motive of practically everyone involved. Her movie begins with a device used in the disastrous Adrian Noble film of A Midsummer Night's Dream where the whole play is dreamt by a little boy after he's fallen asleep reading the Lambs' Tales From Shakespeare. Here, a little boy is playing war games with his lead soldiers using ketchup as blood when an explosion outside leads to him being swept away to a coliseum in ancient Rome. There he witnesses the Roman general Titus Andronicus (Anthony Hopkins) returning in triumph with his muddy centurions, and with Tamora, Queen of the Goths (Jessica Lange), and her three sons as his prisoners.

In a dark, stylised, hieratic sequence, Titus decides to propitiate the deities for the deaths of his many sons by sacrificing to them Tamora's eldest boy, thus earning her undying enmity. Following this primitive opening, the movie modulates from the ancient world into something resembling Mussolini's Rome where Black shirts are rioting in the streets. On the steps of an iconic 1930s building, the fascistic Government Centre, Titus refuses to accept the national leadership, deferring to the late emperor's weak son, Saturninus (Alan Cumming), then acquiescing when Saturninus decides to marry his daughter, Lavinia, who is engaged to the new emperor's brother. Thus by doing his stoical duty to the gods and to the state, Titus has launched a remorseless series of events that will lead to the violent deaths of virtually everybody in the play (more than 30 named characters are killed, mostly on stage, as well as numerous other supporting figures), not to mention mutilation, rape, torture and cannibalism in the famous form of Tamora eating a pie baked from her sons' bodies.

Titus Andronicus contains the seeds of the great tragedies that followed - Titus anticipates Lear; his son Lucius (Angus MacFadyen) is a forerunner of Hamlet; Aaron (Harry Lennix), the black-hearted Moor committed to evil, looks forward to Iago; Tamora is the predecessor of Lady Macbeth. But this film refuses to wear the noble cloak of redemptive tragedy, preferring to skip along in a sprightly dance of death, with pauses for black humour and the acknowledgement of unbearable anguish. People may suffer, but they are not ennobled by their experience. The incessant cruelty, the sense that nothing turns out the way people of goodwill expect, is part of the experience of this past century. The abrupt switches of mood, the shafts of black humour, the pick 'n' mix of fashions and styles (in music, setting, decor), the sex 'n' violence, are characteristic of the art of our own time.

In an admiring review of the 1955 Brook production in The Observer, Kenneth Tynan remarked that 'it is the casualness of the killing that grows tiresome, as at a bad bullfight'. But though the film has flaws (I'm uneasy about the presence of the observing child, even though eventually he joins the action as Titus's grandson, and I don't like the kitschy visions), it seems to me a great bullfight and Anthony Hopkins's snorting old bull is armed with more than his horns. He and the rest of the cast have magnificent verse to speak and they handle it with verve and clarity

Titus starts out as a tired warrior, endures the horrors with stoicism, goes mad, experiences a broken heart, recovers his sanity but only occasionally has glimpses of humanity. He's called upon to kill a son and a daughter, to chop off his own hand, to fire off arrows to attract the gods, to lure an enemy into cannibalism. He runs the gamut from towering hero at the outset to gleeful avenger at the end. Serving up the infamous pie dressed as a chef, he awaits the diners' approval with simulated obsequiousness. Brook eliminated blood from his 1950s production and dropped Titus's chillingly comic line 'Why, there they are both, bakèd in this pie'. Julie Taymor has restored the gore and the wickedly comic line.

webTitle: Turning live reel into real life

fields.headline: Turning live reel into real life
fields.standfirst: Documentary-maker Angus Macqueen  defends the tricks used to deliver a true slice of life
fields.trailText: Documentary-maker Angus Macqueen  defends the tricks used to deliver a true slice of life.
fields.body:
What is the difference between a documentary and a home movie? Modern technology can deliver unexpurgated reality off the internet to any computer screen near you. Big Brother can claim to record what we are really like with its 24-hour access to the lives of its performers. The pure visual document is surely at hand - no danger of dastardly film-makers misleading the audience.

Making London with my co-director Tom Roberts over the past few months has raised a gamut of questions about what documentaries today are trying to achieve and how. The film is deliberately based on the 'day in the life' concept, an old chestnut that goes back to the very beginnings of British documentary tradition. The form was conceived out of a political and artistic movement to find out how real people lived and felt.

Perhaps the most influential example, certainly one that has inspired me, was Humphrey Jennings's Listen to Britain. Made during the Second World War, the film purports to capture the way people were responding to the German onslaught during the Blitz, and comes down to us as a celebration of that strange phenomenon called the British spirit. The film stretches from one afternoon to the next and is constructed to suggest immediacy and improvisation; real people expressing emotions caught in the moment.

Today the film-makers would be hung out to dry on tabloid headlines for misleading the audience. Technology in 1941 did not allow observation in the form we understand it now; 35mm cameras could not be handheld, sound equipment was driven around in. Not only was Listen to Britain not filmed over one day but all the shooting was planned in advance. Canadian soldiers were hired to sing in specially lit railway carriages, which stood in sidings. What made it documentary was that the people were who they acted. The achievement of the film, and those like it, is to take you to the heart of a historical moment, an achievement finally shaped by the director, film editor and all involved. The film has a clear vision of what it is about.

Faced with trying to achieve something similar in 2000, we decided to film everything in a single day - in this case the day after London's first mayoral election. We set out to exploit to the maximum the flexibility that lightweight cameras, CCTV and other modern gizmos give us. Our editorial intention was the opposite of Jennings's. While he had sought to communicate a society united despite all its social differences, we set out to capture the sheer variety of individual lives that exist in any modern city, rubbing together but essentially carrying on independently.

For all the greater authenticity of the shooting, at heart the film-making process was similar. We made lists of scenes, places, types. We drew up a structure of characters and events that were prearranged to ensure that we had some sequences to edit at the end of the day. Yet we allowed directors and crews the maximum flexibility to pick up what happened in the town as they were passing: Jennings could never have caught a drunken couple feeling each other up in a dark underpass or two girls 'tripping' their way through Chinatown.

Equally, we had worked out itineraries and goals - and in most cases characters and scenes to work with. We then tried to observe the world through their eyes, as opposed to restaging what we wanted, but the distinction in some cases is marginal. In the final film we use the bits that feel real, where the subjects have by and large forgotten the camera is there. No different, I suspect, from Jennings's film editor.

By claiming or even seeking greater 'realism' from modern technology, have we created a rod for our own backs? The art of 'making' a film is sacrificed to the guidelines of broadcasters and regulators set down because the concepts of truth, authenticity and reality have all got confused.

So a number of directors have moved back to staging their documentaries. Penny Woolcock's wonderful Tina Goes Shopping, shown on C4 last year, is just one that uses a method not that far from that of Jennings - but for different reasons. You research the story, structure it and then employ the people you researched to act themselves. Restaging reality.

Ultimately London will succeed or fail on the same terms as Listen to Britain: the advance editorial selection, the skill on the day of the shoot and, in particular, the editing of hundreds of hours of material (that's only five days of internet-reality TV) into a shape or vision that says something more than the sum of its images.

As Dai Vaughan wrote in his book on the making of Jennings's films: 'Films which simply remind us of what we have experienced are not documentaries, but home movies.' We must still make the documents.

 London will be shown tonight on BBC2, 10pm. Angus Macqueen's Vodka, A Russian Fairytale is on next Saturday, C4, 7.45pm
